PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Trade, Senator Cook, is overseas on government business. He will return on 23 October. During his absence I will take questions relating to the portfolios of trade and primary industries and energy. I also inform the Senate that the Minister for Science and Small Business, Senator Schacht, is overseas on government business. He will return this week—before question time on 20 October. During Senator Schacht's absence, questions relating to the portfolio of industry, technology and regional development should be directed to Senator Ray; questions relating to environment, sport and territories should be directed to Senator Richardson; and Senator Bolkus will take questions on tourism.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I refer the minister to the assurances given by the Prime Minister, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and five other senior ministers to the National Farmers Federation that pastoral leases would extinguish native title. Was the minister one of the five ministers who gave that assurance and can the minister now continue to assure the rural community that the undertaking that was given to it in relation to pastoral leases will be held?

—The entire issue of the Mabo submission, as Senator Hill knows full well, is a matter that will be discussed this afternoon in cabinet. I will confine my contribution to that debate to the proper place for debating it; that is, the cabinet room. I also advise Senator Hill, for future reference, that the minister that has the primary carriage of the Mabo legislation is the Prime Minister, and his representative in this chamber is Senator Gareth Evans.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. If ever there was a question that specifically related to the activities of a particular minister, it was that question; it asked him that. I therefore ask you to make it clear to Senator Collins that his answer was quite beside the point, that it was a question directed to him and that if he chooses not to answer it then he should say so.
—There is no point of order. Senator Collins is making a point about who is responsible for the legislation.
—Has he finished his answer?
—I do not know. Senator Collins, have you finished your answer?
—Yes.

—I ask the minister a supplementary question in his representational capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Was the minister one of the ministers who gave such undertakings to the National Farmers Federation that pastoral leases would in fact override native title; and, is the government still standing by the assurances that it gave to the federation?
—I have neither the authority in respect of the Aboriginal affairs portfolio—
—You often speak without authority.
—Look, Richard, I am answering the question.
—Order! I am trying to listen to the minister.

—Senator Alston is the Senate's chief interjector. I am not in a position to give such assurances to the pastoral industry either in the capacity of minister for primary industry or as the minister with the primary carriage of the Mabo legislation. I have neither so far as the government is concerned. I say again that the Mabo issue is being discussed in cabinet this afternoon and the minister who has carriage of that portfolio responsibility in this chamber is Senator Gareth Evans, who represents the Prime Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. I ask the question because of my concern for the general health of the public and for the environment. Last week was Fire Awareness Week. As part of the week's activities, concerns were raised about the damaging effects on the ozone layer of halon gas, commonly found in yellow fire extinguishers, which are widespread in the community. There were calls for members of the community to hand in their yellow fire extinguishers. Can the minister tell me what the government is doing to facilitate this collection process?

—The use of halon gas is a significant environmental issue and there are community concerns about ozone. As I am sure all honourable senators are aware, halon, which is used very effectively in fire suppression systems, has proved to be extremely aggressive in ozone depletion. It is a big cause of concern with regard to our obligations under the Montreal protocol on substances that deplete the ozone layer. Therefore, there has been considerable pressure on governments around the world to act in some way to reduce the prevalence of halon.

PARA.TAB: The important thing to note is that, in normal usage, halon is not dangerous or harmful to people, animals or plant life and the bulk storage of halon does not pose a threat to the community. This is not one of those issues where we will have a scare campaign about its storage but it does pose a significant threat to the ozone layer. Unless the extinguishers are properly maintained, they will leak. Some forms of halon are up to 16 times more damaging to the ozone layer than CFCs. So we are not talking about a minor issue. There are 5,000 tonnes of halon in current use in Australia: 70 per cent is held by the Commonwealth and state governments, 15 per cent by major corporations, and 15 per cent by small business and the community.

It was very important that we set up an environmentally responsible process for handling this potentially very damaging substance on this scale. We have established a halon bank, which is being managed by the Centre for Environmental Management in my department. It commenced collections in May this year and depots have been established in each city.

I am happy to say that we are at the vanguard of technological development in this area and the expectation is that the DAAS CEM halon bank will set new international standards for the management of this ozone depleting substance. As far as I am aware, it is the only functioning halon bank in the world. We are setting the standard here, as I think we should.

DAAS CEM has been invited to participate in various international conferences by the US EPA, the United Nations environment program and Environment Canada with regard to these matters to evaluate the pacesetting technology that we are developing here. While this is not one of the issues that are at the forefront of the public mind because there does not seem to be any contention about it here in the Senate—I am sure everybody supports what is happening—it is nevertheless important to reiterate that we are doing these positive, groundbreaking things that are very important. I thank Senator Burns for his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I am obliged to Senator Collins for the advice he gave us that questions touching on the Prime Minister's responsibilities should be directed to Senator Gareth Evans. Less than one month ago the Prime Minister solemnly released a document entitled Mabo—outline of proposed legislation on native title, which stated that where there is or has been valid freehold or leasehold title, native title does not exist. How can this clear and unequivocal statement be reconciled with the Prime Minister's secret deal that will now allow native title to coexist with leasehold title?

—This issue will be considered by cabinet this afternoon. Nobody should jump to any conclusions about what the outcome of those deliberations will be unless and until they have taken place. Whatever decisions are taken by cabinet about the question of extinguishment in relation to pastoral leases and the possibility of some coexistence of native title, to the extent that it is totally consistent with the continued enjoyment of the rights in question—issues which are the subject of live current debate—it needs to be understood that those decisions could only conceivably have application in relation to a tiny minority, if any, of the number of pastoral leases that have been issued in this country.

PARA.TAB: What those opposite need to understand, because it obviously has not got inside their heads, is that the government's legislation only covers leases which are invalid by virtue either of the prima facie operation of the Racial Discrimination Act, in the sense that it would amount to some denial of proper process—a denial of procedural justice—taking into account rights which might exist; or the application of some other law, conceivably a law relating to a breach of fiduciary duty unrelated to the Racial Discrimination Act. It is only leases in respect of which an affirmative native title can be established in relation to the land in question—and a very large number of hurdles have to be jumped over before one gets to that extent. It is only land where, once native title has been established, one can also establish some basis for invalidity on either of the bases I have suggested; it is only in that context that this legislation will have any bite or application at all.

It is only leases which are invalid for any of the reasons I have mentioned that are actually validated by the legislation which has been the subject of so much discussion. It is only, conceivably, a tiny, tiny percentage, if any, of all the leases that have been granted that could possibly give rise to any question of doubt, or have any impact at all, whatever decision might be taken about the effect of such a validation in relation to the extinguishment of the native title over the land in question or what would be the effect of a coexistence if any native title were held to exist.

It is about time those opposite got that into their heads, and it is about time some of the scaremongers in the community got that into their heads. This lot opposite is not interested in good public policy; this lot is not interested in good government; this lot is not interested in good legislation; and this lot is not interested in justice, morality and getting this issue right. What those opposite are interested in is the most vulgar form of scaremongering, and they ought to be ashamed of themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is this backtracking and change in policy by the Prime Minister just another example of his duplicity which he showed in the budget when he brought in tax increases which were not spoken about in the lead-up to the last election? Is this another example of his duplicity?

—A further example of the scaremongering I am talking about—and I am grateful to the good senator for reminding me—is the statement by the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory this morning that the government's native title legislation will rob Australians of their right to a day at the beach, for God's sake! The proposals that were set out in the original outline, in respect of which there has been no suggestion from anyone that there be a change, show how the rights of the public can coexist absolutely with any native rights that might exist as far as the coastline is concerned. There is quite explicit provision for governments to confirm any existing public access, including to beaches. It has been made perfectly clear already that this would not involve any extinguishment of native title.

PARA.TAB: It is this sort of nonsense which has been peddled by people—I do not know whether they know any better, or whether they do know better but they are determined to be mischievous—which is perverting and destroying the course of rational debate on this issue in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a disgrace, Burnsie.
—You are the one who is a disgrace.

—It is not us, not the Prime Minister, who have anything to answer for or anything to apologise for in continuing a process of negotiation; it is the impossible attitude taken by the opposition which has put us in this position. (Time expired)
—Order! On two occasions during that answer I heard from both sides of the chamber the expression `you are a disgrace'. It is unparliamentary and I am not going to tolerate it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer the minister to the issues raised on the Hinch program concerning the provision of family day care to Chantelle Mustafa. Can the minister tell the Senate what action has been taken to provide Chantelle, who has Charge Association Syndrome, with family day care in her own home to enable her mother, Michelle, to return to work?

—I thank Senator Denman for her question. I am pleased to tell the Senate that I recently rang Mrs Mustafa to tell her that special arrangements had been made to provide Chantelle Mustafa, her nine-month-old baby girl, with family day care in her own home. The case was first brought to my attention by the department and then raised further on the Hinch program. That program highlighted the nature of Chantelle Mustafa's disability.

PARA.TAB: Mrs Mustafa sought access to family day care so that she could return to work next month. Because of her daughter's special needs, Mrs Mustafa has asked that family day care be provided in her own home rather than in the home of the family day care worker, which is the usual arrangement. The family day care guidelines do not allow for the provision of child care in the child's home. This means that such care would be ineligible for child care assistance or fee relief.

Mrs Mustafa argued to me, to the department and on the Hinch program that there are special circumstances which justify special care in the case of Chantelle. The Werribee council, the sponsor of family day care relevant to Mrs Mustafa, had indicated that it was willing to assist in providing family day care in Mrs Mustafa's home.

As Senator Denman said, Chantelle Mustafa has Charge Association Syndrome. Essentially the principal concern is that she cannot be fed through the mouth and has to be fed through a stomach tube. She is unable to clear her throat or swallow, which makes her very vulnerable to respiratory infections. The low resistance to colds and flu and the likelihood of serious infection mean that she would be very much at risk if she had to leave her home and go to family day care provided in somebody else's home.

Within the department and under existing arrangements, I have discretion to make one-off determinations in special cases. After examining all the avenues available, I decided that we could make an exception in this case on behalf of Chantelle and her family.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you fund it appropriately?

—Just wait a moment, Senator Newman; I am coming to that. Let me stress that this decision is not made because of Chantelle's disability. Many children in Australia with disabilities enjoy child care assistance under the ordinary provisions.

PARA.TAB: Our child care programs are designed to provide support for families and children with disabilities in the mainstream child care areas. That is assisted by the program's supplementary services to make sure that children with disabilities are eligible and able to be in mainstream services.

The decision should not be regarded as a precedent but as a one-off. I have set very special conditions to make sure that this is a one-off case, particularly so that Mrs Mustafa and her daughter are not penalised unfairly because her case falls between the stools. Mrs Mustafa will have assistance for child care to enable her to return to work and assist her family.

Some of the criteria are that a special contract should be drawn up outlining responsibility of all the parties concerned, insurance and the coverage of liability which, in these circumstances, is one of the most important areas. Secondly, we decided the decision should be reviewed after 12 months. If the little one has learnt to swallow or can manage differently, then she would be eligible to go to family day care in the ordinary circumstances. We have also allowed for her two-year-old child to be assisted with family day care at home for 12 months only. This is a very important decision that confirms this government's commitment to child care and its desire to meet the needs of families in a way that will assist them to return to work, to study or to train and not penalise them because of exceptional circumstances.

This is a special circumstance. I have made a one-off special arrangement for this particular case. I would hope that the Senate would be as pleased as Mrs Mustafa was to acknowledge the commitment of government in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I note that the Russians have admitted to dumping radioactive waste in the Sea of Japan. Can the minister give an unequivocal assurance that no waste generated from Australian supplied uranium has been dumped in the sea by the Russians? If he cannot give such an unequivocal guarantee, will he give an undertaking that no more Australian uranium will be supplied to Russia? What action has the minister taken to admonish the Russian government, in view of the fact that dumping of radioactive waste in the sea is against international conventions? What action, if any, is he taking through international fora to ensure that this dumping ceases?

—The premise of all those questions was that there had been radioactive waste dumping occurring and that that had been acknowledged by the Russians. As of coming in here this morning, I had not seen any report or concession to that effect. I will take the question on notice and give Senator Coulter a full reply as soon as I find out what the truth of that matter is. I know, of course, that Greenpeace has made those allegations—
—You have been watching television again.

—Of course I have been watching television—not quite as much as those opposite, who have nothing better to do. I have seen the reports, but it is a matter of getting confirmation of them. Certainly, if there has been some admission, I will find out about it shortly and give Senator Coulter a proper response.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In relation to the development of democracy in South Africa, and because of the continuing high level of violence and the fact that some of the major parties continue to boycott negotiations, what prospects does the minister see for achieving a peaceful transition to democracy in South Africa?

—Let me say at the outset how warmly the Australian government applauds—and I am sure I am speaking in this respect for all members of both houses—the awarding of the 1993 Nobel Peace Prize jointly to the ANC President, Nelson Mandela, and the South African President, Frederik de Klerk, for their roles in dismantling apartheid and moving South Africa toward democracy. Both men have made an immense personal and political commitment to the restructuring of a new non-racial democratic South Africa and, in making the award, the international community has very properly honoured that commitment.

PARA.TAB: The announcement of the Nobel Prize does come at a very difficult and sensitive time in South Africa. It should help give encouragement to those committed to negotiating a peaceful transition to democracy. Unhappily, that does not seem to extend to the full range of parties that have previously been involved in that process. The continuing boycott of the multi-party talks in South Africa by a coalition of right-wing parties, conservative black Bantustan governments and the Inkatha Freedom Party, led by Chief Buthelezi, does very seriously risk undermining the negotiations and delaying the transition to non-racial democracy.

The continuing high levels of violence that are simultaneously occurring with this are a matter of the gravest concern for all of us. That situation is not being made any better at all by the continuing stalemate in the negotiations. It is clearly imperative that agreement be reached as soon as possible on the proposed interim constitution. Once that happens, the transitional arrangements approved in September by the South African parliament can be put in place and preparations can begin for the election scheduled to take place in April next year. I repeat what I have said on a number of occasions: we urge all the parties to return to negotiations and to work together with a spirit of reconciliation to reach agreement on the proposed interim constitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans. I would have preferred to direct it to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Collins, who is acknowledged in this place as an expert on Aboriginals, but obviously he has been muzzled. I ask the minister: if native title and pastoral leases are to co-exist, can he guarantee that pastoral leases will be automatically renewed on expiry or will they be subject to native title claims? Will native title be able to extinguish pastoral leases? Considering the many hundreds of state statutes under which pastoral leases are guaranteed and granted, can the government guarantee that, if pastoral leases co-exist with native title, there will be no capacity for extensive litigation to test the relationship between native title and each of the hundreds of state statutes? Considering that native title can be challenged with government funding, will the government extend funding to the pastoralists to defend their property rights?

—I repeat, in case the point has been overlooked, that the validation exercise only bites and only takes effect to begin with in relation to those leasehold interests which are invalid. That could only conceivably be a tiny percentage of the number of leases that have been issued in this country, if any at all. In relation to those invalid leases which are validated by the proposed legislation, as has been spelt out already in the outline and will be made very clear in the text of the legislation, it is intended that that validation should extend to all existing rights of renewal. Of course, the right to renewal is an absolutely inherent part of pastoral leases as they have been awarded in this country. The expectation of continuity is part of the deal. That is understood.

PARA.TAB: Any proposal for a coexistence of native title rights, which has yet to be discussed by cabinet, could only be to the extent that coexistence is compatible with and consistent with the validated interest in question. The validated interest would be given its full force and effect. That has been made clear by the Prime Minister. It will be made as clear as is necessary in the event that there is some change in the position relating to pastoral leases as it was originally enunciated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Leader of the Government in the Senate did not answer the last part of my question, which was: will the government extend funding to pastoralists who have to defend their property rights in court actions? As the Aboriginal community will be given funding, will commensurate funding be given to the pastoralists?
—I do not know what is proposed in relation to the funding of anybody in this respect. It is premature to make any response on that particular question. I do not have a briefing on that.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to public concern with recent oil pollution incidents involving shipping and the poor condition of some foreign vessels transiting the Great Barrier Reef region. What action is being taken by the government to assess the impact of shipping activities on the reef and the potential risk to the ecological and tourist value of this region?

—The Great Barrier Reef is recognised internationally as a highly sensitive region and, in fact, is recognised by the International Maritime Organisation of the United Nations as such. The federal government has taken a number of recent initiatives to ensure the reef's protection from shipping activities and to minimise the risk from pollution. In building on these initiatives, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Mrs Kelly, and I have agreed to a comprehensive study being undertaken on the safety, environmental and economic issues associated with shipping activities in the Great Barrier Reef and Torres Strait region.

PARA.TAB: The study framework, which has been developed in close consultation with the Queensland Minister for Transport, Mr Hamill, will have three elements. First, the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics will evaluate shipping requirements in the reef area and the economic implications of using alternative shipping routes or alternative modes of transport. Second, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority will assess the risk and the possible impact of pollution arising from a shipping accident. This part of the study will be financially assisted by Caltex Oil Australia Pty Ltd. Third, the Department of Transport and Communications and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority will examine the legal and technical issues involved with strengthening control of shipping activities to enhance safety and protection of the marine environment.

A steering committee comprising officials from the federal and Queensland governments will manage this study. It will set detailed terms of reference, determine time frames, assess reports from each part of the study and provide recommendations to government for future action. There will be wide consultation with interested parties during this study. The steering committee will establish appropriate consultative mechanisms. Reports covering the individual elements of the study and the draft final report will be made available to interested parties for comment. The study is designed to provide a definitive picture of the potential impact of shipping on the Great Barrier Reef and Torres Strait region and to make recommendations to governments on possible measures to strengthen protection for its valuable ecological and tourist aspects.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer him to Glen Milne's article in today's Australian Financial Review concerning Mabo and the on-again, off-again suspension of the Racial Discrimination Act. I ask the minister: did the official submission to cabinet on Mabo in July indicate that the bill being prepared by the Commonwealth would facilitate `validation of existing grants by putting this beyond challenge on RDA grounds'? Regarding validation, the bill aims to give comprehensive certainty for past actions. Were those intentions confirmed by the Prime Minister in his August letter to all state premiers and in the Commonwealth's cabinet drafting instructions given to the states on 4 August? Do these documents indicate that, contrary to the line now being run by this government, it was in reality the government that proposed the suspension of part of the Racial Discrimination Act?

—It has always been the government's intention to make absolutely clear that, notwithstanding the provisions of any applicable law, leases and other interests in land that have been granted should be regarded as having certainty, continuity—should be in fact validated to the extent of any possible invalidity. That has been the government's position all the way through. That remains the position. That is the position as I have spelt it out this morning. The question that we had to wrestle with was the possible impact in extreme marginal cases—let us frankly acknowledge—of the Racial Discrimination Act as possibly interpreted and applied by the courts in rendering invalid for reasons of procedural unfairness, not taking into account what should have been taken into account, namely the existence of the title. We had to take into account the possibility that racial discrimination provisions looked at at their absolute face value might in some very small number of cases have the effect of invalidating. That remains a concern, and that concern has to be addressed.

PARA.TAB: What has changed is the government's perception of what is necessary in order to reach that result. Originally it was thought, on the available legal advice, that what we had to do was basically override the Racial Discrimination Act, or suspend the Racial Discrimination Act, or read down the Racial Discrimination Act to the extent of its possible application in these cases. Further, and I believe better, advice has since been received that we do not have to do any of those things because there is already in the Racial Discrimination Act, section 8, a particular affirmative action provision, a special measures provision, which is capable of being applied to the whole content of legislation of the kind that we are presently contemplating in the Mabo situation.

So, far from being something inconsistent with the basic thrust and purpose of the Racial Discrimination Act or any particular provision of it, what we are talking about now is making clear that this validation process will continue, will proceed, in exactly the way originally intended. But in the process, the Racial Discrimination Act does not have to be suspended or overridden or read down. The special measures provisions in the Racial Discrimination Act are capable on their face of applying to these situations because the whole point and thrust of the Mabo legislation is, of course, to introduce a very special measure for the protection of the Aboriginal people, certainly to balance it out against the rights of other Australians. But overwhelmingly, the character, the thrust, the shape, the content, the motivation of this legislation is to get it right for the first time in our history so far as Aboriginal people are concerned. That remains our intention and that will be the effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. In view of the assurances given previously by the Prime Minister and a number of his senior cabinet ministers, is this not just another sell-out of ordinary Australians?

—If senators repeat these sorts of feeble supplementaries that they have written out without having any regard to the responses they are given, then they cannot be taken very seriously. I am sorry that I have to say that about Senator Parer because he is someone whom I normally take a little more seriously than he is entitled to be taken with that fatuous supplementary question.

PARA.TAB: The point is that the original assurance given by the Prime Minister, which remains firmly on foot, is that the validation would continue, would have full force and effect. What has changed is the means by which that has been achieved or is likely to be achieved. What has not changed is the end; the end remains exactly the same. With further and better legal advice the means have changed. If Senator Parer cannot tell that particular difference, I am sorry to say that he does not deserve the trust and intellectual affection that I previously had for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of the President of the National Council of Switzerland—its parliament—Mr Paul Schmidhalter. On behalf of all honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate. I trust that your visit to Australia is both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I propose to invite Mr Schmidhalter to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!
Mr Schmidhalter was thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel aware that one of the winners of the Robin Boyd award for residential projects was housing provided by the Defence Housing Authority? Does this mean that after many years of substandard housing for Defence Force families, they are now being provided with housing of award winning standard? Will this high standard be applied to all defence housing in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the joint Robin Boyd award for housing in Darwin commissioned by the Defence Housing Authority. The authority is justifiably proud of the recognition for the high quality of its architectural design.

PARA.TAB: It is indeed the case that since this government established the Defence Housing Authority in 1988 defence families have been receiving a new and better deal in housing. The authority has been actively encouraging talented architects to design housing that is imaginative, attractive and cost effective and provides the amenities needed by mobile defence families. Troppo Architects were retained by the authority—
Honourable senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —I knew that would get a laugh from the opposition. I originally thought, of course, that they were the designers of the Fightback package.
—That did not even get a laugh from your side.
—We had a laugh on March 13, thanks, Richard.
—We just laugh at those opposite. These architects were retained by the authority to design new housing for construction at Larrakeyah barracks in Darwin.

PARA.TAB: One of the design factors that the authority took into account was that the location of the site, overlooking the ocean, makes the on-base housing very popular with defence families and medium density housing uses the land to good advantage while meeting the needs of defence families.

There are 21 houses in the group that attracted equal first in the Robin Boyd award. I recently inspected those dwellings. I would like to add my personal congratulations on the innovative use of the special features of the site and a building design that is very well suited indeed to the Northern Territory climate. I should add that the quality design of the Larrakeyah housing is no flash in the pan; standards are rising all around Australia.

The authority has retained the same firm of architects for other projects such as new housing at the naval base HMAS Coonawarra, another project involving 25 houses at various locations in Darwin; some courtyard houses at Fairview Ridge, Palmerston, which are being built under a joint venture with Territory Construction Association, as well as for design work on renovation to houses on RAAF base Darwin.

I think anyone familiar with the work of the Defence Housing Authority would agree that it has done an outstanding job in changing the face of defence housing in a period of less than six years. I think the vast majority of defence families are now receiving the quality of housing that was always their due, something which, of course, the opposition was never prepared to face up to when it was in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Notwithstanding his answer, could the minister report whether there is any input from service wives—
—Spouses.
—Is there any input from service spouses with regard to the design and the suitability of housing for their families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —Feedback is not only sought but also taken into account by the Defence Housing Authority.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel and it relates to the downgrading of the allowance paid to the ADF in Cambodia from $65 a day tax free to $40 taxable. I ask: who made the decision? Was it the minister, was it the secretary of the department or was it the CDF? Secondly, how and when was the initial announcement made, as opposed to how the FCU was informed? Thirdly, in so far as the allowance was paid because of the danger of the posting, what are the reasons advanced now for the variation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
