TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 October 1991, the government agreed to conditions of service applicable for all ADF personnel to be deployed to Cambodia. At that time, because of the uncertainty of what that would involve in Cambodia, two packages of conditions of service were put in place. The lesser package was to be implemented after the UN cease-fire took effect and when demobilisation and containment measures were, in fact, in place. As events unfolded and elections were held without the UN cease-fire provisions being achieved, it became apparent that the initial rationale to change the conditions of service would also have to change.

PARA.TAB: The date of the Cambodian elections was initially chosen, but there were a number of serious incidents which endangered our personnel around that particular time. The change to the lesser package was delayed to ensure that ADF personnel received the appropriate entitlements in terms of compensation and repatriation cover as well as financial recompense. With the cessation of the UN mandate and the installation of the new Cambodian government, the need for a review became evident. The review indicated that the most appropriate time for change was after the departure of the main body.

All personnel deployed to Cambodia were advised prior to deployment that the conditions of service package would change when the situation in Cambodia stabilised. The administration of the change in service conditions and the timing of the advice given to members were not as well managed as I would wish or as the government would have wished. Personnel in Cambodia were advised of the changes on 28 September 1993 and were advised that the changes were to take effect on 8 October this year. Because of the administrative time involved in changing pay arrangements and the fact that some personnel in Cambodia had been paid in advance, some overpayments did occur and I certainly have directed the ADF to examine ways to ameliorate the effects of the necessary repayments on ADF members and their families.

I acknowledge that a degree of hazard still exists for ADF members deployed in Cambodia. This recognition is demonstrated by the payment of a $40 daily deployment allowance, in addition to continued coverage under the Veterans' Entitlement Act, extra recreation leave, and zone rebates under the taxation act. The revised conditions of service package is considered fair and reasonable. But, of course, should circumstances change substantially in Cambodia, the conditions of service would also change.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I quite sincerely commend the minister on his honesty in admitting that the whole thing was bungled. It is not often that we hear an admission of fault from people on the other side. My supplementary question is: why did the minister not comply with the law? When the legislation relating to the deployment of the force to Cambodia went through this chamber in June of last year, the Senate passed an amendment requiring notification of the parliament of any proposed variation to the package of allowances and, in so far as it is a disallowable instrument, seeking the approval of the parliament to any variation to those allowances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I am aware, the UNTAC deployment was a pre-existing one. That means that the matters raised by Senator MacGibbon do not apply. As well, pre-existing conditions of service for ADF personnel serving overseas did not apply—new conditions of service, of course, having been announced by me in the parliament earlier.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I ask: in framing those aspects of its industrial relations legislation which are intended to comply with ILO conventions, does the government interpret convention No. 156 dealing with workers with family responsibilities to include the right to take unpaid leave to care for elderly parents? Is the government's interpretation broad enough to include the other voluntary caring responsibilities which still fall primarily to women and which cause stress and career interruption to many working women?

—The final form of the legislation has not been determined. As with some other matters which have been referred to today, it still has to go to cabinet. It is a very significant, but not simple issue which Senator Kernot raises. My understanding is that it is probable that the legislation will not be specific on the matter that Senator Kernot raises; the legislation depends upon ILO convention No. 156 and its related recommendation No. 165.

PARA.TAB: The convention makes specific reference to parental leave to care for a child or other family member who is ill. It therefore provides authority for legislation which would allow a worker to take leave to care for an aged member of his or her immediate family while they are ill. There is no specific reference to such leave where the person is not specifically suffering from an illness, but is just an aged parent requiring constant attention. There seems to be significant doubt that the convention would provide authority for legislation that went all the way to cover unpaid leave to care for elderly parents.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has to get through the parliament.
—It is likely, but it will only occur if legislation does, Senator.
—But it provides the head of power.
—It is law passed by the parliament of Australia or not. If it is passed—
—It is the head of power which intrudes into other states' activities.
—I realise that it horrifies Senator Kemp that the Senate may pass a bit of legislation that actually helps workers in Australia, and I am very sorry about that.
—Order! Senator Kernot asked the question.
—I think she enjoyed the answer to Senator Kemp's interjection as well—and she should have; it was good.

PARA.TAB: The situation is that the legislation will go particularly to convention No. 156, as it should. I expect the parliament to support it because it is good legislation in the interests of the people of Australia. But it will place an obligation on the Industrial Relations Commission to have regard to the requirements of the legislation. Depending upon the final form of the legislation, it may well provide an avenue for people to pursue with the Industrial Relations Commission the sorts of issues that Senator Kernot raises. The legislation itself is unlikely to specifically provide those avenues, the nature of the convention on which it is based.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. In the superannuation debate we recognised the demographics of an ageing population. If it cannot be done in this industrial relations package and if there are limited funds available for the sorts of community care programs that might be helpful, how can the government recognise that one of those very important responsibilities of women is now to look after elderly parents as well?

—There has been an important change in social priorities, demands and pressures because of the changing demographics. If I were to take the question literally, wearing my hat as the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, I would say there is not a lot that the government can do in that capacity. Ranging more broadly, it seems to me that the government cannot solve that problem absolutely, but the development of home and community care packages and a variety of measures that are being undertaken provide the opportunity for workers with family responsibilities, broadly described, to participate in the work force.

PARA.TAB: It may well be that the provisions of government support measures; the enterprise bargaining provisions which enable greater flexibility of workplace arrangements; and the provisions of this legislation and the powers which it gives the Industrial Relations Commission, create a framework in which more contemporary recognition of those matters is open. Of course, if the constitution does not allow the Commonwealth to act, it is specifically open to the states to act.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I remind the Minister that there are 27 Public Service paydays in the 1993-94 financial year and that Child Support Agency deductions are based on there being 26 Public Service paydays in a financial year. What steps has the government taken to avoid overpayment by non-custodial parents who have child support payments deducted from their Public Service salaries?
—I do not have a brief on that matter. I will seek an answer for Senator Reid.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I am aware of a number of media reports over the past few days following an announcement of the membership of a National Transport Planning Task Force. What is the role and value of the task force in the government's transport reform agenda?
—Those people who take a close interest in transport policy issues would be aware that the formation of a National Transport Planning Task Force—
—Why are they muzzling you on the Mabo legislation?

—It has absolutely nothing to do with the Mabo legislation—one of the few things that does not. The formation of a task force was a specific promise made by the government in the federal election campaign.
—You are the only one who knows anything about it.
—Order! Senator Collins.

—I was just pausing for the commercial, Mr President. The task force is a key element of the government's fifth term transport reform agenda. The federal Labor government has initiated substantial reform of transport systems on land, sea and air over the last decade. The reform program has led to significant efficiency gains in each transport sector. The task force will build on this foundation. It will tap further into the needs of users and plan the way ahead for a truly integrated national transport system.

PARA.TAB: The primary focus of the task force will be on the interstate movement of freight. It will assess the future pattern of transport demands and plan the infrastructure investment to meet those demands, including alternative sources, and it will focus on the broader economic costs and benefits of increased transport infrastructure investment. The task force will also look at all aspects of the relationship between the various transport sectors. A particular focus will be the efficiency and cost effectiveness of the interface between land transport and sea and air transport infrastructure.
Senator Bishop interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't worry about me, Bron—you concentrate on John Hewson. By the way, what are you going to do when he is not so high in the polls? Does your position change then? A particular focus will be on the efficiency of that interface between land transport and sea and air transport infrastructure. It will also have regard for the social and environmental impact of the transport system and the maintenance and enhancement of safety standards.

PARA.TAB: Given the task at hand, I am particularly pleased to inform the Senate of the appointment of three part-time members of the task force. They are: Mr Ian Webber, Chairman of Mayne Nickless; Mr Lance Hockridge, Group General Manager, BHP Transport; and Dr Derek Scrafton, Director-General of Transport in South Australia. All these people have a long involvement in the transport industry and public policy issues affecting transport. They will bring to their task strong practical experience and a keen appreciation of the importance of this sector to Australia's economic growth and prosperity. The task force will report to the government by March 1995 after consultation with a wide range of affected parties. In conclusion, I am encouraged by the positive response to the task force which has come from my state and federal counterparts, the federal opposition and, most importantly, the transport sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the long running saga of the injustice concerning the Midford Paramount matter where the Joint Committee on Public Accounts made a unanimous and bipartisan recommendation that compensation be paid. Will the minister explain to the Senate why the interdepartmental committee established by the Prime Minister to set the level has failed to meet its September deadline to report? Is the minister aware that one of the parties was recently admitted to hospital as a consequence of the delay; that another has been in and out of hospital for months and was readmitted this morning; and that a third was forced last week to close down his business? Does there have to be bankruptcy and/or death before the minister and his government will act on this matter and compensation is paid after 10 months of waiting?

—The IDC in question is expected to complete its report on this matter this week, I am advised by the Prime Minister's department. It is expected that cabinet will be in a position to consider a joint submission from the Attorney-General and the Minister for Finance soon after the Prime Minister returns from CHOGM. It has been quite a complex exercise to assess the comprehensive and detailed claims that were received in this matter. The IDC was assisted on technical issues relating to valuation and income stream by consultants. The tax office, senior officers of the Customs Service, the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development, neither of which had prior involvement with matters relating to the prosecution or the subsequent JCPA inquiry, are also providing assistance. It ought to be appreciated under those circumstances that it was not possible to bring this to too speedy a conclusion, but every effort has been made to do just that. I remind Senator Bishop that she will not have nearly as much opportunity for fun like this when she gets into the House of Representatives; nonetheless, there it is.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. This is a serious matter and I would ask the minister not to be flippant about it. I would ask him to tell us whether or not he will give us an undertaking to report to this chamber by the end of this week. I simply do not accept that the fault lies anywhere else but with the consultants and the bureaucracy who have retried the matter; and you have failed to intervene and bring justice in less than 10 months—I mean you collectively, the government.

—Prejudging matters has always been part of Senator Bishop's repertoire. I am glad to see she is not changing her spots in this respect. I give no such undertaking other than the one I just did give: the cabinet will consider this matter as soon as possible, as soon as the joint submission has been received from the Attorney-General and the Minister for Finance; as soon as the PM gets back from CHOGM, we will be looking at it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I am sure the minister is aware of the decision by Qantas to introduce direct flights between the Northern Territory and Japan next year. What implications does this decision have for the Territory's tourist industry?

—I do appreciate the continuing interest that Senator Beahan has in the welfare of the Northern Territory, particularly my home town of Darwin. I am pleased to advise the Senate that Qantas has announced a non-stop Tokyo-Darwin service to commence in March 1994, giving the Northern Territory direct access, for the first time, to the Japanese tourist trade. The introduction of a weekly Boeing 767-300 flight will make Darwin Qantas's second northern gateway from Japan following the highly successful introduction of direct services from Japan to Cairns. The Japanese market will have easy access not only to Darwin, but to Kakadu, Alice Springs and Ayers Rock—Uluru—three of Australia's major tourist destinations, following this decision.

PARA.TAB: As Japan now provides more international tourists to Australia than any other country, this is an important announcement for the Northern Territory's tourism and hospitality industries. It will also provide the opportunity to expand existing Japanese markets by attracting those who are looking to new adventure holiday experiences in Australia's outback, as opposed to some of the more conventional coastal destinations.

The decision will also build on encouraging signs already being shown in the growth of international passenger numbers through Darwin last year. These results showed an increase of almost 10 per cent to over 96,000 international visitors going through Darwin airport for the year ended 30 June 1993.

This announcement is a further demonstration of the Commonwealth's strong aviation links with Japan which were further enhanced by the successful outcome of negotiations last year which provided for a 40 per cent increase in capacity between the two countries over the next two years. It is also a further sign of the development of international air services to Darwin, which has most recently seen the introduction of Ansett's international services to Indonesia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the minister to his claim today that pastoral leases will be subject to a Mabo claim only if they are invalid. Does the minister accept that, if the Queensland Wik claim succeeds on the basis that there was a breach of fiduciary duty, there is not a pastoral lease in the country which would be safe from a Mabo claim? Accordingly, will the government do as it is asked by the Queensland government and legislate to protect against the Wik or any similar land grab claim?

—The point about the proposed legislation, as was spelt out in the original outline—nothing is intended to be changed in this respect—is that it is not just a lease rendered invalid by the operation of the Racial Discrimination Act that needs attention by way of validation; it is a lease that is rendered invalid by the operation of the combination of native title with any other law. Of course, what we have in mind is the possibility of the law of fiduciary duty having some force and application in these circumstances, and it is that that has to be addressed if there is to be proper certainty. It is in that context that the outline was previously circulated and it is in that context that it will be circulated again, making clear that the validation exercise that is occurring is in relation to interests in land that are rendered invalid for any reason whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: But the point that I tried to spell out before holds: it is inconceivable that there could be any wide-ranging exposure even to question marks so far as the overwhelming majority of leasehold interests are concerned. Not only does one have to establish the threshold question of whether there is native title at all in relation to the land in question—which is a completely separate issue and which obviously limits the issue in a very extensive way—but there also has to be some element of breach of procedural justice or breach of actual duty. It would be pretty hard to establish a breach of procedural justice or a breach of duty in a circumstance where, until 1992, nobody could have had any knowledge of the possible existence of native title. The view of many lawyers—and I am one of them—is that the whole exercise of possible invalidity of leases or interests in land by virtue of the application of the RDA or fiduciary duty law or anything else is really a bit of a will-o'-the-wisp because it is almost inconceivable, except in an extremely theoretical situation, and maybe not even then, that any land interest would be rendered invalid in this respect.

So before everyone gets too excited about this issue I ask honourable senators to please understand and accept that they are only talking about something on the extreme margins of possible relevance when talking about these issues at all. It is not something that could have any conceivable application to the overwhelming number of interests in land that have been issued in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—Under procedural order 15, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs why my question No. 47, dated 4 May 1993, has yet to be answered.

—I have ascertained that that question relates to—I hope this is correct—an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission issue. I thank Senator Campbell for advising me half an hour ago that this question was still outstanding. I have pursued the matter. I am advised that within 24 hours ATSIC will provide to me an answer, which I will provide to Senator Campbell.

—My next question, under the same procedural order, is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I ask for an explanation as to why my question dated 16 July 1993—specifically question No. 416—has yet to receive an answer.

—I suppose the best answer is that some ministers in the House of Representatives do not quite understand the procedures of the Senate and the need for speed. My office contacted Mr Baldwin's office during question time. He has promised to provide an answer for tomorrow. For my part, I apologise for not following it through.
—It is your responsibility.

—If Senator Crane was listening—he ought to do much more of it—rather than talking, he would have heard me apologising. I seek to have these questions—those directed to ministers in the House of Representatives as well as those directed to me—monitored by my office. I apologise for the fact that, on this occasion, that does not appear to have happened.

—My last question, under the same procedural order, is directed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. It relates to a question I put on notice on 4 August—specifically, question No. 479. I seek an explanation as to why it has not been answered.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my colleagues, I thank Senator Campbell for his courtesy in giving me some notice of this matter. I thought the answer had been provided. We have been chasing it up. It is available and will be supplied during the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Prime Minister in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop this day, relating to the Midford Paramount case.

SPEECH.PARA: The directors of the Midford Paramount company and the people associated with those directors in that business venture have been subject to the most outrageous and heinous injustice by the operations of a government agency and the bureaucracies that comprise it.

PARA.TAB: It took two years for the Joint Committee of Public Accounts to conduct the inquiry, going through thousands of pages of evidence. It came down with a unanimous report, which stated that compensation should be paid. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) established an interdepartmental committee and said that under no circumstances was it to retry the issues; it was simply to determine how much was to be paid.

The committee became aware that there was resistance in the bureaucracy—the Department of Finance and the Australian Customs Service—to the setting of a precedent by the payment of compensation to give some justice to these people. Their behaviour has been reprehensible. The pressure that has been put on these individuals is far beyond anything that they should reasonably have been asked to endure. One person is a shadow of his former self. He has been in and out of hospital. He was re-admitted this morning, and his wife will not be far behind him. Another director was put into hospital some weeks ago when I raised this matter and asked that it be expedited.

The committee has taken action, yet 10 months after the report came down these people are still being made to suffer. I said weeks ago that one of the people concerned would have to close his business because the compensation issue was not resolved. He has now done that. He is only being maintained by help from his local church and, quite frankly, his health is only being maintained by prayer.

How long this can go on I do not know. Senator Gareth Evans saying today that this is all the fault of taking proper evidence to get a result—when an investigation of this case shows that there is ample evidence of the bureaucracy seeking to retry the matter and of toing-and-froing between it and the consultants, which was not warranted—simply will not do.

The reason I am raising this point now is that if the minister can see his way clear to say that he will report to this parliament at the end of this week and that compensation will be announced by the beginning of next week, then perhaps we might save a life. It is that serious. I do not think it is reasonable for the government and the bureaucracy to think that their problems can be solved by either death and/or bankruptcy. They will have to wear that on their conscience if that is what transpires. I again ask the minister to reconsider his position and say that he will do everything in his power to make the announcement of that compensation this week so that the people who have been hospitalised and the people who are facing ruin can perhaps take some reassurance that justice in this matter will come about by at least next week.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Ellison this day, relating to Mabo legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of my question to Senator Gareth Evans was to highlight the change in the government's stance in relation to the coexistence of native title with pastoral leases. I referred to a document entitled Mabo—Outline of proposed legislation on native title. That document stated that native title would not exist where there was a leasehold situation.

PARA.TAB: Today in question time the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) clearly indicated that the government did not intend to extinguish native title rights on pastoral leases despite its earlier indications that only mining leases would coexist with native title. I bring to the attention of the Senate the fact that this vindicates the reason for my question and also vindicates the press reports of late which show that the Prime Minister has reneged on his prior stand. Senator Evans's attempts to downplay the change in stance by the Prime Minister were completely erroneous.

Senator Evans sought to dismiss the concerns mentioned in the press by Mr Perron in relation to access to public waterways and, in particular, beaches. Question 20 in the booklet handed out by the Prime Minister's department in September this year entitled Mabo—Questions and answers, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Will the public be denied access to parks and beaches found to be on native title land?
The answer stated:

The Bill will allow governments to confirm existing public rights of access to and the enjoyment of beaches, parks, waterways and recreational areas. This confirmation will not extinguish native title. Any new public rights of access to native title land will only be granted in the same way as rights would be granted to other private land.

That clearly indicates a problem with the rights to access by the public to such areas as beaches. Mr Perron was quite right in raising those concerns. Senator Evans was quite wrong to try to shrug off the concerns of Mr Perron in the way he did.

PARA.TAB: When one refers to the government document, one is not given any reassurance, one is not given any answer to the situation, and any man or woman off the street reading that document would still wonder where their rights lay with respect to public waterways and beaches. This is a matter the government has not cleared up. Mr Perron is quite right when he says:
"The Prime Minister will need to explain to Australians why he is unwilling to guarantee the continuation of our most treasured national pastime—a day at the beach . . .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to make some comments about Senator Gareth Evans's answer to the question asked today by my colleague Senator Ellison. I believe that what Senator Evans has said conflicts with what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said earlier today in the House of Representatives. It was probably about the same time as Senator Evans was speaking in this chamber. It conflicts with the position in the paper produced in September 1993 entitled Mabo—Questions and answers, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: What impact will the Bill have on pastoral properties?

Any pastoral interests which are invalid because of the existence of native title will be validated. The validation of pastoral leases without any reservation for the benefit of Aboriginal people will extinguish native title.
It says that absolutely, totally, clearly, without any doubt whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is still right.
—No, it is not still right. In his answer today, Senator Evans said that the impact of this would be minuscule. That it is contradicted absolutely by the Prime Minister, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: Native title claimants could make claims under common law on all of the thousands of pastoral leases issued before 1975 using a part of the High Court's judgment.

The Prime Minister said that today. I will address the situation in Western Australia for a moment. Pastoral leases account for some 38 per cent of the total area of Western Australia. If that is added to the almost 50 per cent that is crown land, there is not too much of Western Australia left.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, Senator Evans does not understand the situation under which pastoral leases are granted and renewed. It is very simple. A pastoral lease is not automatically renewed at the end of the lease. In some instances, they are closed up for a period and then they are renewed.

The answer given by Senator Evans in the Senate today is absolutely and totally misleading with respect to the position which will exist. This adds to the uncertainty that exists around the Mabo decision and the impact that it will have on jobs, investment and a whole range of activities, particularly in Western Australia. Western Australia is somewhat different from most of Australia in terms of its land title structure, although there are similarities, particularly with South Australia and the Northern Territory.

The point I make relates to the backflip which has obviously been made by the Prime Minister. That is best summed up by comments from Mr Farley of the National Farmers Federation in an article in the Australian today. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: He said yesterday that Mr Keating's 11th-hour change of heart meant "there is no point in any group talking or negotiating with the Government on any issue . . . they simply cannot be trusted".
The article then goes on:
Mr Farley said if public assurances from Mr Keating and six ministers "can't be believed then I don't think there is any way you can trust the Government".

The position of pastoralists is quite clear to me. Because of the expectations built up by the Prime Minister and because of the way he has handled this matter, we are going to see millions and millions of dollars being spent on court decisions and processes. As I said, that has been highlighted by today's comment of the Prime Minister that all leases entered into pre-1975 will be subject to common law. That will have a very detrimental impact on the economy of Australia, particularly that of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: I have not raised in my comments—obviously it is not an issue here—the impact that this will have on the mining industry. If we look at the way the mining industry is handled in Western Australia, the co-existence of two, three or even more titles for that matter would not work; it could not work. I support the comments of my colleague Senator Ellison. I think it is a tragedy that this country has been allowed to slide to where it has.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the motion to take note of the very thorough and well-informed answer that Senator Gareth Evans gave us in question time. There are just a couple of points that I wish to make, because obviously there will be a much more comprehensive debate of this issue.

PARA.TAB: The first point is that it was draft legislation that was released. Those who are talking about a backflip should be aware that that detail was released for comment, for discussion, for consultation and for negotiation.

TALK.START.PARA: —By whom?

—By the government, and that is what has happened. The second point is that native title is totally different from any other form of title that Australians have ever had to deal with. That is why we get these extreme claims that native title cannot coexist with pastoral leases. It does coexist and it has coexisted since the middle of the 19th century. It was not called native title, but the British recognised the rights of indigenous people all those years ago. In 1993 we still have members of the opposition who do not even know that, with the reservations in Western Australia, South Australia and the Northern Territory, native title is coexisting.

PARA.TAB: The third point is that essentially this issue is about industry groups learning to talk to indigenous people. Some industry groups find this very threatening.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be so patronising. They have been doing it for 50 years, you fool.
—Order! Senator Tambling, you will withdraw that comment.
—I withdraw.

—Similarly, on 12 October in the Kimberley region—and Western Australian senators should be aware of this—the Kimberley pastoralists sat down and initiated an historic agreement with the people of the Kimberley. That is the sort of positive, negotiated agreement that we will see as a result of the High Court's decision and as a result of this government's very effective and consistent approach in responding to a High Court decision. Every time those opposite criticise, they criticising not only the High Court but also international native title law practice which, frankly, none of them understands.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on the motion to take note of an answer moved by Senator Ellison with regard to a matter I raised earlier. The pastoralists and graziers of Australia were promised unconditionally that their pastoral leases would not be extinguished by native title. Today we have seen a reversal of that by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Senator Gareth Evans has decided that it is not even worth worrying about—it is so minuscule that it will not worry the parliament. I do not think Senator Evans really understands what is under pastoral lease. For instance, 70 per cent of Queensland is under pastoral lease. There are 3,139 pastoral leases in Queensland alone.
—How many of those areas are subject to a native title claim?

—That is exactly what we would like to know. No-one knows what claims will be validated. If native title will now coexist with a pastoral lease, what will happen at the end of the pastoral lease? Will the native title be snuffed out? That is the problem that no-one is answering and it will only be solved by a massive number of claims.

PARA.TAB: I directed a question to Senator Evans, which he sidestepped, asking him to put on record whether the pastoralists of this country will receive government money to defend their property rights, as the Aboriginal community will be given money.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are the rights of the children in the gallery?
—I acknowledge their rights. Those people seem to come from the Torres Strait Islands and I welcome them to Canberra. They should be able to listen to this debate.

PARA.TAB: We are trying to establish here today whether the coexistence of pastoral leases and native titles will run, and whether at the end of the pastoral leases the leases will be extinguished. No-one has been able to assure the grazing industry that that will not happen. Many pastoral leases in Queensland have been given out under different statutes: the home lease, the perpetual lease, the grazing lease, and the miner's homestead. They go on and on, right across Australia. Will those leases have to be fought out one by one in a last ditch stand?

There are so many of these questions that Senator Evans cannot answer. I would like him to try to answer them. There are all these different types of leases. Does that mean that there has to be a court action for a perpetual lease, a court action for a homestead lease, a court action for a mining lease? There are hundreds of different types of leases. These are the sorts of things that the National Farmers Federation and the graziers want answers to. The government gave them the assurance that their leaseholds, their livelihoods, their property investments were going to be guaranteed. For the past five or six weeks—maybe two or three months—the government has been retracting on that, leaving the pastoral industry that does not have freehold title—which is probably about 70 or 80 per cent of it, certainly in Queensland—in a state of uncertainty. The government has put these pastoral leases at risk. There is great uncertainty out there. No-one knows what to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially the banks.

—The banks are worried about it. The people are worried about it. The banks certainly are not going to lend any more money to be spent on pastoral leases. The government has created absolute terror out there. People's livelihoods are at risk. They understand that. Some of these people have been on these properties for four and five generations. They are worried that their investment, their families' investment and the blood, sweat and tears that their predecessors have put into the properties will be at risk. I would like the minister to give us some answers and not just brush us off. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Senator Faulkner) in response to a question asked by me today relating to the payment of an allowance to the ADF in Cambodia.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a different view to Senator Faulkner in relation to the danger that is involved in Cambodia. It is certainly at variance to the government's view in relation to the mine clearance forces we had in Namibia, where after the cease-fire the government continued to pay the allowances because of the danger involved.

PARA.TAB: I have been to Cambodia twice in the last 12 months. I do not pretend to be an authority on it, but I think that the situation in Cambodia for the ADF is probably as dangerous today as it was 12 months ago. Certainly, the danger is less from the Khmer Rouge, but banditry is now getting very much out of hand. Something like 180 vehicles have been stolen from the United Nations forces in the last few weeks. Daylight robbery at gunpoint is not an infrequent occurrence in the capital, Phnom Penh. I talked to one soldier who had had a bullet fired between his legs when he was being robbed.

In the newspapers today, it was reported that three bridges were blown up in Battambang. It probably was not done by the DK; it was probably done by the bandits. I noticed that one of the bridges had just had a hole blown in it. One of the techniques there is to blow up one lane of the bridge so the bandits can collect a toll illegally on the traffic through there.

There is a good case to be made that the danger there is probably as much as it ever was. However, that is a decision for the government to make. My concern is the process by which the government withdrew the allowance.

Mr Bilney when dealing with this legislation spoke of the allowance being reduced from $65 to $60. In fact, it has come down to $40. When the legislation was before the Senate we were operating under a guillotine, thanks to those great custodians of democracy and free speech, the Australian Democrats, so the time for debate was limited. But if one goes back and reads the Hansard, one finds that Senator Watson referred to the ADF in Cambodia and the allowances in relation to the amendment that went through to the income tax act. Later Senator Newman passed an amendment through the Senate which was quite specific and related to the allowances being paid to the ADF. It did require that they be tabled before the Senate and in the form of a disallowable instrument and thereby the Senate would have the opportunity of approving or disapproving those allowances.

According to the answer from the minister today, that did not apply because the force was already in Cambodia when the legislation went through. I am at a loss to understand that because my reading of the debate, as recorded in Hansard, is that it was quite specific in relation to the amendment that was going through to the Income Tax Assessment Act; it did relate to Cambodia. Therefore, I believe the government is bound to notify the parliament of the change in those allowances. It clearly has not done that. Alternatively, if the government has followed another pathway it is also bound, under the spirit of the legislation, to advise the Senate and the parliament how it arrived at that decision. That has not been done.

I agree with Senator Faulkner that the whole thing was handled appallingly. I was in Cambodia at the time, in Phnom Penh, before the main contingent left several weeks ago. The effect on morale was really quite considerable. People were very disappointed at the way the government has handled this. Well they might be because what has happened now is that the troops in the rearguard of the Australian Defence Force in Cambodia—about 110 or 120 troops; most of them would be privates and in the lower ranks—have been denied a benefit that they understood they would get.

What is the saving for the government? Probably an increased payment of $25 or $35 a week, at most, for four or five weeks for 120 people—amounting to $20,000 in rough terms. This was a commitment that Australia performed extremely well in Cambodia. I have no hesitation in saying that without the Australian contingent and General Sanderson as head of the headquarters, the Cambodian UN operation would not have come to the successful operation that it did, but it probably cost Australia $30 million or $40 million. Why quibble over $20,000-odd and upset the ADF, which has done a marvellous job up there? It is just stupid.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:
1.discriminates against low income families and those living in rural areas
2.increases business costs and will cause further unemployment
3.adds further to the price of an already heavily taxed product
4.breaks Mr Keating's election promise not to put up tax.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate oppose these increases in petrol excise.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Calvert (from 118 citizens), Senator Kemp (from 611 citizens), Senator Minchin (from 79 citizens) and Senator Tierney (from 815 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Wine Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned call on the Senate to oppose the Labor government's inequitable wine tax.
We believe that any increase in tax on wine will cause harm to an important industry which promotes Australian jobs and is an important export for our country.
We oppose outright any increase in wholesale sales tax on wine and reject any moves to defer the introduction of this tax, as deferral is simply deferred support of the proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wine Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:

PARA.TAB: The 1993 Federal Budget announcement by the Keating Labor Government to increase wholesale sales tax on wine by more than 50%, from 20% to 31%,

PETITION.PARA: discriminates against the wine industry compared with other beverages;
discriminates against South Australia, which produces 70% of Australia's wine;
threatens the continuing existence of 150 smaller wineries and 500 related jobs;
destroys the capacity for a further $500 million, job-creating investment in the wine industry;
will result in lower grape prices for grapegrowers already burdened by the rural recession;
will severely damage the domestic market base for Australian wine which is so essential to its continuing export growth;

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject the increase in wholesale sales tax on wine.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:
1. The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
2. The implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
3. We regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Herron (from 41 citizens) and Senator Knowles (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned strongly oppose attempts by the Government to increase the level of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) and to decrease the threshold at which graduates begin to repay their HECS debt.

Wherefore, your petitioners, request that any further changes to the Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) be referred to a committee that will assess the impact of fees and loans on higher education.

PETITION.TITLE: Tax: Holiday and Long Service Leave
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to retrospectively subject accrued holiday and long service leave to the full rate of taxation be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of taxing accrued holiday and long service leave as unfair and inequitable.

2.The implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect upon millions of taxpayers who have foregone their long service and holiday leave entitlements in order to accumulate a nest egg for retirement.
3.We regard the Government's intention to apply such measures retrospectively as being an undemocratic use of the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: VIP Aircraft
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate our strongest opposition to the Prime Minister's intentions of purchasing new VIP aircraft, particularly given that the Prime Minister is responsible for the record unemployment and worst recession in sixty years, and calls on the Prime Minister to abandon his plans to purchase any new aircraft until Australia's economy picks up and unemployment falls dramatically.
Further, that the Senate recognises the Prime Minister's previous misuse of such aircraft, in particular, his using one to fly from Canberra to Melbourne and back to watch a football game.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the Senate to oppose any plan by the Prime Minister to purchase any new VIP aircraft.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Vietnamese Buddhist Congregation
PETITION.PARA: To Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Federal Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that

(1) One of the most critical issues to the Vietnamese people today is the persecution of their freedom of religion and expression, which has been carried out by the Government of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam (GOSRV) since 1945. World media reports have shown consistently that this persecution has increased greatly since 1992, when Buddhists, despite violent repression by the GOSRV's armed forces, started asking for `real' freedom of religion.

(2) The continuation of the GOSRV's centralised and corrupt structure, as well its failed and disorderly `economic renovation' and its declared loyalty to the atheistic socialism, has seriously degraded the moral, cultural, family, economic and spiritual life of most Vietnamese people.

(3) The GOSRV's policy of oppressing religions has, since 1945, applied equally to Catholics, Protestants, Caodaists, Hoa Hao Buddhist members and, most seriously, to the Unified Vietnamese Buddhist Church (UBCV) which represents the faith and spiritual life of 80% of 72 million Vietnamese.

(4) As the rightful heir of the 2000-year old Buddhist tradition in Vietnam, the UBCV was formally formed in 1951 by all Buddhist sects, lineages and regional congregations. It is the sole legitimate umbrella Buddhist body in Vietnam despite the GOSRV's unsuccessful attempt, in 1981, to disband and forcibly replace it with the State-run Vietnam Buddhist Church (VBC), and instrument for the GOSRV's propaganda purposes.

(5) Despite being held under strict house arrest since February 1982 simply because of his opposition to the GOSRV's attempted disbandment to the UBCV and its formation of the State-controlled VBC, the Patriarch Thich Huyen Quang, a nominee for 1979 Nobel Peace Prize, has been repeatedly and patiently appealing to leaders of the Communist Party and the GOSRV to ask for:
a) the urgent restoration and legal recognition of the UBCV's independent status,
b) the separation of Church and State and the withdrawal of the GOSRV's control over, and politicisation of, the Buddhist church.
c) the release of all arrested clergy, including the Patriarch, along with thousands of other prisoners of conscience,
d) the return of, and compensation for, all confiscated and misused Church properties.
e) open negotiations, free of pre-conditions, between the leaders of the UBCV and the GOSRV to establish mutually agreed solutions to the current conflicts.

(6) In replying to these reasonable requests, the GOSRV has, in the last few months, ordered stricter surveillance of the Patriarch's place of confinement and placed bans on all of his external communications. Whoever tries to contact, visit, help or offer gifts to him are stopped, threatened, interrogated, bodily searched (and in some cases strip searched), etc. The Patriarch's straightforward appeals have not only been ignored by the Hanoi leaders, but have also been vilified as `anti-state', `reactionary', `creating division amongst Buddhist community', etc. by the GOSRV's mass media and its nation-wide agencies, including its own VBC.

(7) All of the UBCV's brave clergy and lay members, who openly declare their support for the UBCV's appeals and who have worked sincerely for the reconciliation between the State and the UBCV, also between the VBC and the UBCV, have been inhumanely and violently attacked by the GOSRV. In the last 12 months, hundreds of monks, nuns and lay persons have been arrested and/or tortured, harshly interrogated, searched, investigated and threatened. Amongst them are the Venerables Thich Nhat Lien, Thich Tri Luc and Thich Khong Tanh (Oct—Nov 1992), Thich Thien An (Oct. 1992, tortured to death few days after arrested), Thich Hai Tang, Thich Tri Tuu, Thich Hai Thinh and about 50 lay members (5/6/93), Thich Hanh Duc, 17 other monks and about one hundred of lay followers (9/7/93), etc.

(8) The GOSRV's violent attack and mass media campaign against Buddhists' appeal for Church independent have caused suffering to many thousands of people, resulting in increased instability for the whole country. Despite the GOSRV's current campaign to illogically calumniate them and to deceive the world, these monks and lay Buddhists are arrested solely because of their aspiration to be involved and support their chosen church, the UBCV.
(9) To politicise the traditional Buddhist community in Vietnam, the GOSRV has publicly been, and is:

TAB.TAB: a) recruiting members for the VBC by forcibly converting the UBCV's moderate clergy to join it, and arresting or exiling other leaders who refuse to do so. (The GOSRV's view of `religious freedom' is not in accord with natural human dignity and heritage, but a rare favour given reluctantly on the terms of the State),
b) forcing the VBC to include, in its Charter, `Socialism' as its third aim of service—the other two, which originated from UBCV Charter, are People and Buddhism,

c) creating mutual distrust and conflicts between the lay Buddhist community and their clergy or amongst the clergy themselves by appointing VBC senior leaders to artificial political positions, and by closely controlling and intervening in the limited activities it is permitted to perform training programs such as ordination procedures, seniority promotions, etc.
d) requiring the VBC to make frequent political statements supporting the GOSRV's inconsistent policies, with the consequence of eroding the VBC's religious identity.

e) directing the VBC to start a nation-wide campaign to accusing the UBCV of having political ambitions, and forcing it to declare the VBC as the `only legitimate Buddhist authority' and its `everlasting loyalty' to the GOSRV. This is whilst the GOSRV is facing huge pressure and condemnation from the international community about its oppressive attitude to the Buddhists and its systematic violation to all human rights of all non-party-cadre citizens in the country.

PARA.TAB: (10) The GOSRV's exclusively economic renovation has not, and can not, lead to democratisation or potentials which will allow long-overdue human rights to its citizens, such as freedom to select their own political aspirations, ways of expressions, religions, education, employment, place of resident, etc. The greater its economic strength, the more determined and confident the GOSRV is in its opposition to such a democratisation process and the worse its treatment of its citizens becomes. This causes ever greater social instability and a sense of total hopelessness for Vietnam's future, and more broadly, prevents the development of stability in the SE Asia region as a whole.

(11). As its history has proved, if the UBCV is completely free and independent of political intervention, it would be a most beneficial part of, and the best spiritual force to contribute to, a humanitarian and ethically orientated redevelopment process for Vietnam.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate requests the Australian Government to:

PARA.TAB: 1. make conditional the release of currently approved financial assistance, and any future aid, to the GOSRV, on its granting of all internationally accepted human and civil rights to its people, without discrimination. This must be demonstrated by the GOSRV through its complete cessation of persecution, in any form, of all religious organisations, particularly the UBCV.
2. urge the GOSRV to cease all ill-treatment of the UBCV, and to achieve a mutually acceptable resolution, by means of fair negotiation, of all appeals made by the UBCV's Patriarch;
3. make clear statements requesting the GOSRV:

TAB.TAB: (a) not to conduct in any further suppression of those who non-violently demonstrate their beliefs and involvement with their chosen religious organisations;

(b) immediately release all who are under arrest, with or without trials, because of their religious beliefs, including the Patriarch Thich Huyen Quang and other clergy; the GOSRV should also cease their unreasonable political accusations directed towards the UBCV leaders concerning their appeals and commitment to religious freedom and the Church's independent status;

(c) completely withdraw its politicization of religion obstinate and its gross intervention in the internal affairs of religious bodies such as supporting the VBC whilst inhumanely oppressing the UBCV or by using the official mass media to create staged scenes dishonouring and defaming holders of religious authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: SUPERANNUATION (FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE FUNDING) LEVY BILL 1993

The Superannuation (Financial Assistance Funding) Levy Bill 1993 forms part of the package of seven cognate bills which are being introduced today to give effect to the new prudential arrangements for superannuation announced by the Treasurer on 21 October 1992.

The Superannuation (Financial Assistance Funding) Levy Bill 1993 provides for the imposition of a levy on superannuation funds and approved deposit funds for the purpose of funding financial assistance to any such funds that suffer loss as a result of fraudulent conduct or theft. The maximum rate of levy is .05% of fund assets in any one year.

The measures provided for in this Bill complement other measures in the various companion Bills I am also introducing today which together will strengthen substantially the framework of prudential supervision of the industry.
I commend the Superannuation (Financial Assistance Funding) Levy Bill 1993 to the Senate and present the related Explanatory Memorandum.
SUPERANNUATION (ROLLED-OVER BENEFITS) LEVY BILL 1993

The Superannuation (Rolled-Over Benefits) Levy Bill 1993 forms part of the package of seven cognate bills which are being introduced today to give effect to the new prudential arrangements for superannuation announced by the Treasurer on 21 October 1992.

The Superannuation (Rolled-Over Benefits) Levy Bill 1993 provides for the imposition of a levy on certain superannuation funds and approved deposit funds for the purpose of recouping the cost of maintenance by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission of a register of certain rolled-over benefits in respect of members who have left employment or who are no longer in contact with their fund. The maximum levy which can be imposed on these entities is $30,000.

The measures provided for in this Bill complement other measures in the various companion Bills I am also introducing today which together will strengthen substantially the framework of prudential supervision of the industry.
I commend the Superannuation (Rolled-Over Benefits) Levy Bill 1993 to the Senate and present the related Explanatory Memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this bill is to put arrangements in place for the provision of general purpose assistance to the States, Northern Territory and the ACT in 1993-94, consistent with the decisions taken at the Premiers' Conference and Loan Council meeting on 5 July 1993. The bill will replace the State Grants (General Purposes) Act 1992 and its provisions closely follow those of that Act.

The current estimate of general purpose funding for the States and the Northern Territory under the bill amounts to $14.7 billion, or about 13 per cent of estimated Commonwealth Budget outlays in 1993-94. As such, these payments constitute a major element of the Commonwealth's Budget. In combination with the Loan Council Allocations agreed at the Loan Council meeting, they also have a major bearing on the spending and borrowing of the public sector and in particular State Governments.

At the 1993 Premiers' Conference, the Commonwealth, States and Territories recognised that the economy is continuing to expand but the generally subdued growth of the international economy is hampering a more rapid domestic recovery.

While recognising that 1993-94 is not the year to cut dramatically into budget deficits, the National Fiscal Outlook report identified that significant structural repair of both Commonwealth and State budgets is needed in order to lift national savings over the medium term. Indeed the Government's medium term budgetary objective is to reduce the Commonwealth's deficit to around 1 per cent of GDP by 1996-97 and the States will need to adopt a medium term strategy of deficit restraint if the public sector is to make a significant contribution to savings.

Most of the assistance to be provided under this bill is in the form of general revenue grants, which are currently estimated to be $14.4 billion in 1993-94. The level of financial assistance grants in 1993-94 has been set so as to fulfil the Commonwealth's three year real terms guarantee that was agreed at the 1990 Premiers' Conference.

The distribution of these grants is essentially determined by the Medicare adjusted relativities recommended by the Commonwealth Grants Commission in its 1993 Report including a further adjustment for the alternative treatment of stamp duty revenues from corporate reconstructions. The Northern Territory and the ACT will receive special revenue assistance funded from the pool of financial assistance grants of $30 million and $20 million respectively in recognition of the adjustments they face in moving to State-like funding levels.
The use of the Commission's Medicare adjusted relativities reflects understanding reached with the States as part of the new Medicare Agreements.

The health funding arrangements under the new Medicare Agreement took account of a number of health factors which were also addressed by the Commission's methodology. Therefore, to implement the new agreement without also amending the Commission methodology to exclude these factors would have involved a significant element of double counting. The impact of the new arrangements on the interstate distribution of Medicare funding was to increase significantly funding to the smaller States at the expense of New South Wales and Victoria. The adjustments to the Commission's methodology were expected to have the opposite effect—that is, to redistribute financial assistance grants from the smaller States to New South Wales and Victoria. New South Wales and Victoria were given guarantees that this redistribution of financial assistance grants would benefit them by $131 million and $112 million respectively. In the event, New South Wales benefited from the new relativities, but by significantly less than expected while Victoria actually lost. At the same time, the smaller States and Northern Territory lost significantly less from the Medicare adjustment to the financial assistance grants distribution than was expected. Against this background, it was decided at the Premiers' Conference that the cost of the Medicare guarantee payments to NSW and Victoria would be shared between the Commonwealth and the States.

The contribution from the smaller States is achieved by funding payments totalling $216.6 million to New South Wales ($72.5 million) and Victoria ($144.1 million) out of the financial assistance grants and hospital funding grants pool. These payments are funded by each State according to its share of the financial assistance grants and hospital funding grants pool. Consequently, funding the payments out of the pool costs New South Wales $62.8 million (29 per cent of $216.6 million) and Victoria $45.5 million (21 per cent of $216.6 million). The Commonwealth will make payments of these amounts to New South Wales and Victoria totalling $108.3 million thus ensuring that the net benefit to New South Wales and Victoria will be $72.5 million and $144.1 million respectively. The gross payments to New South Wales and Victoria are therefore $135 million and $190 million respectively.

In 1993-94 these arrangements ensure that the Commonwealth bears approximately half the cost of these guarantee payments and the smaller States the remainder. From 1994-95 until the end of the agreements, the Commonwealth share of the cost of these guarantees will be halved and the remainder borne by the smaller States.

For the first time, State-like funding for the ACT will be incorporated into this Bill. In previous years the general revenue grants to the ACT have been funded directly by the Commonwealth rather than through the financial assistance grants pool. State-like funding for the ACT will be incorporated into the financial assistance grants pool for 1993-94 and the size of the pool has been increased to reflect that change in funding. Special revenue assistance to the ACT of $20 million in 1993-94 will also be funded from the financial assistance grants pool and is included in this Bill. Other payments to the ACT including transitional allowances and special fiscal needs totalling $64 million as well as a further $20 million special revenue assistance will be paid directly by the Commonwealth under the Annual Appropriation Bills.

As noted earlier, the Northern Territory is to be provided with special revenue assistance in 1993-94 of $30 million. In general the relativities recommended by the Commission take account of the particular circumstances facing individual States and Territories. The high per capita relativity recommended for the Northern Territory recognises the higher costs it faces in providing government services to its population. In the medium term this level of funding should be sufficient to enable the Northern Territory to provide the same level of services to its population as enjoyed by people in other States. The purpose of the special revenue assistance is to allow the Northern Territory to adjust to this level of funding from the more generous levels provided in earlier years. It compares with special revenue assistance of around $40 million provided for this purpose in 1992/93 and similar assistance having been provided each year to the Northern Territory since its inclusion in the pool of general revenue assistance for the States.

Consistent with arrangements in previous years, financial assistance grants and special revenue assistance will all be adjusted for the difference between the actual increase in the Consumer Price Index in the year to the March quarter 1994 and the forecast at the time of the Premiers' Conference, so that the real level of assistance agreed at the Premiers' Conference is maintained.

In accordance with its priorities and policies in the health education area, the Government decided that, from 1985, nurse education should be progressively transferred from hospitals to higher education institutions. This move has helped to provide a better educated and more flexible nursing work force and to increase the educational and employment opportunities in the nursing profession, particularly for women.

The transfer will be completed this year and from 1 January 1994 the Commonwealth will take over full responsibility for funding of nurse education. This bill gives legislative effect to the reduction in general purpose payments to the States reflecting this transfer in funding responsibility.

In addition, from 1 January 1994, the Commonwealth will untie annual funding of $350 million of Commonwealth road funding for arterial roads. In 1993-94, payment will be $175 million, distributed on the average of the arterial roads allocation for the three years to 1992 (inclusive). In 1995-96 and 1996-97, the aggregate level of funds will be indexed to the movements in financial assistance grants. In 1997-98 the funds will be absorbed into financial assistance grants.
The bill also provides for the payment of $330.3 million for capital grants to the States and Territories.

The bill includes one additional feature to the Act it replaces. This bill includes a clause helping to protect the right of Higher Education institutions to decide the most appropriate range and level of services and amenities for their students.

Student organisations provide a wide range of services and amenities for their members, for example counselling, sport, health and careers services. These are funded mainly by a services and amenities fee collected from students by institutions on behalf of organisations representing the interest of students generally.
The Western Australian State Parliament recently legislated to interfere with the rights of institutions in that State to make their own decisions about imposing or collecting these fees.

This Bill, in conjunction with the Higher Education Funding Act 1988, provides an avenue for the Commonwealth to make up any shortfall in revenue experienced by an institution as a result of such State actions and to recover this money from the States.
Mr President, this bill is an integral part of the Commonwealth's financial relations with the State Governments and of the Budget.
I present the explanatory memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
