PARA.TAB: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That these bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the revised explanatory memoranda relating to the Wool International Bill 1993 and the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Bill 1993 and move:

PARA.TAB: That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: WOOL INTERNATIONAL BILL 1993
There are eight bills in this package of wool industry legislation.

Mr President, these bills will provide the statutory framework for a much stronger, and commercially driven Australian wool industry. The wool industry's long term future will only be secured as the supplier of a high quality premier textile fibre to world markets if we fundamentally change the industry's structures to provide a more market-driven approach that is more closely attuned to the needs of its customers and end-users.

Both the food and the natural fibre industries as presenting the most exciting development opportunities for this country, with the potential to substantially increase value adding, exports and the jobs that go with such developments. We already have in place a strategy for the development of the food industries, through the work of the agri-food council, and the legislation being introduced today will also provide the foundation for the wool industry to also grow and prosper.

In March 1993 the government made an election commitment that an independent review of the role of the wool industry structures would be commissioned. One of the first actions of the government following the election was to establish a review committee to achieve this.

The committee, comprising Professor Ross Garnaut, Mr Rodney Price and Mr Stephen Bennett brought an extensive background in wool industry, economics, trade, business, finance and marketing expertise to the review and presented a comprehensive blue-print for securing the future of the wool industry in August this year.

Upon receiving the Wool Industry Review Committee's report, the minister initiated wide ranging consultations with all sectors of the industry and modified the committees recommendations to account for some legitimate industry concerns. The minister has, however, maintained the integrity of the committee's package in the legislation I am presenting today.

The Wool International Bill 1993 establishes a new, strongly commercially oriented organisation called Wool International which will assume responsibility for discharging the $2.28 billion debt and disposing of the 3.9 million bale stockpile currently held by the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. It will also be responsible for the development for the industry of a range of forward selling, marketing and risk management mechanisms to provide a broader range of options for wool producers and others in the industry to market their product and manage risk.

The Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Bill 1993 will establish a new Australian wool research and promotion organisation which will be responsible for generic wool promotion and wool research and development.

The Wool Legislation (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1993 will repeal the three acts, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991, the Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991, and the Australian Wool Industry Council Act 1991, on which the current wool industry arrangements are based. It amends the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989, to remove provisions relating to wool research and development which will now be encompassed within this new package of legislation. It also amends the Wool Tax (Administration) Act 1964, to require the provision of additional information concerning wool tax paid.
The last five bills in the package each amend one of the five wool tax acts to reflect changes in setting wool tax rates necessary with the new industry structures.
This legislation reflects an integrated package of measures. Essentially these provide a three pronged strategy for the wool industry designed to
.establish industry bodies with a clear commercial focus;
.establish new mechanisms for marketing wool,
.expand international trade in wool and wool products through the establishment of an Australian trade and investment package;

This new approach gives a greater emphasis on building demand, promoting quality and reliability to our customers and providing new marketing tools to spread market risk and develop new markets, not only in the growing markets of Asia, but also in our more traditional European markets.

Mr President, this package represents a watershed in the development of the Australian wool industry because it establishes the means for enabling the industry to take more direct control over its own destiny. As such it represents a critical step forward towards self-determination and independence for the future. It will see wool producers becoming key shareholders in their own wool marketing company—Wool International—supported by a professionally and commercially oriented generic promotion and research organisation, whose activities will be closely linked to those of Wool International to ensure complementarity and full exploitation of market opportunities.

Mr President, the structures embodied in this package reflect on the one hand the commercial thrust the government sees for the industry in the future. On the other, the package reflects the government's continuing commitment to wool industry research and development and, through its maintenance of wool tax legislation, the funding of promotion.
Wool International

Mr President, perhaps the most exciting element of the government's proposed measures is the establishment of Wool International. Within it is embodied a mechanism for effectively reducing the wool stockpile to commercial levels; giving producers equity in any residual value, including all wool and non-wool assets, once the associated debt has been acquitted; and largely removing the government from much of its involvement in industry affairs.

Wool International is established at the outset as a statutory authority with the intention that it be first corporatised, then privatised, by a target date of 1 July 1997. This is a departure from the recommendations of the wool industry review committee which were that Wool International be established as a 100 per cent government owned company until privatisation.

The reason the government has decided on a three phase approach rather than two is because it received legal advice that it would be difficult to move directly to a government owned corporation. Relevant considerations included the extent of the debt that Wool International would have to initially take on and the practical difficulties of achieving corporatisation within a reasonable time frame.

However, in framing the legislation for Wool International, particular care has been taken to reflect as far as possible the model for government business enterprises (or GBES) so as to ensure that the commerciality of such bodies is a feature of Wool International.

The Wool International Bill provides at this stage only the framework for the second phase in Wool International's life, corporatisation. Legal advice on the complexity of these processes means that it is better to leave the detail relating to corporatisation and privatisation until closer to 1997. This represents in the government's view, the more responsible approach. At the same time, by providing the framework we are clearly signalling our broad intentions and our commitment to privatising Wool International.

Wool International's functions will include the development of alternative forward selling, marketing and risk management mechanisms to better enable industry participants to market their product, manage their cash flows and their risks.
In the period leading up to privatisation, a key activity of Wool International will be to effectively manage and market the wool stockpile and to reduce the debt.
Fixed disposal schedule

Because of the decisions taken in April this year by the government, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission is in a position where it is not required to sell any more wool during 1993-94 to meet its debt reduction schedule. It may however sell further wool if there is sufficient demand.

A central element of the marketing of the stockpile under Wool International will be the imposition of a fixed sales schedule. This is central to the development of forward selling mechanisms and the establishment of wool futures and other commercial risk management tools.

The government has decided, however, that the fixed schedule will not commence until 1 July 1994. Until that time, Wool International will be required to manage the stockpile in accordance with current policy.

The minister has indicated previously that the process of stockpile disposal will be a transparent one. The legislation clearly sets out, for all in the industry, exactly how much wool must be sold in any month or quarter.

Although the Wool Industry Review Committee recommended that Wool International be required to release 5 kt per month between 1 November 1993 to 30 June 1994 and then 33 kt per quarter from 1 July 1994 to 30 June 1997, the government has delayed the introduction of the fixed schedule to 1 July 1994.

In deciding to delay the introduction of the fixed schedule to 1 July 1994, the government was concerned to honour its existing commitments regarding stockpile disposal, which apply until 1 July 1994, and to allow more time for the development of forward selling and risk management tools by Wool International. The introduction of a fixed schedule is central to the development of such tools and it is prudent to allow the additional time for this to occur.

From July 1994 until December 1994, the fixed disposal rate is to be within a narrow range around 5 kt per month. In commercial terms, this translates into the range of 27,700 to 29,100 bales per month. The narrow range has been introduced purely for practical reasons. From 1 January 1995, the disposal rate is to be in the narrow range around 33 kt per quarter, or 182,000 to 192,000 bales. These ranges represent around 5 per cent of each of the relevant target rates of 28,400 per month and 187,000 per quarter.

Wool International will be required to make a public statement monthly and then quarterly on its compliance against the disposal schedule for that month or quarter. This is expected to be a very simple statement although Wool International will have the opportunity to report more fully to industry should it decide on commercial grounds that it should do so. Wool International will not be required to report in detail on its activities in relation to stockpile management. It is intended to be a commercially oriented body and its commercial activities will be treated accordingly.

Nonetheless, a confidential and regular reporting process will be required of Wool International by government on its disposal activities and its debt management activities generally while ever the government guarantee is in place. These reports will set out how the disposal schedule has been achieved in the relevant period and how revenue has been utilised. This will also provide government with an ongoing view of the body's debt profile and ensure its operations accord with its charter.

During the period between now and July 1994, the government expects Wool International to make significant progress in setting up forward selling and risk management mechanisms for the industry. We appreciate that this will take time, however, the government believes that Wool International should be well advanced in this process by the time the fixed disposal schedule commences. During this period also, Wool International will be able to undertake other activities on a commercial basis. In this context, the government is well aware of the importance of market intelligence and reporting to the industry and, having yet to settle how industry can best undertake these activities in the future, a savings provision has been included in this bill to enable Wool International to continue to perform this Australian Wool Corporation function until 30 June 1994.

Prior to privatisation, Wool International will primarily be a selling organisation. The government does not intend that it be a day-to-day trader in the market place. Neither is it to be a speculator. The minister will be issuing instructions to the board of Wool International that they develop Wool International's selling strategies specifically to meet its requirements under the fixed disposal schedule. The buy-in power would only be used in specific circumstances to meet the legislative requirements of the disposal schedule set out in the act.

With regard to the non-wool assets of the industry, the new board of Wool International will have the power to dispose of these should they decide it commercially prudent to do so. On the same basis, such assets may well be retained so that on privatisation, a portfolio of non-wool assets complements the wool assets and the overall net worth of the organisation. In the interim, Wool International will be able to use the revenue stream from these non-wool assets for its commercial activities. This will potentially generate around $25 million per annum of seed capital for its developmental work. However the government expects that as Wool International develops its own revenues from its other commercial activities, the need to draw on these funds will be reduced. The government intends to review Wool International's use of the seed capital in two years time to determine the need for continued access to these funds. Wool International will be required to maintain and report to government on this funding separately.

The government will continue to guarantee the borrowings but will include the hedging activities of Wool International as these are related directly to the financial management of the stockpile. This arrangement will be through a statutory guarantee. The guarantee will not apply to any activities outside the stockpile management.
Determination of equity in Wool International

Producers' payment of the debt component of the wool tax from 1 July 1993 onwards will give them their equity entitlement in Wool International on privatisation. However, provision will also be made for producers to increase their debt repayment contribution up to a maximum 10 per cent should they wish to acquire additional equity in Wool International.

To establish the equity rights of producers to shares in Wool International, it will be required to keep a register of wool-tax payers. The register will become the share register of Wool International on privatisation. The register will record the details needed to assign such rights, and in future, wool tax payments will need to be accompanied by information on the wool tax payer. Any unclaimed shares will be re-allocated proportionately to all eligible wool producers.

On privatisation, shares will be issued to wool tax payers at zero value. Should they subsequently dispose of them they will be liable for capital gains tax. The rationale for this is that the initial tax payment is tax deductible. To allocate shares with an imputed market value would effectively confer on wool tax payers a double taxation benefit. In respect of voluntary contributions up to 10 per cent of the sale value of wool, the expectation is that they would not be tax deductible and the value of the shares for capital gains tax purposes would be based on the value of the contributions made.
Australian wool research and promotion organisation

I will also be shortly introducing the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Bill 1993. This bill will implement the merger of research and promotion that wool producers agreed to at their last AGM and will continue Australia's close involvement in the generic promotion of wool.

The government recognises that there may at times be slightly grey areas where the activities of Wool International and AWRAP may impinge on each other. However, it will be relying on the commonsense and business acumen of the boards. The majority of membership of each board will overlap to ensure that, while they each have quite distinct roles to fulfil, there is a close linkage between the two functions. In resolving any potential areas of conflict over functions the government will be relying on the chairpersons to be guided by the underlying philosophy of the proposed new structures that as much as possible of the current functions of the wool corporation should be transferred to the private sector.
Board structures and appointment procedures

The members of the boards of Wool International and AWRAP will be the key to the success of this package. It is important that the boards not be selected on the basis of representation but on the calibre of their expertise.

The boards of AWRAP and Wool International will have a majority of common members. AWRAP will have 9 members while Wool International will have 11 members. Consistent with the wool industry review committee's recommendation there will be a commercial approach to the selection and appointment of the Wool International board and, because of the need for overlap in the boards and the need for appointments to be expertise-based, there will no longer be a selection committee process for AWRAP.
It is intended that the minister will appoint members after wide consultation with the business community and with industry groups, including the wool council of Australia.
Staffing arrangements

Staff in the AWC and the AWRC will, in the first instance, become the staff of either AWRAP or Wool International on the establishment of those bodies. This will allow for some staff to be transferred between the two bodies if necessary to ensure the continuation of particular activities. Staff transferred over to the new bodies will be transferred on no lesser terms and conditions than existed prior to the restructuring. Thereafter, staffing matters will be the responsibility of the incoming boards.
Wool tax arrangements

The wool tax rate for debt management purposes is set out in the Wool International Bill at 4.5 per cent and this rate will remain in place until privatisation. This will provide for Wool International to establish a net worth prior to privatisation. The rate cannot now be changed without amending the act.

Wool tax rates for promotion and research and development will be 3.5 per cent and 0.5 per cent respectively and will apply for three year periods rather than the current single year. These rates will therefore apply for the period July 1994 to June 1997 unless changed by grower ballot during that period.

The maximum rate of wool tax will remain at 15 per cent to allow flexibility to increase the promotion and research and development components if the industry wishes to do so and thereby not constrain the ability of growers in establishing appropriate rates for promotion and R and D through grower ballot.

In the process of making consequential amendments of an administrative nature to the wool tax acts, the government is tightening up on the collection process by requiring that all collectors of wool tax be registered in future. This will ensure that wool tax can only be paid on behalf of Australian wool producers by a registered collector. The change is an important one for the industry particularly in the area of future individual equity rights in Wool International. Such equity rights are to accrue in proportion to wool tax paid for debt management and the process for assigning such rights will need to be as tight as possible.
Australian Wool Industry Council

The Australian Wool Industry Council was established to provide a forum for the provision of representative industry advice to the government. The need for such a body will be substantially diminished with the implementation of the proposed new arrangements. The new structures will provide the right communication linkages for the wool industry. Consistent with the wool industry committee's recommendation the Australian Wool Industry Council is therefore to be abolished.

Mr President, this package of measures represents an exciting shift in wool industry arrangements and I am confident that it has within it the potential to revolutionise the way we regard our wool industry and the way it manages itself.
I commend this bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
AUSTRALIAN WOOL RESEARCH AND PROMOTION ORGANISATION BILL 1993
This bill establishes the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, AWRAP.

Mr President, I have already outlined how this particular bill fits into the total package of legislation for the wool industry. AWRAP will play a critical part in improving the performance of the Australian wool industry by encouraging the maximum possible co-ordination of the generic promotion of wool and wool products with research and development activities.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has long held the view that R and D and promotion should be closely linked in order to get proper targeting of the R and D effort and promotion activity. This view is also supported by the wool industry at its last AGM and was subsequently endorsed by the wool industry review committee. The aim is to get a more commercially driven and consumer responsive approach to these activities and this legislation will give effect to this objective.

The legislation makes it quite clear that AWRAP's role is to direct the generic promotion dollar to where it will be most effective, including promoting the use of wool and wool products in Australia and overseas through consumer advertising coupled with the provision of technical advisory services in those markets which require assistance to develop and expand their wool processing industry, using Australian wool.

As well, it will assess research and development needs in relation to the wool industry, and provide funding for this purpose, and will disseminate and encourage the adoption of the results. There is clearly a strong link between the R&D and the promotion activities and the government is pleased to be able to respond to the industry's request that the two functions should be merged.

Generic promotion for AWRAP is envisaged as promotion in its broadest sense and encompassing such activities as consumer advertising, the provision of technical advice and assistance to wool processors, manufacturers and retailers to encourage wool and wool blend product processing and innovation to meet consumer needs, and supporting wool trade marks such as the Woolmark. Generic promotion will also encompass a range of international market development activities both of wool generally and Australian wool in particular where these latter activities are directly related to promotion and are directed to encouraging processors in developing markets to opt for Australian wool rather than other fibres.

In summary, AWRAP's activities might be defined as those which promote the use of wool over other fibres but do not extend to direct marketing or sale of wool. Selling wool will be clearly the function of Wool International and other commercial suppliers.

While the role of AWRAP is clearly focused on generic promotion, there is a need for this activity to be closely integrated with the advertising and brand promotion of companies promoting wool products. In the past, wool promotion funding has depended heavily on funds provided by wool growers and the government. This needs to change and one of the principal goals of the new organisation will be to actively seek additional funding from commercial sources, principally wool processors and companies producing consumer wool products. The Minister has made commitments to the industry that wool promotion will be adequately funded and the new structures provide the opportunity for this to be secured from commercial sources. For example, discussions are continuing with the international wool textile organisation to assess its role in promotion funding.

AWRAP will be able to continue its participation in, and fund international promotion activities of, bodies such as the International Wool Secretariat (IWS). The nature of, and level of funding for, such activities will be a matter for the AWRAP board but the expectation is that Australia will continue to play a major role in influencing the policies and strategies of bodies such as the IWS.

While the activities of the Wool Research and Development Corporation will be transferred to AWRAP, the government recognises the success of the operational arrangements of that corporation. Therefore, the sub-structure of advisory and technical committees is expected to be maintained in the short term, although in the longer term this will be a matter for the AWRAP board to determine.
The government will continue its matching of the research effort, the funding of which will be separately accounted for as part of the accountability arrangements to apply to the new organisation.

It is also aware that with the downturn in the wool industry and the reduced revenue base derived from the wool tax, it has been difficult to maintain the funding base for both R and D and promotion. In this context, the government is well aware of the difficulties faced by the research and development corporation in trying to accommodate the fluctuating revenue base whilst continuing to provide for ongoing research programs.

The creation of AWRAP will provide some relief in this respect. AWRAP will have borrowing powers which, should the AWRAP board choose, could be used as a short term smoothing mechanism to alleviate some of the impact of wool tax income variability on suppliers of research services.

The government has been encouraging greater commercialisation and comprehensive uptake of new technology and innovation by wool producers and processors. Increased commercialisation of R and D will not only assist in supporting the competitiveness of wool in the world's fibre markets, it will also provide a means of generating additional income for research and development purposes.

The promotion and research and development components of the wool tax will both be determined through a ballot of producers, which may be conducted either independently of AWRAP annual general meetings, or in conjunction with them. The timing will be a matter for the board of AWRAP to determine. Provision has been made for the AWRAP board to formally consult with the Wool Council of Australia regarding the appropriate rates of the promotion and research and development components of the wool tax to be put to a ballot of producers.

Annual general meetings will be continued for AWRAP only, although Wool International will be able to hold such meetings if decided by its board. The AWRAP AGM will provide the opportunity for wool producers to question the board of the organisation about the performance of its functions and, in the ultimate, provides the sanction of a vote of no confidence in the board. However, no provision has been made to take general motions from the floor of the meeting. There is no sense in such a process unless the outcome was to be binding on the board and that could, on occasions, be in clear conflict with the board's responsibilities under the act for the day to day direction of the organisation. Similar arrangements to those currently in place for the determination of voting rights will apply. However, the information needed to determine voting entitlements will, in future, be drawn by AWRAP from the share register to be maintained by Wool International. Upon privatisation of Wool International the register of wool taxpayers will be passed to AWRAP.

AWRAP will be required to prepare both corporate and operational plans each year and is expected to widely consult with industry in doing so. The corporate plan will define principal goals, outline strategies and nominate performance indicators and must receive ministerial endorsement before coming into effect. The annual operational plan will detail the activities required to give effect to the matters set out in the corporate plan and must also be submitted to the minister.
Mr President, most of the proposed changes encompassed within the bills before the House can be implemented immediately.
There are, however, two particular areas concerning the transfer of functions which have yet to be settled. These are quality assurance and shearer training.

AWRAP is expected to have a very focused and concentrated approach to generic promotion and not be distracted by a wide range of other activities. It will therefore be an immediate task of the new AWRAP board to drive the process that will ensure the earliest and successful divestment of functions, particularly those concerning quality management.

To ensure that the transition is effectively made, and that there is no break in continuity in the performance of those functions, the legislation includes savings provisions, the effect of which is to enable AWRAP to continue to perform this function until an orderly transfer can be achieved. The savings provision will apply for no longer than the period to 31 December 1994.

The government is well aware of the importance of quality assurance to the future of the wool industry. Indeed it has been a strong advocate of the adoption by the industry of a quality management approach to marketing. It therefore has no intention of having the function taken from the Australian Wool Corporation without ensuring that there is a workable, effective arrangement in place for the function to be performed by other bodies.

The intention is to progressively hand over those functions identified for transfer from AWRAP to other bodies which the government, in consultation with AWRAP, deems can effectively take up particular responsibilities. By this means we can ensure a smooth process of divestment from AWRAP, without dislocation of quality assurance and our customers' ability to be reassured about the quality of our product.

The various alternatives will be carefully examined over the coming months during the transfer process. Without being definitive, the divestment process might include a role for the Australian Wool Exchange and the Australian Wool Testing Authority.

It might also be possible given the extent of standards already developed, that an Australian standard could be developed for wool packs and that this be reflected in customs regulations replacing the current reference to the Wool Corporation's involvement.

The government is confident that the wool industry can, utilising the standards currently in place and developing new ones, bring an industry-wide response to building on and further developing Australia's already high global reputation for premium quality wool.

Wool quality is an industry wide challenge and there are already examples of innovative responses which demonstrate that different sectors are prepared to meet quality goals to better differentiate their product in the marketplace and so attract buyer premiums.

Wool broking companies are already encouraging producers to distinguish their product by meeting predetermined quality standards in the shearing shed and I am aware of the work being done on this by Dalgety and Elders for example. Systems for wool testing in Australia are already regarded as the world's best.

Shearer training has long been organised and funded by the Wool Corporation through the wool tax. The government is already working with the Wool Corporation and relevant training agencies to determine the most cost-effective approach for the future, given the particular nature of shearer training. There is the opportunity to bring shearer training into mainstream technical training approaches, such as through TAFES and to link it in an integrated way to quality assurance systems involving a better understanding of clip preparation for fine wools. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy expects the industry to actively pursue these opportunities.
Finally, a savings provision has also been included to provide for the continuation of funding for exotic animal disease eradication program which is to run through until mid 1995.

In conclusion Mr President, with the creation of AWRAP there is the opportunity to better coordinate and commercially focus wool promotion and the R and D effort. The wool industry is facing a period where industry funds for promotion and R&D are at their lowest levels for some time. The more streamlined approach which AWRAP will bring to the industry will allow a better focus on achieving returns for the industry for the benefit of all participants.
I commend this bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
WOOL LEGISLATION (REPEALS AND CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1993

The purpose of this bill is to remove or amend existing wool legislation to allow for the introduction of new legislation to establish wool international and the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation.

This bill repeals the Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991, the Australian Wool Industry Council Act 1991 and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Act 1991 and sections of the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 relating to the Wool Research and Development Corporation.

The bill also provides for arrangements to cover the transitional period between the existing arrangements and the new arrangements, in particular to ensure that staff employed under the current structure retain their terms and conditions of employment, and benefits, under the new structure.

I have indicated previously that a significant part of the move towards the wool industry commercialisation is the inclusion of a provision to give producers equity in wool international. The mechanism for establishing the entitlements of producers to shares in wool international on privatisation will require amendments to the Wool Tax Administration Act 1964. Wool brokers, dealers, exporters and manufacturers will be required within 6 months to provide details of tax payers to the tax commissioner who will be in turn required to pass these onto wool international covering the period from 1 July 1993.

Other minor amendments to the administration act which have been made provide for greater uniformity in penalties and registration of wool-tax collectors; and reduce the penalty for unpaid tax in line with reductions in tax related penalties in other Commonwealth legislation.
I commend this bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
WOOL TAX (Nos 1 to 5) AMENDMENT BILLS 1993
The purpose of these bills is to amend the existing wool tax acts to reflect changes to the wool tax arrangements flowing from changes to the statutory arrangements for the wool industry.

Under the current arrangements, in determining the debt repayment component of the wool tax, the views of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission must be taken into account, together with any views expressed by the Wool Council of Australia.

Similarly, in determining the wool tax rates to apply for promotion and research and development purposes, account must be taken of the recommendations of the annual general meetings of the Australian Wool Corporation and of the Wool Research and Development Corporation.

Under the new arrangements, the debt component of wool tax is a fixed rate of 4.5 per cent and is included in the Wool International Bill 1993. This will terminate when wool international is privatised. For promotion and research and development tax rates, provision has been made in the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Bill 1993 that the wool tax rates will remain at their current level of 3.5 per cent and 0.5 per cent respectively unless a ballot of wool producers recommends a change.
I commend these bills to honourable senators.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Finance and Public Administration Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on the provisions of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993 concerning the taxation treatment of credit unions together with the submissions and the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The provisions in the bill concerning credit unions were referred to the committee on 28 September for report by today and the committee has met that timetable. Given that the bill will be debated perhaps later today or tomorrow, I will not take much of the Senate's time in referring to the report, but it is important that I give an overall summary of the committee's conclusions and recommendations.

PARA.TAB: We have dealt in some detail with the various terms of reference that were given to us: the role played by credit unions in Australia; their structural operations and community services; the reasons for credit unions being granted a partial tax exemption in 1974; the effect of the taxation treatment proposed by the government on credit unions' capital formation and on their continued provision of financial and community services; the effect of the taxation treatment proposed by the government on asset concentration in both the credit union movement and the retail financial sector, and the implications of this effect upon consumer choice; whether the reasons for the differentiated tax treatment of credit unions and building societies are still valid; and the effects, if any, of the taxation treatment proposed by the government on housing cooperatives and mutual savings banks.

The committee made some general conclusions and recommendations. The main issue of concern to those who provided submissions or oral evidence to the committee was whether the tax exemption should be removed. Senator McMullan told the committee that the decision was an on balance one and that there were arguments in both directions. The committee agreed with this and noted that the arguments have been extensively canvassed for more than a decade.

The government's main argument was that the need to change the practice of the past 20 years arose because some credit unions had become sufficiently large providers of financial services as to create distorting effects in the financial system. This was identified as an emerging trend by the Campbell committee 10 years ago. That committee recommended either that the tax exemption be removed—its preferred option—or that, if the exemption were to be retained for social reasons, the membership of credit unions be closely and continuously monitored to ensure that the principle of mutuality was strictly applied.

There is no doubt that the larger credit unions are significant providers of financial services in competition with other institutions and, in principle, should be treated like them. It is equally clear that the credit union movement provides social and community services which deserve support. The committee's view is that these two factors need not conflict.

The social and community services supplied by credit unions in most, if not all, cases would be deductible from the tax otherwise payable. Such expenditure would include donations to charitable organisations normally eligible for tax deductibility, sponsorships in the nature of advertising expenditure and, where there is a relatively uneconomic branch and staffing structure as part of a deliberate policy of providing community access and advice, legitimate business expenditure. The committee was told that building societies have supplied many of the same benefits without a section 23G exemption.

The present tax exemption benefits the majority of credit union members who are in secured, paid employment and is an inefficient way of delivering benefits to those members who are not. The committee believes it should be possible to maintain the benefits provided by the credit union movement while removing the distortion involved in the exemption from tax of income earned by the larger credit unions.

The committee raised the issue of treating small credit unions differently and canvassed the comment made by Senator McMullan in answer to that. Despite the arguments, it seemed to the committee that distinguishing between small institutions on the one hand, and medium and large institutions on the other, might be one way of improving the efficiency of delivery of the benefits currently said to result partly from the tax exemption.

The committee first considered there might be an appropriate discontinuity in the asset range of credit unions which would allow such a distinction to be made. If there had been, it would have been possible to set such an asset level below which the tax exemption would apply and which would be sufficiently low as to not distort decision making while removing all of the very small credit unions from the income tax system. However, figures supplied by the Australian Financial Institutions Commission indicated that there was no such discontinuity and this led the committee to consider an alternative based on a phased exemption from tax for the very small credit unions. Such an arrangement related to taxable income would avoid the problems inherent in a sharp cut-off point. It would be possible to exempt from tax those credit unions with taxable incomes of less than, say, $50,000. The exemption could be phased out so that the full effect of the normal corporate tax rate would apply to credit unions with taxable incomes of more than, say, $150,000.

If this proposal were adopted, the committee estimates that of the 320 or so credit unions, about 100—all of them very small—would be entitled to full or partial tax exemption. Extending this same approach to very small cooperative building societies would be unlikely to add significantly to the cost. In fact, only one or two building societies would fall into this category.

The committee believes that the differences between the larger and the very small credit unions in terms of their operations and objectives are sufficient to justify consideration of assistance to the latter through the tax system as a matter of social policy. It also believes that the scope for other measures to maintain the social benefits provided by the credit union movement and to remove the competitive disadvantages suffered by credit unions in some areas should be assessed. In particular, the effects of differences in the cost of prudential supervision of different types of entities should be considered.

The submission of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) stated that the tax exemption was not an appropriately targeted instrument in this case for achieving social or competition policy ends. While there is force in this argument, the submission is silent on what other arm of policy, if any, should be used. The committee believes that the transition period provided in the legislation allows time for such issues to be considered.
To conclude, I will read the committee's recommendations. Firstly:

SPEECH.PARA: that the provisions of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) 1993 concerning the taxation treatment of credit unions be agreed to but that, in view of the strong evidence of differences in the role and structure of the very small credit unions on the one hand and the larger institutions on the other, the Government give serious consideration to moving amendments so that such very small credit unions retain the benefit of a tax exemption and so that very small cooperative building societies are similarly treated;
Secondly:

that such amendments exempt from tax those credit unions with taxable incomes of less than, say, $50,000, with the exemption phasing out so that the full effect of the normal corporate tax rate would apply to credit unions with taxable incomes of more than, say, $150,000;
Thirdly:
that the Government, in consultation with representatives of financial institutions:

.prepare a statement on how the socially beneficial services currently provided by credit unions will be maintained and on how the competitive disadvantages currently faced by credit unions will be dealt with after the removal of the tax exemption;
.pay particular regard in the statement to means of removing possible inequities in the way in which the costs of prudential supervision of various types of financial institutions are met;
.publish the statement in its response to this report before the 1994 budget.

I thank all those people who gave evidence to the committee at its hearing on Friday, 8 October 1993, and I thank all members of the committee for their cooperation in coming to this unanimous report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report just presented is the result of an inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration into the removal of the tax exempt status of credit unions. This has naturally raised considerable concern within the community. It clearly came as a considerable surprise to the credit union industry when the government removed, without warning, a tax concession which had existed for about 20 years. Despite the very tight timetable for this inquiry, 28 individuals and organisations thought it important enough to provide written submissions. The committee heard both sides of the argument at length from a range of witnesses at its public hearing on Friday, 8 October.

PARA.TAB: As the deputy chairman of the committee, I would like to take this opportunity to thank Senator Coates, the chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, for his independent assessment of what was a politically charged issue. I believe the final outcome—a consensus report—was largely attributable to his independent assessment of the importance of the issues that were before the committee.

Two main issues have been raised since the government announced the removal of the tax concession for credit unions in the last budget. The first relates to whether the decision was appropriate or correct; the second concerns the way the government went about its removal. There are arguments both ways on the merits of the decision. Some credit unions have grown very large and are fully competitive with other financial institutions. The 18 largest credit unions now have asset levels exceeding $150 million. The largest has more than $370 million in assets. It seems illogical that credit unions of this size should continue to be subsidised by the Australian taxpayer through the non-payment of income tax. It would certainly be illogical to base any continuation of the subsidy on the needs of the smallest credit unions. Nevertheless, the government must continue to exempt the small credit unions when their role is significantly social in character and the lending process is but one area of their work in society.

The committee heard very convincing evidence on the value of the social contribution made by the small community based, and often church based, credit unions. This contrast between the role and structure of the smaller and the larger credit unions led the committee to the alternative approach proposed in its report—that it seemed reasonable to exempt a certain amount of the income of credit unions from taxation. This would relieve the small institutions from any tax on their operations, which clearly are not primarily commercial.

If the tax-free threshold applied to the whole credit union sector, it would provide some compensation for all credit unions for the higher cost of prudential supervision which they face when compared with banks. The government must recognise the changing part of the regulatory and taxation structure, even if there is a case for a change in isolation which might lead to some unintended consequences.

The committee has recommend that the government consider a phasing out of the tax-free threshold and report back to the parliament on a means of removing the competitive disadvantage posed by differentials in prudential supervision costs. I would urge the government to consider the advantages of simply extending the tax-free threshold to all credit unions. The additional cost to revenue would be negligible and would completely avoid the distortion of a phasing out system. It should not have been necessary for the committee to recommend that the government go back and consult with the industry on better ways of achieving its ends. The problems have arisen in this case because of the government's approach to the issue.

Witnesses with strong connections to the labour movement told the committee how they were astonished about this change and how it had occurred without consultation. The credit unions—wrongly, as it turned out—had relied on the government's promise before the last election that there would be no new taxes. One witness told us:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we believed that we would at least have had the chance to put our case fully in the type of . . . consultative process that has been a consistent
hallmark of this government's activity over the last 10 years.

Unfortunately, that consultative process was not present on this occasion. We all accept the need for confidentiality of budget measures but the amount of revenue involved in this case is trivial. The issues are complex and there was no need to rush into legislation. The legislation does not even have any effect this financial year. The government should have consulted with credit unions on this proposal before committing itself to the details of that approach. Its own strong supporters expected that it would.

PARA.TAB: I pay tribute to the evidence that was presented by a distinguished former member of the House of Representatives, Mr Vince Martin. He was a top executive within the Australian Taxation Office before taking his place in the House of Representatives. Mr Martin, a life member of the ALP, told us that he thought it would be political suicide for the government to persist in this cause. The ACTU and the Victorian and New South Wales trades hall councils have condemned it. I recommend that honourable senators and listeners read the evidence given by Mr Vince Martin where he detailed the history of the development of the credit union movement in Australia following the return of a number of distinguished servicemen after World War II.

I trust that the government will heed the committee's recommendations, effectively, to exempt from tax the income of the small credit unions and building societies. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard two graphs showing the growth in building society assets and credit union assets as at 30 June 1993. Both types of institutions show similar rates of growth, which are quite significant, and both types of organisations compete very effectively in terms of lending processes within the Australian financial structure.
Leave granted.
The graphs read as follows—
[GRAPHS OMITTED FROM DATABASE, SEE HARD COPY PAGE 1987]

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report presented to the Senate by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration regarding credit unions. I have attended many hearings on a wide variety of issues. The evidence that was given to the committee by both sides—the building societies and the credit unions—was of an extremely high quality, and they addressed with vigour and hard facts the issues before the committee. I join Senator Coates and my colleague Senator Watson in commending those people who attended the committee hearing and gave evidence to the committee.

PARA.TAB: I would like to comment on a couple of matters which came before the committee. The first relates to why we had this particular hearing. It was clear from the evidence that was given to the committee that the credit unions did not expect a Labor government to impose this type of tax. Senator Watson pointed out that the representatives of the credit unions sought assurances from the coalition parties that no such tax would be imposed. When they heard the promises of Mr Keating, reiterated time and again during the election campaign, that there would be no new taxes, they naturally assumed that such a promise applied to them and they could rest safe in the comfort of knowing that no such levy would be imposed on credit unions. This is despite the fact that, as Senator McMullan said to the committee, this had been discussed for a long time and had been an issue. Senator McMullan was quite right to raise that. The credit unions took great comfort from the promise and commitment from Mr Keating that no further taxes would be imposed. Like so many others in the community, regrettably, they are paying the price for the broken promises of the Keating Labor government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could not stretch this one and call it a new tax, could you?

—I reply to Senator Coates by saying that two issues are involved. Senator Coates would understand that if he went to the election and said, `We are going to raise fuel taxes and taxes on heavy fuel oil used for shipping from Tasmania, on credit unions and on superannuation'—
—Not to mention wine.

—And indeed wine. If Senator Coates had done that, he would not be sitting on that side of the chamber; he would be sitting on this side of the chamber. The reality is that his Prime Minister and senior ministers went around promising the Australian people that there would be no new taxes and no further increases in taxes. That was the impression that the Labor Party sought to create all through the election campaign.

PARA.TAB: One reason why the Keating government has no moral authority in this country is that the Australian people recognise that they were fooled. The credit unions and all those who use cars and public transport were fooled because of the new taxes. The wine industry was also fooled because it relied on the promises of Mr Keating. It has been a heavy lesson. Australians will never again trust the promises of Mr Keating, and correctly so.

Mr Keating has treated the Australian public with a cynicism which I do not believe we have seen before in this country. He won the election on the promise of no new taxes and then proceeded to apply a vast new range of taxes. It is no wonder that this government has no moral authority. The credit unions are paying the price that so many other people who are providing goods and services are paying in this country, because they believed Mr Keating's assurances.

A reading of the report's recommendations clearly shows just how flawed is this proposal to impose taxation on credit unions. The evidence before the committee shows that there are a great many unresolved and difficult issues. The committee brought down its report, pointing to the classic, major problem in relation to the small credit unions, which would have emerged had the government decided to consult with the people involved. The committee has addressed that issue and indicated to the government that amendments will have to be made to the legislation to remove the particular problems which relate to the small credit unions.

The matter goes further than that because the recommendations show a number of other serious issues that have to be addressed. How do we maintain the socially beneficial services of the credit unions? In imposing this tax, are we putting the credit unions at a seriously competitive disadvantage compared with other financial institutions, such as building societies, banks, and so on?

The committee has called on the government, before the 1994 budget, to examine these issues, take the time and decency to consult with the people who will be affected and to find out, after proper consideration, how these problems can be effectively addressed. The committee has identified that these are serious problems which the government clearly did not consider when it brought in the legislation.

The recommendations suggest that the government, in consultation with the representatives of financial institutions, should pay particular regard to the ways of removing possible inequities so that the cost of prudential supervision for the various types of financial institutions is met. The committee received a great deal of evidence on that issue. Again, it is a difficult problem to resolve in the context of a hearing. Nonetheless, it is important that further study be given to it to see whether the problem can be resolved.

The committee saw serious problems with the government's budget initiative of imposing this tax on credit unions. It has asked the government to go back and look at it again so that the problems which we heard in evidence before the committee can be appropriately considered out of the budget context and dealt with.

I think the inquiry was well conducted. I commend the people who gave evidence to the inquiry. They effectively drew to the attention of the committee some very real problems. In the time available, the committee was clearly unable to resolve those problems. But appropriately it has called on the government to look once again at this initiative so that the problems which should have been sorted out before the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) announced his budget do not recur. One Labor supporter described this budget as a defence of the indefensible; yet another described it as an act of bastardry.

There are real issues involved and the committee has pointed to them. My colleagues and I—and I hope, for a change, people on the Labor back benches—will look closely at these issues. After all, many Labor supporters are directly affected by this initiative. We know that if Mr Keating had kept his promises, we would not have this problem before this chamber today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I associate myself with the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. In all the hearings that our committee has held over the past few years that I have been a member, I believe this was probably one of the better attended and more vigorously argued ones.

PARA.TAB: The credit unions, building societies, banks and, specifically, as Senate Watson said during his remarks, people like Vince Martin and some of the other people who have a strong stake and personal commitment to this issue put forward their cases exceptionally well. I say that quite genuinely, not only in relation to Vince Martin and some of the other witnesses, but also to the credit unions whose representatives put forward their position exceptionally well.

One could sense the frustration in their evidence for the reason that Senator Kemp put forward. They had had no idea that the dark cloud of this tax was looming on the horizon. It was an absolute surprise to them when, on budget night, this new tax befell their industry. One can understand the anger and angst experienced by the credit unions during this period. I think it was a great credit to all their representatives that their evidence was put so sensibly and clearly and argued so well on Friday.

My colleagues have covered most of the points that need to be made in relation to the report. However, the $50,000 income cut-off exemption that the committee is strongly recommending for small credit unions—I call them small; the report calls them very small—is, in my opinion and that of my colleagues, a minimalist approach. It needs to be seen as a starting point.

Clearly, if the government accepts the strong recommendation of the committee, there need to be constructive and urgent consultations with the credit union industry, particularly the smaller credit unions, as to the most effective way of distinguishing in the tax system between small, medium and large credit unions. I urge the government and the Minister representing the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who has carriage of the legislation through this place, to seek those consultations as a matter of urgency. I urge them to conduct the consultation and constructive dialogue which was clearly missing before the budget.

Before the last federal election there was a great distinction between the approaches of the coalition and the government to matters of public policy. The coalition entered into one of the biggest dialogues and consultations in Australian political history over matters of tax policy. We discussed and debated quite publicly with just about every industry sector the approach we would take to taxation and how it would affect their industries. The government did not do any of that. The government had a secret agenda. It had a bottom-of-the-drawer tax policy which no-one knew about until budget night. Sitting in the Great Hall at the budget dinner, I was particularly horrified when I heard the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, announce many of these tax measures. I know that thousands and thousands of citizens across Australia were equally shocked.

The petition that the credit unions put together on this issue—I think in excess of a quarter of million people have signed the petition opposing this measure—is an indication of the anger that many people are feeling towards the government on these unannounced bottom-of-the-drawer tax policies that were thrust upon them on budget night without any notice or consultation.

I repeat my call that, if the government accepts the unanimous recommendation of our committee that the tax exemption be continued and phased in for smaller credit unions, there be some constructive consultation over the coming weeks to determine the right cut-off levels for the exemption.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit unusual for a minister to be involved in a discussion on the presentation of a report, but I want to make a few things clear. I thank members of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, including Senator Coates and other caucus colleagues, who contributed to the inquiry on this legislation that was announced on budget night.

PARA.TAB: It is a bit unusual to get a controversial speech on an agreed report. Normally one would have thought that such agreement would be the basis of some indication of desirability. But at least one senator could not resist the temptation to be provocative and confrontationist even about things with which he agreed. The fundamental predisposition to be provocative has unfortunately succeeded here, but only briefly.

The government did not have any difficulty with the concept of the very small credit union exemption to which the committee referred. I have not had a chance fully to examine the report because it has not been circulated—and I understand the production difficulties and the pressure to bring the report in quickly. However, I have had the opportunity quickly to peruse some of the indications. I cannot say absolutely that we will use the mechanism the committee has recommended with regard to the small credit union exemption. There may be another mechanism. But we do not have any difficulty with the concept. It is a matter that we have already been discussing and considering.

I note the committee's recommendations and suggest that the government is likely to be sympathetic to moves in that direction. Whether that is exactly what we do or not is a matter which will become clear when we get to the committee stage of the bill. I thank the committee for its contribution.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This bill proposes amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to increase the excise duty payable on tobacco, tobacco products and certain petroleum products as part of the package of deficit reduction measures announced by the Treasurer in his Budget speech and subsequently modified by the Government.

The proposed increases in duty on tobacco and tobacco products occur in five stages with a three per cent increase effective from midnight on 17 August 1993 and further rises of five per cent in February and August 1994 and February and August 1995. As well as providing an increase in revenue to assist reduction of the deficit, the increases in duty help address the government's concern about the social cost of smoking. The government considers that the proposed increases constitute a responsible measure.
The proposed increases in duty on petroleum products also occur in a number of stages.

Petroleum products presently subject to excise duty (with the exception of aviation fuels) are to be subject to an immediate increase in duty of three cents per litre. The duty on such products, other than leaded petrol, will rise by a further one cent per litre in February and August 1994.

The duty increases also encompass government initiatives to reduce the consumption of leaded petrol by providing that in February and August 1994 the duty on leaded petrol will increase by two cents per litre.

The duty increases will be cumulative. The new rate of duty on each occasion commencing in February 1994 will be determined by adding to the previous duty rate, any increase stemming from indexation based on movements in the consumer price index and the additional amount specified for the period.
Financial Impact Statement
The increases in the duty on tobacco and tobacco products are expected to result in increased duty collections (including customs duty) of $55 million in 1993/94 and $175 million in 1994/95.
The increases in duty on petroleum products are estimated to result in additional duty collections (including customs duty) of $790 million for 1993/94 and $1375 million for 1994/95.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present its accompanying Explanatory Memorandum.
