DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993[COGNATE BILL:EXCISE TARIFF (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993]

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —With the concurrence of the Senate, I suggest that the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 be debated cognately with the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate has before it the Custom Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. The purpose of both of these bills is to increase either customs duty or excise duty payable on tobacco, tobacco products and certain petroleum products. The increases will occur in stages according to formulae specified in the bills. While both bills refer to deficit reduction, I wish to stress to the Senate that there is no deficit reduction in the current year to 30 June 1994.

PARA.TAB: Many commentators have tried to blame the fragility of the value of the Australian dollar on the Senate's handling of the budget bills. A more correct assessment would be that the value of the Australian dollar is actually being affected by the lack of concern of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for the main economic worries of this country. Mr Keating appears to be preoccupied with non-mainstream economic issues such as the republic, the Australian flag and Mabo.

Of major concern to the coalition though is the effect of the increase in the fuel levy, as designated by these bills. On Friday, 30 September the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration heard from over a dozen different organisations that will bear the brunt of the regressive and poorly designed measures in the customs tariff and excise tariff deficit reduction bills.
In its submission to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, Nabalco, the large aluminium producer in the Northern Territory, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The new Budget impost cannot help but emphasise the heightened sovereign risk of investing in mining and mineral processing in Australia.

Overseas investor perceptions about the stability of investing in Australia will be further eroded by almost a doubling of the excise. Indeed, one could hardly blame Nabalco if it were to review its recently announced decision to establish the regional headquarters of its parent company in Sydney. The government is always telling us how it wants companies to make their Asian regional headquarters in Australia. This government is going the right way about putting everybody off side with discriminatory taxes like this one on fuel oil.

PARA.TAB: It is quite obvious that the consequences of the impact of the increase in the fuel levy had not been examined prior to the drafting of the legislation. Neither the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) nor the Minister for Tourism and Minister for Resources (Mr Lee) knew about it until it was announced—still less were they or their departments consulted.

Nabalco, the aluminium producer at Gove in the Northern Territory, is a case in point. As a heavy user of fuel oil, and with no recourse to the use of natural gas, the levy will add $25 million to the cost of its operation. Recently over $100 million was spent in reducing product costs there by $10 per tonne. This increase will raise costs by $15 per tonne and will make competition in a recessionary environment much more difficult.

When members of the committee asked whether or not the witnesses had taken into account the savings to be gained through the company income tax cuts, the unanimous verdict was that the excise tax increases far outweighed any advantage from the company tax rates. For example, in the case of Nabalco, its 70 per cent owner, Swiss Aluminium Australia Ltd, earned $4 million in 1992. The lower tax rate will save $200,000, whereas the increased cost of fuel is $25 million. The increase in the fuel levy alone will wipe out the benefits to Nabalco of a decade of hard won micro-economic reform in an important value adding industry.

I also put on record that during the committee hearings even the Minister for Science and Small Business, Senator Schacht, was surprised to find that about half the entire burden of the massive proposed increase in the fuel oil excise will fall on the single enterprise, the Nabalco joint venture. In fact, the minister referred to it as the `Nabalco tax'. This surprise is evidence of the small number of ministers who are dreaming up tax measures in the 1993 budget.

The fuel oil hits Nabalco much harder than any of its Australian competitors, all of whom have access to natural gas. Nabalco does not have a gas supply alternative. In Nabalco's view, the fuel oil duty must constitute one of the most offensive transgressions ever of the principle of non-discriminatory treatment in taxation. In 1968 in the Gove agreement the Commonwealth undertook to `use its best endeavours' not to impose discriminatory taxation on the project. There is little sign of any such endeavours in the present budgetary scene.

I am told that Nabalco has been trying to get in touch with government ministers ever since the budget was announced. To date there have been no replies, even though I am told that the Treasurer's office undertook to consult Nabalco further. Even Senator Collins has told this chamber more than once that the matter is under consideration. But there is no sign of any outcome of that consideration. We can conclude only that these ministers have lost heart and decided that it is all too hard for them. Similarly, we have no indication from the Australian Democrats about their position. All we hear from them is endless talk about leaded petrol. Do they care when a grossly discriminatory tax is imposed which puts a major question mark over an already uncertain investment climate in this country?

A minority report produced after the hearings by me and by my colleagues Senator Campbell and Senator Kemp showed that the bills have a number of flaws. The government, by a stroke of the pen, has imposed taxes that have completely offset the benefits of micro-economic reform in three areas—coastal shipping, road transport and industry productivity improvement measures.

The measures impose large, unexpected and highly discriminatory cost increases in particular industries, often after management and unions within those industries have made progress in enterprise bargaining and reform to work practices based on previously understood cost levels. As a consequence, the government is now appropriating to itself most or all the benefits of hard won efficiency gains in some industries, thus reducing an incentive to reform in the future.

This is best shown not only by the already mentioned Nabalco reforms, but also by the reforms that the government has achieved in the area of Australian coastal shipping under the auspices of the Shipping Industry Reform Authority between 1989 and 1992. That program saw a reduction in average crewing levels on Australian ships from 27.9 to 20.5. That is a 26.5 per cent reduction in manning costs over three years, and I acknowledge that that is a notable achievement.

Under the second and last stage of the reform program now under way, an agreement was reached with the maritime unions on 19 August 1993 to further reduce crewing levels to 19. This exceeds the target of 18.5 set by the government. This could save $270,000 per ship per annum and further reduce the cost of coastal shipping. But five days after this agreement with the unions, which was done under the auspices of the government, the budget increased the excise on marine fuel for ship propulsion. This equates to a total percentage increase of 92 per cent, an outrageous amount when compared with an increase of 18.8 per cent in excise on petroleum and automotive diesel fuels.

The increase in marine fuel excise will increase the fuel bill for an average coastal ship by $360,000 per annum, amounting to $16.1 million per annum across the whole of the Australian coastal shipping fleet. It needs to be noted that ships on international voyages do not pay the excise. Within five days of overseeing an agreement to reduce manning costs under its own shipping reform program, the government has not only completely wiped out those reform savings but has also added to shipping costs. That saving of $270,000 per ship per annum as a result of crew reductions has been countered by an immediate tax impost of $360,000 per annum per ship.

The finance and public administration committee hearing with respect to these bills heard that what might appear to be small increases in the absolute level of the cost of fuel will, in reality, have a disproportionately large percentage effect on the cost structures of some of the firms and the industries. The committee heard that it will cause serious regressive and inequitable effects between individuals on different levels of income and between different regions of Australia.

As a result there is a high likelihood that the fuel increase levy will increase unemployment. The National Farmers Federation reported that the well-known Orani general equilibrium model of the Australian economy suggests a possible increase of 30,000 in the level of unemployment. In particular, there will be a heavy cost burden imposed on inputs to exports and import substituting industries.

The National Farmers Federation advises that, in agriculture, the budget's increases in excise will impose costs of more than $70 million and will reduce net farm income by four per cent. In industries which are heavily dependent on transport, such as the northern cattle industry, where transport costs comprise about 15 per cent of farm costs, the effect will be even more pronounced.

The NFF further advises that, at a broader level, increasing fuel taxes in the Australian economy, which is geographically large and comprises a relatively high proportion of fuel intensive activities, will have disproportionate effects on the recovery of growth and employment. What is clear is that many of the worst effects were not taken into account by the government in the preparation of its budget.

My home state of Tasmania, in particular, will be seriously affected by the increase in the fuel excise. Let me outline a few of the effects on the mineral processing industries. A number of companies will be affected: for example, Savage River Mines, Comalco Aluminium at Bell Bay, Tasmanian Electro Metallurgical Co. Pty Ltd and Pasminco Metals-EZ are all heavy users of fuel oil.

The possible early closure of the Savage River iron ore mine and the loss of 300 jobs has been mooted. Savage River Mines has stated that the full impact of the fuel excise increase in 12 months will bring forward the planned 1997 closure of its open-cut mine to as soon as next year and will cause an underground expansion which may have prolonged the mine for another 10 years to be abandoned. The fuel excise will add $600,000 to direct operating costs to August 1994 and a further $840,000 from August 1994. Senators from Tasmania who do not oppose this measure carry a very heavy burden of responsibility. I refer particularly to Senators Murphy, Coates, Denman, Devereux, Sherry and Bell. They all carry a heavy responsibility for the problems in Tasmania arising from this iniquitous and regressive tax.

Comalco, in its submission to the Senate inquiry, expressed concern that unpredictable taxation behaviour by state or federal governments may affect the viability of a redeveloped smelting operation. The misguided excise increase on fuel oil by the federal government has sent the wrong message to Comalco. All major Tasmanian mines and mineral processors are dependent on coastal shipping for the import of production inputs from the mainland and the export of final products. The industry is responsible for about 44 per cent of tonnages shipped through Tasmanian ports.

Another 33 per cent of Australian coastal shipping task is used for the shipment of petroleum products and crude oil where the excise on fuel used by tankers adds to the cost of production and the cost of fuel. The overall result to the population of Tasmania will be that the goods carried on these ships will have to bear the costs. Therefore, it is expected that the extra fuel bill will inevitably flow through to freight costs. We are told that the average grocery bill in Tasmania will rise by a minimum of $3 a week.

Generally, the effect of the increased excise in marine fuel will reduce the competitiveness of Tasmanian industry in relation to both international and mainland producers, and thus further increase the loss of employment and the potential for new investment in Tasmania. Therefore, as the Tasmanian Chamber of Mines has submitted, along with the many other organisations who appeared before the committee, the fuel excise should not be increased on the grounds that it is patently unreasonable in itself. The increase is contrary to federal government policy of encouraging investment in value added export industries. Where is former Senator Button? We are missing him at present in terms of his call for value added industries. The increase will add severely to the international perception of sovereign risk associated with Australian investment.

The message is more severe and stronger the further one gets from the capital cities, because it is the remote and decentralised areas that will be affected most by this fuel excise. Not only is shipping affected by the fuel levy, but also representatives from the Road Transport Forum told the committee how transport will be affected. The forum stated that this increase negates the efficiency gains made by Australian unions and business over the last few years as Australian industry tries to become more competitive on the world stage. The tax will gravely impact on Australia's economic, road safety, social and environmental record.

The forum condemned the federal government's action as increasing the cost of providing jobs for Australians. This tax is contrary to the statements made by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in his budget speech on the need to make Australia more competitive and to remove what he said was the `tyranny

SPEECH.PARA: of distance'. In other words, we need to provide Australia with a cheap and efficient road transport system. It is only with a cheap and efficient non-urban road transport industry that regionally based industries and regional communities can afford to survive. With a cheap and efficient non-urban road transport industry, Australia can promote regional development. This is vital in developing decentralised value adding industries and, therefore, regional communities.

PARA.TAB: The application of this excise will increase diesel fuel costs for non-urban transport operations by $40 million for the balance of 1993-94 and by almost $90 million with the application of the full 5c per litre increase. It needs to be noted that every tonne of value added product from the farm to the finished product is moved by road. Every box of cereal, every litre of milk, every kilo of vegetables and every export product gets from the farm to the process factory, to the warehouse and to the retail outlet through the efforts of non-urban road transport operations.

Consequently, the coalition will be moving amendments with regard to the increase in the fuel levy. I will seek leave for two tables to be incorporated in Hansard which summarise our proposed amendments to be moved in the committee stage of the debate. In brief, we will be opposing the differential between leaded and unleaded gasoline; we will be opposing the increased excise on mineral turpentine; the differential between leaded and unleaded coal tar distillates; automotive diesel oil, industrial diesel fuel, marine diesel fuel, fuel oil, heating oil, lighting kerosene and power kerosene, the gasoline component of gasoline and ethanol blends as well as topped crude petroleum oil. There is also the excise tariff differential between leaded and unleaded gasoline. We will make similar changes to the excise tariff and the customs tariff legislation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a schedule of the items that will be affected as a result of our proposed amendments to the bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We could agree certainly with a few of the closing remarks made by Senator Watson in relation to developing alternative and newer industries, but we believe that what he has indicated is really looking in the wrong direction. As I will show during my speech on the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993, the government has a rare opportunity available to it, through the excise which it will collect on fuel, which it should grasp with both hands. It has the opportunity to develop an alternative fuel industry in this country, to remove the lead from petrol altogether and place Australia, once and for all, on the basis of a sustainable fuel for automotive transport.

PARA.TAB: Before I begin, let me observe that the fuel we are talking about is fossil fuel—fuel which, by its very nature, is non-renewable; fuel which was laid down many hundreds of millions of years ago as carbon in the atmosphere, removed from the atmosphere and secreted away in the form of coal and oil to give us the atmosphere that we enjoy today with a relatively higher oxygen content. We are, as everybody knows, progressively removing those fossil carbon deposits by burning them and putting them back in the atmosphere. Science tells us that this will have quite disastrous consequences for later generations in terms of the greenhouse effect, to say nothing of the effect on many other creatures, on our agricultural production, on the sea level and so on and so forth.

The government has frequently paid lip-service to the idea of sustainability. The government has also indicated that it is committed to the notion of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 20 per cent compared with 1988 by the year 2005. We have seen very little activity in this area. In the transport areas, in particular, we have seen no action whatsoever on the part of government. With the excise included in these bills, the government has an opportunity not only to make that transition, but also to find the money to make that transition possible.

The principle of sustainability means that future generations should have the same options available to them in relation to access to energy that this generation has. Clearly, by using up fossil fuel we are running counter to that principle of sustainability. The concern over greenhouse means that as far as possible we should be attempting to maintain an atmosphere for future generations which is not dissimilar to the atmosphere that we enjoy today and which the other between four million and 30 million creatures on this planet have become well adapted to.

The use of fossil fuel is also very polluting in other ways. The major source of air pollution in all our urban centres is the use of fossil fuel in private motor vehicles. In the case of Australia, which is not self-sufficient in its supply of fossil fuel for motor transport, we are importing $3.1 billion or more worth of petroleum each year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you taken it off what we export?

—To pick up Senator Panizza's interjection, if we can develop indigenous sources of fuel then of course we will be that much better off. As I will show, it is within our ability to provide those sources.

PARA.TAB: What I have said so far relates specifically to the actual fuel content of the petroleum material which we use. In addition, for many decades Australia has added lead to its petroleum. As we now know, lead is a disastrous component of the atmosphere, with particular reference to the intellectual and mental development of young children. The National Health and Medical Research Council, in a recent report, indicated that children are likely to lose some two to five points of intelligence quotient for every 10 micrograms per decilitre of lead in blood and that children in inner urban areas frequently have such high levels of lead that their intellectual and mental development will be retarded as a direct consequence of the lead that we add to our fuel.

Australia has by world standards extremely high levels of lead in its fuel, particularly in some of the country areas, but also in the urban areas. Compared with the US levels of lead of 0.026 grams per litre, Australia, with the minimum level of 0.3 grams per litre of lead, has well over 10 times the allowable level in the US, and yet that level of lead in the US is sufficient to provide the valve protection properties which have been discovered for lead. Ninety per cent of the urban air pollution with lead comes from the use of lead in petrol. So we have a serious problem.

The government has tackled this problem by introducing a price differential between leaded and unleaded fuel, which initially will be 1c and which in August next year will go to 2c. We support that price differential, but we say to the government that in introducing that differential it has only done half the job. Some 55 per cent of all the petroleum used in Australia by private motor vehicle operators at present is leaded fuel.

We know that there is a proportion of cars which requires a higher octane fuel. At this stage that proportion seems to be unknown. I am distressed by the inability of state motor vehicle registration authorities to provide figures as to the makes and models of cars which require a higher octane fuel. Given that fact, it is not possible to say how much of that 55 per cent of motor vehicles using leaded fuel at the moment require a fuel of higher octane and how many would be able to immediately switch to unleaded fuel. It is thought that perhaps some 25 per cent of vehicles in Australia would be of a make and model which would require a higher octane than the 92 octane unleaded fuel.

The imposition of a 2c differential will be sufficient to cause—and all the evidence indicates that it is the case—those who are currently using leaded fuel but whose cars can equally use unleaded fuel to shift to unleaded fuel. That will substantially reduce the amount of lead in the atmosphere. But to leave the situation at that point is to do only half the job. Those people who are driving the older cars—because all cars post-1986 are mandated to use unleaded fuel—are most likely to be the people less able to upgrade to a newer car or a new car so that they can use unleaded fuel. They are likely to require the use of those vehicles and, with the government program as it is, the government is providing no light at the end of the tunnel, no solution to the problem of these people continuing to use leaded fuel, no solution to the continuing problem of air pollution in our cities, with the large amounts of lead in the atmosphere because of the high concentration of lead in Australian fuels. The government needs to do more than simply put 2c on leaded fuel.

The Democrats are seeking from the government a substantial boost to an indigenous fuel industry which will simultaneously solve the problem of lead in petrol and give us an indigenous source of fuel that will help to address the problem of fuel imports. This will provide us with another industry which, particularly in regional centres, will provide employment. It will provide farmers with another source of income, another source of sale of many products. It will establish new technology which will help Australia in many other ways. This is precisely the industry which other countries have developed, that is, the industry of using alcohol as a mixture in petroleum.

The so-called gasohol mix is in wide use in the States. Eight to nine per cent of all the fuel used in America is alcohol petroleum mixes. It is used extensively in many other countries. Brazil has gone all the way and has cars running entirely on alcohol. Alcohol by its very nature, used in an internal combustion engine, adds no greenhouse gas whatsoever to the atmosphere. The carbon dioxide which is taken up by plants making the sugars is precisely the same carbon dioxide which is released when that fuel is burnt in an internal combustion engine. Ten per cent alcohol in petrol, which is the standard mix, adds three numbers of octane to the fuel. So 92 octane unleaded with 10 per cent alcohol added to it would be 95 octane petrol, which would be usable in not all but most of the cars on the road which currently use leaded fuel and which require that higher octane.

It also has the advantage that, being a fuel derived from the fermentation of plant material, it can eminently be developed in Australia. We already have a plant at Manildra near Nowra in New South Wales, which is providing gasohol to 23 service stations in New South Wales—23 service stations supplying gasohol for private motorists without any complaints whatsoever regarding the use of this fuel. Manildra currently provides some 50,000 litres of alcohol per day, 5,000 litres of which goes into gasohol. That amount can be substantially expanded, given the right incentive.

That is the key to the Democrats' position on this. The solution to the problem of lead pollution in our cities is partly the price differential. The other part of the solution to the problem is to provide an alternative. Alcohol as a fuel additive is a proven alternative. We seek from the government a substantial bounty scheme paid out of the revenue which it will derive from this 1c and then 2c

SPEECH.PARA: additional excise on leaded fuel to encourage this industry which can be very rapidly expanded right around Australia.

The advantages of such a program are that ethanol is a renewable fuel. Its use will reduce greenhouse gas emissions directly. The 10 per cent of alcohol which would be used in the fuel will add nothing at all to the greenhouse gas emissions. Once this industry is established and as production exceeds the demand to replace lead in fuel the product can replace petroleum in the rest of the fuel supply. Given that, one can progressively change our demand from petroleum fuel to ethanol fuel for transport.

I remark in passing that ethanol has also been used in a mixture with diesel fuel. Several buses in this city are running on a mixture of 15 per cent alcohol in diesel, so-called diesohol. Buses are also running in Sydney on the same mix. Farm machinery and a whole fleet of trucks are running on the same mix. The vehicle which won the recent greenhouse trials was an unmodified heavy duty vehicle running on 15 per cent alcohol in diesel. It beat, by 25 per cent, the greenhouse emissions of a heavily modified heavy duty vehicle running on compressed natural gas.

The use of ethanol also reduces emissions of other pollutants from internal combustion engines—carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxides—because the engine runs a great deal cooler. The same applies to diesel engines. As I said, it reduces our need for imported fuel, thus reducing our trade deficit, it increases our independence and, particularly in the farming area, it provides a large number of industries in regional centres which can be based on wastes from farming production. Therefore, it increases regional employment and generates new technology.

On this particular point let me say, lest I be misunderstood, that I am not looking to a long-term fuel alcohol industry based on substituting production of grains and so on for alcohol production for the production of foods for human consumption. The technology which is currently being developed in Australia based on the use of cellulose materials for alcohol production is indeed a very exciting technology. It means that waste material such as straw, sawdust, paper and small thinnings from tree lots—a whole array of materials—can be fermented to alcohol for fuel. The cost of alcohol under such conditions would be very competitive with petrol, as it is at present. That greatly expands the availability of alcohol as a renewable indigenous fuel which in no way will compete with food production—in fact, in many cases it will actually complement it—and will provide farmers with an alternative source of income.

We have negotiated with the government for a halving of the increase which was originally mooted. We are supporting those increases as they are now on the grounds that we are talking about a non-renewable polluting fuel. For those reasons we believe that fuel prices should rise. In parenthesis, let me note that Australia's price for petrol is the third lowest, and we have the second lowest rate of excise of all 24 OECD countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —You keep forgetting that we have the biggest distances, too.

—I thank Senator Ferguson for that point. We are concerned about the prices of petrol for country users. My colleague Senator Woodley will pick this up. The state government in South Australia has for some time had in place a fuel transport subsidy scheme which, nonetheless, still results in petrol prices in country areas being quite a lot higher than in city areas. We believe that there should be an inquiry into that differential so that country people pay exactly the same price as city people.
—Is that part of your negotiations?

—That certainly has been part of our negotiations. Of course, it does not fall neatly within the purview of this legislation. The main point that I wish to stress is that the government must come to the party on solving the problem of lead in petrol and not simply slug those people who are unfortunate enough to have the older cars which need higher octane.

PARA.TAB: Mr Acting Deputy President, I saw you speaking to the clerk earlier. I do not know whether it was about the incorporation of graphs, but I have incorporated graphs previously in Hansard.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—It was just a suggestion to me that the incorporation is approved as long as Hansard can accommodate it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has previously.

—I rise to speak on the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 before the chamber at present. Senator Coulter said the issue was how to reduce lead. I do not deny that that is an issue. I think we have, over a number of years, had varying degrees of effectiveness in addressing that issue. It is a real issue. But I think the real issues that we have before this chamber are: how can we create jobs in Australia; how can we make our industry more efficient; and how can we increase the household disposable incomes of Australian families? Those are the sorts of issues which are really before this chamber and which are intimately tied up with the customs and excise bills which we are debating, particularly with the increases in fuel taxes.

PARA.TAB: Before any comment is made on the detail of the legislation before us, I think the chamber has to remind itself about the whole question of ethics, honesty and mandates in government. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would be aware, as indeed would every senator, that during the election campaign—this has been said before in this chamber today—the promise was that there would be no new taxes. You would be aware that for about 12 months, as the debate raged before and after the election, Mr Keating said that he could deliver all his tax cuts without putting up taxes. Just to take one example, Mr Keating said that the incidence of tax would not rise; he said, `What I'm promising is not to put up tax'. That is a very clear promise.

If there is any dispute about the policy of the Labor government leading up to the election and during the election campaign, I wonder whether any Labor senator could stand up in this chamber and say, `We would have won the election had we revealed that we were going to raise taxes across the broad range of the Australian economy—all wholesale sales taxes up, fuel taxes up, wine taxes up and credit unions will be taxed'. I suggest to Senator Loosley or Senator Carr, who may speak on this, that when they stand up—and we are being broadcast today—they should indicate to the Australian people, to the chamber and to the people in the gallery whether they believe that the election gave them a clear mandate to carry out these policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —We left the tax promises to you, Senator.

—Labor did win the election, and honourable senators on the other side have spent a lot of time saying, `We won the election'. But I wonder whether there has ever been an election where the moral authority of the government has been so compromised in such a short period after winning it. A lot of hassling and complaining has been heard from Labor ministers in this chamber and in the House of Representatives about the problems the Senate is causing. My view is that the Senate is attempting to at least mitigate the savage damage that this budget will cause to Australian industry and families.

PARA.TAB: But another important element to the debate is that this chamber has a mandate to keep governments honest. If the government wins an election having promised that it will not increase taxes, I think it is reasonable, when it introduces bills to massively raise taxes, that this chamber should look very carefully at such legislation. The bills before us will raise in the order of $1.4 billion. The excise increase on fuel is very big bickies. It is a very savage impost.

Ross Gittins, in the Sydney Morning Herald, assessed the impact on Australian families of both the Fightback package and the package that Mr Keating presented in his first budget after the election. The article was headed, `Keating's taxes are worse than the GST'. Mr Gittins came to this conclusion by saying that the net indirect tax effect of the Fightback package by increasing indirect taxes after the removal of whole host of indirect taxes was $2 billion, whereas the taxes in the Keating budget will have the ultimate effect of raising indirect taxes by some $3 billion. Mr Gittins came to the conclusion that this package was, in fact, worse than the GST. He pointed out that, unlike the Hewson package at the election, there was no compensation element brought forward.

We have before this chamber a massive item of revenue raising—in the order of $1.4 billion. One of the issues that came out of the election campaign and which I think is now more clearly understood by the Australian people is that when taxes on things such as fuel and inputs to business are raised, business is adversely affected and those costs are fed through to every good and service which is produced and sold in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a consumption tax.

—In a sense, it is a dishonest form of a consumption tax because there is no item transported around the nation—food, clothing and babies' products; I mention those as Senator Crowley is in the chamber and she is concerned with issues of child care and the effects on young families—which will not be affected by the taxation measures before the chamber. Equally, there is barely a service delivered in this country that will not also be affected by these taxes. This is all from a government that promised that there would be no new taxes, to use Mr Keating's words.

PARA.TAB: I think it has become clear from the evidence that was given to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration that, when one looks across whole sectors of the Australian economy, the effect of these taxes on industry is quite dramatic. We heard evidence from the Road Transport Forum, the National Transport Federation, the Australian Automobile Association, the Australian Bus and Coach Association, the Australian National Maritime Association, the Mining Industry Council and the National Farmers Federation, to mention a few. They all came and showed the committee the effect that these taxes will have on their particular sectors.

It is not surprising that when taxes are raised it increases the costs of doing business, it makes Australian industry less competitive with imports and makes it more difficult for Australian industry to export. All of that is, of course, entirely predictable. What I do not think was well understood when these taxes came in was just how savage the effect on particular sectors could be.

For example, Mr Payne of the national maritime industry presented evidence to the committee which was really quite traumatic. The coastal shipping industry is a major transporter of goods, services and minerals around the coast of Australia. Quite rightly, because of the inefficiencies in this sector, there has been a major effort by the government to bring about cost reductions in the industry, well recognising that it is going to be very difficult for Australia to compete if our shipping sector is not efficient.

After a number of years of great effort, negotiations and what have you, the government very recently announced agreements with the unions to remove a further 2.46 berths from the average Australian ship. It may not seem enormously dramatic, but the cost savings of that particular agreement totalled $270,000 per annum per vessel. Translated into cost savings, that was quite a dramatic saving. But within days of the budget being announced, Mr Keating's new taxes—the hidden taxes, the secret agenda, the taxes in the bottom drawer, as Senator Campbell said—were pulled out. The excise on heavy fuel taxes would increase the average cost of running a vessel by $358,000 per annum. After all these negotiations with the unions, the industry saves $270,000, yet the following day the government whacks on massive increases in heavy fuel taxes so that, even after the savings, it costs $358,000 to run the same ship. So all of those micro reforms are all wiped out by this particular tax.

It was no wonder that the mining industry made, I thought, a very important submission that highlighted to the committee the savage effect on that sector. It will cost more to ship iron ore from Western Australia to New South Wales steelworks, inflating the cost of steel on both domestic and international markets. Those that work in the great steelworks of Australia will find, again, the security of their jobs in that sector put at even more risk. Domestic steel products will be more expensive in many states—great for our exports! There will be an increase in the shipping costs to process manganese from the Northern Territory into ferromanganese at the BHP plant in north-eastern Tasmania. Again, great for that sector of the industry!

We saw the farming industry produce another series of statistics. The farming industry believes that the effect of these taxes on its sector will be quite dramatic and will raise very substantially the cost of farming. Mr Goucher from the National Farmers Federation pointed out to the committee that it would add to the operating cost of the farming sector by $50 million a year. This is at a time when the farming sector is struggling, when commodity prices are at an all-time low and when our wool producers are finding savage reductions in prices. What happens? The government whacks on another series of taxes which will have a further impact on the farming sector. We received submissions from the Australian Bus and Coach Association pointing out to us the savage effects these taxes will have on that sector.

One of the issues which came up during the hearings was that, because of the problems which were emerging, Senator Schacht, who was at the hearing, undertook to help arrange meetings for a variety of people who came before the committee so that they could present their particular problems to the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, to see whether any particular measures could be taken to address these particular problems. I am sorry to hear what my colleague Senator Watson said. He mentioned that the representatives from Nabalco had not, I understand, been able to arrange a meeting.

Members of the National Transport Federation indicated to the committee that the impact of the extra fuel taxes on running an average truck, a long haulier, would be in the order of an extra $5,000 a year—quite a dramatic cost to people running a small business, running a truck, trying to make a buck for their families and trying to build up their business. In the midst of these very difficult times, Mr Keating and his colleagues are going to slap on another tax costing these people another $5,000.

Mr Gaynor presented strong evidence to the committee. He sought meetings with Senator Schacht. I have to report to the Senate that those meetings have not taken place. That is a great pity. Mr Gaynor also sought meetings with the Australian Democrats. Unfortunately he was not able to put to them the case of his particular sector. It is a pity that people who have very real concern about the future of their industry and future employment in their industry are not given a hearing.

Senator Spindler has told us that we have to protect Australian jobs. We all agree with that. He wants to raise tariffs on Australian industry. Senator Kernot wants to rush this budget through so that we can have what she sees as greater security, again to help build confidence and employment in the Australian economy. In the past the Democrats have proposed a jobs levy to try to increase employment.

At a time when taxes on Australian industry have been raised to the extent that they have in this budget, I would have thought that the people who stand up in this chamber and talk so much about jobs—and I do not disparage that, because it is important that the Senate address its mind to jobs—would have been prepared to meet with the people who are employing people who are out there trying to make a quid. I hope that, as this debate continues, in the very near future the Australian Democrats will have a chance to meet with the Paul Gaynors of this world, as well as the National Transport Federation and other sectors of industry that wish to draw attention to their particular concerns.

For example, one of the views that the National Transport Federation put to the committee was that, if there were an exemption granted to fuel excise used in long haul road transports, the cost would be in the order of $80 million. That is the federation's figure. That is, of course, a very similar figure to the cost of the extra tax that was raised on the wine industry. Whether the government or the Democrats would be prepared to support such an exemption, I do not know. Our policy is not to support any of these taxes, and we shall be voting against these taxes in this chamber.

I would have thought that, where people have a very real case to put—the Greens and the Democrats—they will be given a fair hearing to put their particular views. All of us agree that there is a bipartisan policy on the need to increase employment in this country. It is so obvious, it beggars belief that it has to be restated in this chamber. If we put extra taxes on Australian industry, it will cost jobs. Every model that has ever been produced shows that. It is a great pity that the savage taxes that are encompassed in these bills—taxes amounting to over $1.4 billion—will, to a large extent, be paid by Australian industry. The cost of those taxes will feed through into all goods and services that Australian families purchase.

The issue here is one of honesty in government. It is a very big issue. I think it is important that the Australian people recognise that, of all the promises made and broken by this government, these bills are just about the most expensive.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's the big one.
—As my colleague said, it is the big one. Therefore, it is very fitting that the coalition parties will be opposing these bills.

PARA.TAB: But, apart from honesty in government—of which I think there is far too little, certainly in Canberra today—there are the issues of what is best for employment, what is best for jobs and what is best for Australian industry. On all those tests these bills fail. They fail Australia. That is why my colleagues and I on this side of the chamber will be opposing the increases in fuel prices which are contained in the bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has proposed a substantial tax increase of 5c to 7c per litre on the price of petrol. This will fuel inflation both directly through higher cost of living and indirectly through being added at every transport stage in the production and marketing system. This comes on top of an inflationary and inequitable increase in wholesale sales tax. The only justification for supporting these bills is that they are liable to have a favourable effect on the environment through reducing car use. It is only because of that aspect that we support them.

PARA.TAB: In environmental terms, the effects of these bills are virtually accidental. They have the crudest market impact. The lead differential is not even a proper pollution tax which would tax lead in petrol, rather than leaded petrol, giving a competitive advantage to manufacturers who produce cleaner products.

Australia has one of the highest per capita uses of petrol in the world but, unlike the United States and Canada, we are making no efforts to reduce this. We support strict guidelines for reducing greenhouse gases but do nothing about the major source of such gases here—the transport sector.

The transport component of the lead problem we currently face is a direct result of such inaction. Internationally there was a push for cars with engines that use unleaded fuel that led to legislation forbidding lead petrol engines in the United States in 1974. It was another 11 years before unleaded petrol was even available in Australia. There has been a similar push for strict standards of other emissions and overall fuel efficiency. By 1998 many states in the United States and the European Community will have in place emission standards up to 10 times stricter than ours.

The major means of reducing emissions and greenhouse gases from the transport sector is clearly a shift away from car dependent urban design and towards cities in which services and frequent reliable public transport are readily available. By no accident, this was the finding of the government's own ecologically sustainable development transport working group. Not only is this the way to reduce environmental and public health damage; it is the means by which equity can be developed. Yet the government will cut funding for urban development and public transport from last year's $1,200 million to $200 million in 1996-97. This year state programs will be cut from $1.5 billion to $1 billion. Meanwhile, the government is trying to raise $1.3 billion in revenue from petrol and leaded petrol.

I foreshadow an amendment which seeks to tie the government to some measure of real action on the environmental and equity issues. It seeks three things: firstly, to tie the government to measures in lead abatement, upon which it says it already has received industry agreement; secondly, to ensure that manufacturers who are producing vehicles using clean technology for other nations cannot dump older and dirtier vehicles on the Australian public; and, thirdly, to ensure that the government implements its own policies regarding the creation of better, cleaner, safer and fairer cities and to ensure that there is funding provided for this.

The economic impact of funding on the ecologically sustainable cities program at 1c per litre on petroleum products would be only $160 million. This is a small portion, only 10 per cent, of the cuts currently flagged for similar existing programs over the next four years. The other measures are revenue neutral.

The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has reported that she already has state and industry agreement to reduce lead levels in petrol to 0.2 per cent by 1995. The change in the Australian Design Rules standard simply demands that a manufacturer making clean efficient cars provides similar cars for sale here. We are asking that the government puts its words into action.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address my comments specifically to the effect the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 will have on the far north region of Western Australia, particularly the Kimberley and the Pilbara region. Of course an extra tax on transport will adversely affect remote areas. Mr Acting Deputy President, I know that in your home state of South Australia you have a lot of remote areas that will also be adversely affected. I am sure my colleague Senator Ferguson will refer to that later in the debate. I will address the issue of regressivity and its effect on low income earners and also the impact on the economy and the environment.

PARA.TAB: The effect on remote areas will perhaps be felt more in my state of Western Australia than in any other state in the federation. I want to alert the Senate to the fact that the increases in fuel prices and bulk fuel prices which will come as a consequence of these measures, combined with the increase in wholesale sales taxes on long distance road transport, will have an incredibly regressive effect, particularly on areas in the far north of Western Australia.

On 5 December 1991, former Senator Peter Walsh asked former Senator Button a question in relation to the effect of the proposed goods and services tax on prices in remote areas. If I read the Hansard correctly, I note that Senator O'Chee was interjecting quite a lot during the answer. Senator Walsh tried to draw the conclusion that the GST would have a regressive effect on freight charges. In fact, Senator Walsh had it wrong—the GST policy would have massively reduced the burden.

Later that month, on 19 December, I asked former Senator Button a question which was based on a leaked document dated 26 November 1991 from the caucus economic industrial relations committee. I asked specifically what that caucus committee had been advised in relation to the effects of the wholesale sales tax on road transport. In December 1991, in answer to Senator Walsh, Senator Button said that the impact of the WST, the wholesale sales tax, was about two per cent—in fact, it was 2.8 per cent. The Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics had provided to that back bench Labor Party committee, then chaired by Ric Charlesworth, an analysis which showed that the effect on a two-axle rigid truck was about two per cent, the effect on a large articulated truck was 3.8 per cent, and the effect on a triple road train was 4.5 per cent.

Most of us know that in a state like Western Australia particularly—and, I guess, Queensland and South Australia—most of the major grocery items and so forth that are transported around, particularly to places such as Karratha, Kununurra and the mining communities in the far north of Western Australia, travel on large trucks, semi-trailers and the like. Therefore, the effect of the wholesale sales tax increases is quite significant.

I do not need to repeat the arguments that have already been quite succinctly put by the Road Transport Forum and circulated to honourable senators. The increase in wholesale sales tax will have a very deleterious effect on the purchasing power of people's wages in the north of Western Australia and other remote areas of Australia. When we put on top of it the fuel tax increases that are a part of the bills before us tonight, we have an even worse effect. I will speak later about the regressive nature of that increase as it affects not only people in metropolitan areas but also, increasingly, people who live in the far north. Whether this government knows it or not, there are a lot of low income earners who go to remote areas of Australia to try to progress their living standards, to get ahead and to earn bigger money. They live in low income circumstances and they have to pay these much higher prices.

I want to draw to the Senate's attention a table I have prepared from a survey my office conducted on 18 August, the day after the budget. We looked at what the effect of the price hike of 7c a litre on leaded fuel would mean to some of my constituents in remote areas. For example, we looked at the town of Exmouth, in the north of Western Australia, which is where—as many honourable senators, and certainly Senator Chris Evans, who is from Western Australia, will know—the Harold E. Holt communications base was located. The price people in that town pay for leaded fuel at the moment is 86.5c a litre—some 16c a litre more than people would pay in the metropolitan area. After Labor's 7c a litre tax slug, the price will rise to 93.5c a litre—nearly $1 a litre. That is an enormous price for anyone to pay. There are many low income earners living in Exmouth and seeking work either in the fishing industry or at the communications centre. These low income earners have to pay this most regressive tax.

My constituents in Kalgoorlie are currently paying roughly 10c a litre more than we pay in the metropolitan area. They will be slugged an extra 7c a litre for leaded petrol. In Kalgoorlie the price will go up to something like 83c a litre. In Southern Cross, where Senator Panizza, the opposition deputy whip, comes from, the price will go up to 83c a litre. In Carnarvon, it will go up to 85c a litre; Kununurra, 81c a litre; Esperance, in the south of the state, just near where Senator Crane comes from, 78c a litre. By comparison, people in the metropolitan area get off relatively easily. At the moment, on average, we are paying roughly 70c a litre. The price will go up to 77c a litre.

This tax is a massive increase. It will not affect those of us who are on reliable salaries, be we public servants or politicians or other people on middle to high incomes; the people it will affect the most are those on low incomes who have to scrape together the money to put fuel in their cars just to go down to the local grocery store to buy their groceries.

The other effect will be on the transportation to remote areas of groceries, newspapers and all of the daily requirements of life. The price of all of those things will go up quite a lot. The Road Transport Forum has estimated that the increase will be between $2 and $3 a trolley load of groceries in the metropolitan area. This will be much higher in places such as Kununurra and Exmouth that are a long way from the metropolitan area.

The other effect that the increase will have on my state of Western Australia is in curtailing development in remote areas. There are enormous risks associated with developing new projects, be they mining projects, tourism projects or even pastoral or agriculture projects, a long way from the metropolitan area. Everything has to be put on a ship or a train, if a train is available—they are not available in most parts of northern Western Australia—or transported by heavy haulage on the roads. The cost of transport to those areas will be increased. Those people looking at developing new tourism facilities—and there are a number going on in northern Western Australia at the moment—who have not already been stopped by the uncertainty created by the High Court's Mabo ruling now face this extra hike associated with fuel increases.

Another good example in Western Australia is the expansion of agricultural activities in the Ord River scheme. This is something that the Western Australian Court government is keen to expand and another thing which will be made that much harder and that much less feasible if the price of taking goods and service to the region by transport is increased by this iniquitous tax hike.

It is a tax hike which, as Senator Kemp has already pointed out to the Senate this evening, was hidden from the Australian taxpayers. We did not hear Senator Chris Evans going around Western Australia, moving up through the north-west region, doorknocking and saying, `Elect us because we will put 7c a litre on your petrol price'. I was in the town of Newman the day after Senator Beahan was there because I found his business card stuck in a few doors that I knocked on; I did not hear any reports from the fine people of Newman that Senator Beahan had been knocking on their door saying, `We will increase your petrol price by 7c a litre'. The government did not do that because it knew the people did not want it. That is not what the people voted for. Senator Kemp has covered that and I will try to restrain myself from repeating the anger of those many Australians who feel totally betrayed by this government and its lack of honesty with the people.

The other important matter which Senator Kemp referred to was the effect that these taxes will have on employment generating economic growth. Australia's most important economic and social problem at the moment is that we have more than one million people either out of work or not working to their full capacity. Long term unemployment is an enormous problem which is having terrible effects not only on suicide rates and family breakdowns but also mostly on our economic capacity as a nation. We cannot have one million people out of work and at the same time have maximum economic growth occurring. This does have environmental consequences which I will refer to a little later.

One of the crucial problems with this taxing measure is that it will adversely affect our international competitiveness. It will affect the input costs of our businesses, the input costs of waterfront and shipping and the input costs of everything that gets moved around Australia—every single transport and service. When this measure was announced I gave notice of a motion in this place calling it the hidden GST. It is a goods and services tax because it increases the cost of every single good and service in this nation.

The difference with this GST—Keating's GST; the hidden wholesale sales tax and tax on fuel—is that no-one gets any compensation for it. It increases the cost of consumer goods and groceries and so forth but, more importantly, in the long term, it increases the cost of everything we produce in this country and it makes things that much harder to sell competitively on the international market. We have heard from industry associations that all of the cost advantages we have got from the waterfront reform and shipping reform which Senator Collins has told us about month in and month out for years and years in this place have been wiped out by the stroke of one budget pen with these massive increases in the cost of transporting things around our shores.

Here we are trying to compete internationally. A small country like New Zealand just across the Tasman is performing very well in the micro-economic reform area. We have given ourselves another international competitive disadvantage over our cousins across the Tasman. New Zealand's shipping and its transport sector will be that much more competitive than Australia's. It is a nation which Australia hates being beaten by, be it in cricket, rugby, yachting or any other field of endeavour—probably even bobsledding, I say to the National Party Whip. We hate being beaten by the Kiwis when it comes to sport or any other field of endeavour. But when it comes to the reform of our economy, when it comes to increasing people's individual liberty, to increasing people's economic freedom, to increasing competition and choice, the Kiwis are beating us hands down. Week in and week out they are beating us on the waterfront, in shipping, in transport and in telecommunications. All of these areas are vital to our living standards, particularly those of low income earners and of so many young and middle aged Australians who have no hope of getting work at the moment.

This is a crucial aspect of increasing taxes on the productive sector and increasing taxes on business. If we keep doing this we keep diminishing the opportunities to export Australian products and services and to create more jobs. It is really perplexing that Mr Dawkins, Mr Keating and the Labor Party have gone down the path of increasing these taxes on the productive sector, on enterprise, on the very sector that has the ability to create the growth that will get rid of the unemployment problem.

The last area I want to cover in this address is the environment. It was quickly covered by Senator Kemp. The important parallel was drawn between fixing environmental problems and creating economic growth. We cannot afford as a nation to give the environment proper protection if we do not have a strong and growing economy. There is no better proof of this than this sort of legislation.

This morning I received a letter relating to the wine tax from Michael Wright, a constituent of mine, who is the proprietor of Voyager Estate, a winery in Western Australia. Mr Wright took the opportunity in that letter to raise a few other issues of national importance. I thank him for taking the trouble to do so. He drew to my attention the fact that in 1986, when unleaded fuel was introduced to the market in Australia, the average life of a car was something like five years. We have now increased the tax on leaded petrol as a further incentive for people to move to unleaded petrol—at least that is what the Treasurer would have us believe. Not even the Greens believe that line.

Mr Wright continued to say in his letter that the idea was that if cars lasted, on average, five years, within a decade or so there would be very few cars using leaded petrol. Now with the state of the economy and the state of the sales tax system and the petrol taxes and the general anti-business, anti-expansion policies which this government seems to be pursuing, the average length of time that motor vehicles are on our roads has extended to nine years. We now have more lead petrol burning cars on the road than we should have. If we had a better economy with a better tax regime we would have more economically fuel efficient cars on the road.

Senator Margetts in addressing her amendments said that the Greens did not want to see economically inefficient cars dumped on the Australian market. It was not that long ago that we had the debate about the imported Japanese cars. Most Australians will be put off by the concept of getting hand-me-down, second-hand vehicles from Japan. But the cars we were talking about in that debate last year were cars that had a far better fuel efficiency and a lower rate of greenhouse gas emission than many of the cars in Australia, particularly those cars that burn lead fuel. They were all unleaded vehicles with great fuel emission standards.

When Mr Dawkins first announced this regime of unleaded and leaded fuel taxing in which there was a 10c slug on leaded petrol, his opening shot with the Greens and the Democrats was to reconsider the $12,000 import duty that was applied to imported Japanese cars. He said to the Greens, to the Democrats and to anyone else in Australia who wanted to listen that he would review whether or not he would let in all these Japanese cars. Only a year or so ago Senator Button was saying he would put on a $12,000 tax; if they still came in, he would double the tax. He would do anything to stop those Japanese cars from coming in. In the pressure of budget night when Mr Dawkins, the Treasurer, thought his budget might come unstuck, he let all those cars in again to achieve the environmental standards that the Greens are, I am sure, very genuinely concerned about.

I conclude by reiterating the point that if we want to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from motor vehicle fleets—there are a lot of other sources of greenhouse gas emissions—we need to have a strong and growing economy where average Australians can afford to go out and buy a new car that has a much higher standard in respect of emissions than the car they are driving at the moment. At present there are very few Australians who have the faith in the economy or the income to go and buy themselves a new car. It is a chicken and egg situation. But we do not encourage environmental standards to be increased by slugging the productive sector of the economy. I am opposed to these bills. I am opposed to the concept of taxing the productive sector in this manner. I look forward to joining my colleagues in voting these bills down when the question is put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 form part of what is arguably the worst budget that the Labor government has delivered. Senator Campbell highlighted most of the areas where this government is slugging the persons who use fuel. I suppose that saying that this is the worst budget that the Labor government has ever delivered is a rather bold statement. Given the wide selection of awful budgets and inappropriate legislation that has been the hallmark of the Keating ministry, I suppose that is really something.

PARA.TAB: Yet again we have a set of bills before us on which the minister and his department have not done their homework. If they had they would know how iniquitous, inappropriate and unnecessary these increases are. In speaking to the bills, I want to highlight the fuel tax increases because I regard them as the most iniquitous, inappropriate and unnecessary. They are iniquitous because they hurt most of those least able to afford them. In their original form, the fuel increases would have been especially unfair on those forced to drive older cars using leaded petrol.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is supposed to represent the people of Bankstown and Canterbury—and I suppose he gets there at least once before an election. A survey reported in the Sydney Morning Herald showed that 62 per cent of all Canterbury motorists use leaded petrol while 43 per cent of motorists in Woollahra, Mr Keating's preferred neighbourhood, use leaded petrol. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald is headed `ALP's petrol tax hits the true believers'. And well it does; it hits the people who can least afford to have another tax imposed on them.

The legislation is unfair and the government has been more than a little unfair and more than a little iniquitous in masking the intent of the legislation. Why would people want to go into business if they get slugged every time they want to have a go and produce something or get their exports off-shore? This is another example of anti-business legislation that will hurt the people who produce our export incomes.

As far as this fuel tax is concerned, we had an environmental summit where the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Mrs Kelly, highlighted the damage that leaded petrol was causing the community. The government then claimed that the legislation was intended to protect the environment. Not even the environmental movement swallowed that line of argument. We on this side of the chamber and the environment movement know that this legislation and the other tax measures are all about an unbalanced budget, unfunded electoral promises and unfunded tax cuts. We all remember the election campaign, when so many promises were made by Mr Keating and those opposite. They have not been able to keep them because they did not prepare for them and did not know what they were going to do if they ever won the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Peter Walsh did not think they could win.

—That is correct. Faced with the prospect of being caught out with its intent for these bills and faced with a revolt from its back bench, the government abandoned the environmental line and said, `Well, perhaps leaded fuel is not such a problem for now'. So the additional levy on leaded fuel was abandoned and the rates are now as we see them in this legislation. But that has not removed the inequity; it just means that everyone is unfairly hit equally. It is slugging the people who produce export income—the transport industry, farmers and mining companies; the list is endless.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration heard from 14 organisations a couple of weeks ago. Those 14 organisations and industry groups said the same thing—the legislation is unfair and their industries will be hit hard. There was overwhelming evidence that these increases are not only unfair but also positively regressive. A lot of people have already mentioned Nabalco and it is good that we make mention of it again. It is the largest inland consumer of fuel oil in Australia, using about 460,000 kilolitres a year for power generation and calcination. It suggested that this legislation will wipe $25 million from its joint venturers' pre-tax profits and will increase its fuel oil costs by 29 per cent. In the submission it made to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration it claimed:

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget increases the duty on fuel oil by a staggering 96 per cent, writing off $25 million from our Joint Venturers' pre-tax profits.
It went on to say:
The impost cannot help but confirm the heightened sovereign risk of investing in mining and minerals processing in Australia.

This is just another slug. I imagine that the Labor Party is just getting the next slug ready for the mining industry—that is, Mabo. That will slug it again. If it has not slugged it with fuel, the government will slug it with other legislation that it is introducing in this place.

PARA.TAB: We wonder why a government wants to be so anti-business, so anti-export industries, so regressive and so unhelpful to the people who can produce the export income that gives all Australians their standard of living. It is absolutely amazing. We wonder what it is on about.

TALK.START.PARA: —And why others in this chamber want to support them.
—Senator O'Chee is correct again. Nabalco's submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The ad valorem rate of tax on fuel oil by August 1994 will be 88 per cent, a figure exceeding the rates on cigarettes, alcoholic spirits and petrol (and over twice the rate on beer).

The National Farmers Federation also appeared before the Senate standing committee. It too was scathing in its remarks about this tax. It is pretty scathing in the remarks it is making about Mabo as well. It knows that all the businesses out there trying to do something are being hit by this Labor Party government all the time. Given that this year farmers are suffering across all commodity groups and given that they are major users of fuel, it was generally thought that there would be some incentives in the budget for the farming communities. After all, when incomes for broadacre farmers are anticipated to be negative $18,000 or worse and wheat growers make on average a business profit of about $1,000 per farm, it is hard to see how a government imposing these extra taxes can be regarded by anyone as being fair dinkum. That is precisely what the Keating government is doing. The NFF said:
Taxes on fuel are widely acknowledged to be highly regressive because fuel consumption rises only slightly with income.
It went on to say:

At least 60% of fuel taxes are paid, in the first instance, by businesses. Introducing an increase in a tax that falls primarily on business is a direct contradiction of moves elsewhere by Government to reduce taxes on business.
A letter to the Treasurer written by Graham Blight of the National Farmers Federation stated:
I write to raise the strongest objections to your decision in the federal budget to dramatically increase fuel excise.
He went on to say:

Because more than 60% of excisable petroleum products are consumed by business and industry, the rises in excise rates will reduce international competitiveness and add to business costs. The effects will be most pronounced in agriculture and mining—Australia's major export industries.

That is exactly what I said a minute ago—the government is slugging the people who produce the export income that gives us our standard of living. Why does the government not think a little about it and acknowledge that the people who play the tune and give us the export income should be paid a little bit occasionally rather than being hit to leg every time they try to get their heads above water?

PARA.TAB: The transport industry is another industry that is struggling to make a profit. It is a major business user of fuel and so important to our export industries. It estimates that its fuel bills will increase by something like $6,000 per lorry per year. That is extra costs on our export income which means that we cannot compete with other countries.

New Zealand was mentioned earlier by Senator Campbell. Holy hell, New Zealand has outrun us. New Zealand is competing around the world and jumping tariff barriers like nobody's business because it is competitive. If we try to jump tariff walls around the world—if a country has a tariff barrier to stop us getting in—and we increase our costs again, it means that the high jump rail will be put up even higher. What is the government on about? Why is it being so anti-business?

These costs to the transport industry cannot be absorbed. They will have to be passed on. That is where we will see extra costs on a range of goods going to our export industries and extra costs going to our farms and our country towns and country cities. It astounds me that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Sherry, is allowing his party to slug country people, especially, and exporters as hard as they are being slugged by this increase in the fuel excise.

I believe that the fuel rises are inappropriate because they will blow out inflation and, despite all assurances given by the government ministers, it is obvious that that will happen. The excise increases are inappropriate because they put industries at risk.

The shipping industry has already been mentioned. After years of negotiation, it convinced the unions to agree to reduced manning levels on ships. That would have made Australian shipping a little more competitive, but the increases in fuel excises that are mooted in this budget will negate the whole cost saving of the manning level alleviation. So much for helping an industry! As I have said, this government is completely anti-business.

These taxes are definitely unnecessary. They were foisted on us without being talked about during the election campaign. The coalition's Fightback package, which we talked about during the election campaign, would have done a job for business and made it competitive. As Senator Campbell said, the New Zealanders have got right under our necks and become competitive, because they have taken up all those things that we were talking about here at the last election.

The coalition's Fightback package showed that we had a balanced budget by abolishing wholesale sales taxes and abolishing the fuel taxes—the complete opposite of what this government is doing. Under a Hewson-Fischer government we would have been paying something like 19c a litre less for our fuel. That would have helped export industries and people in country areas, country towns and country cities, wherever they may be.

Over the last 10 years or so, the Hawke-Keating governments have ripped off the Australian consumer to the tune of billions of dollars. In 1983, petrol excise was 6.155c a litre. By August 1992, it had increased to 26.154c a litre. The total tax for fuel in 1982-83 was $970 million. Just think how good things were in those days. By 1992 there was a tax rip-off at the fuel bowser by this government—by Senator Sherry's and Senator West's government; they should hang their heads in shame. Fancy Senator West coming from a country area and allowing these taxes to increase the way they have.

The petrol station is just another branch of the taxation department and Senator West is a part of it. If these bills go through, everyone who calls in to a petrol bowser will be able to say that the people in the Labor Party slug them every time they want to go from point A to point B to do their jobs, or whatever.

TALK.START.PARA: —The little people.

—As Senator Sandy Macdonald just said, they are the little people. I have already mentioned what the Prime Minister is doing to the little people—the people who have small incomes and who cannot afford to upgrade their cars and buy new, modern cars that use unleaded fuel. They are also going to be slugged.

PARA.TAB: The whole of this legislation is anti-business to the extent that it is not helping Australian trade competitiveness. We are sinking further and further into debt every day in Australia because we cannot be competitive in our export markets. This is another way of saying that we will become even less competitive.

This government and the people who sit on the government benches in this place stand condemned for trying to foist on us today an increase in fuel excise which will not do any good for anyone, and which will do much harm to our export industries and people who live in country towns and country cities and rural communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, rise to speak on the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. It is unfortunate that I have to rise to speak on these bills, because I would have thought that by now the government would have woken up to the fact that, after 10 years in government, it cannot continue to tax the productive sector—the people who have to produce the income—and expect it to go on producing.

PARA.TAB: I was fortunate to be able to sit through the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on this issue. We heard a similar story from the long haul road hauliers, the shipping industry, the short haul road hauliers, the mining industry and the farming industry. The costs that are being imposed through these increases will have a significant impact on their competitiveness.

To begin with, I will deal with the impact on Western Australia. Western Australia is a state that is relatively small in population but large in size and production capacity. That state is now producing in excess of 25 per cent, going close to 30 per cent, of the total export income of this country. Within 10 to 12 years, that capacity is estimated to rise to 40 per cent, particularly if the government gets off its back and lets it get on with the job. Whatever analysis is applied to it, it is being severely disadvantaged.

I will cite some figures showing the impact of this increase in the fuel excise on Western Australia. It must be remembered that the transport industry, in terms of its tasks and the geography of Australia, is a very heavily taxed industry at this time. Once the full 5c fuel excise increase is in place, it will create a two per cent rise in general freight costs across Western Australia. It will cost Western Australia something like an additional $175 million a year for transport services.

The excise will increase the cost to farmers of grain cartage by another 25 cents per tonne. It will increase the production costs in the agricultural area by $560 million.
