As one works through these figures, one finds that the impact will be quite dramatic and very devastating. It must be remembered that this increase will take place against a background of the wool industry in particular going through very difficult times. It is estimated that the impact of these measures on each producer will run into several thousands of dollars.

I particularly want to deal with the wool industry. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Research Economics currently predicts that the losses in the wool industry this year will be in the order of $34,000 or $35,000 per property. This measure will add another couple of thousand dollars to those loses. It will certainly increase the number of individual operations that have difficulty in dealing with the current crisis in the wool industry and it will lead to further bankruptcies. The government has not really thought through the economic and social implications of this legislation on the Australian public and Australian industry.

The legislation will also have a very significant impact on the mining industry. The mining industry in Western Australia is basically in remote areas. As I have already mentioned, the increase in the fuel excise will mean that the industry will be less competitive. For example, the Australia iron ore industry will be less able to compete with countries such as Brazil.

The increased fuel excise will result in an impact on Westrail's fuel bill of something like $1.5 million. It is rather pleasing to see that a couple of Western Australian senators are on the other side of the chamber. I hope they take account of Western Australian industry when they are looking at the implications of this legislation. There comes a time when senators have to stand up in this place for their states and be counted. It will be rather interesting to see whether or not those Western Australian senators do that.

There will be an additional cost of $16 million to the Australian shipping industry. I will continue to deal with the impact of the increase in the fuel excise on our productive sector. Every month Australia consistently produces a current account deficit of somewhere between $1.3 billion and $2 billion. This measure will only exacerbate that problem. If adopted, this legislation will mean that it is going to be that much longer before Australia can start balancing its budget and balancing its books.

Of course, there are other implications. This measure will mean that Australia will be less able to employ more people and address our serious unemployment problems. This is particularly disappointing for Western Australia because that state is showing some signs of coming out of the recession we had to have. It is showing some signs of increasing its productive capacity. This is certainly the case in the mining industry. In agriculture, farmers have responded to the rural crisis and lifted their overall effort in grain production. I am sure that Senator Panizza, a fellow Western Australian senator from the Southern Cross wheat belt, is well aware that these farmers have made a major effort to improve productivity. Yet they are being slugged again. I am certain that when grain growers do their sums for next year—and we should bear in mind that they are subject to the variability of world markets—and realise the damage that this legislation will do to them, some of the incentive to repeat their efforts to improve productivity will be destroyed very dramatically.

In putting forward this legislation, the government is penalising those people who have made an effort over a significant number of years to tackle the problems associated with the management of the Australian economy. It is a pity that the government has not applied the same sort of toughness to reforming our industrial system and making it a lot more competitive than it currently is. I am not going to dwell on this now; we will deal with it at a later date.

I would like to look at the impact of this legislation on the shipping industry; and I think this is one of the greatest tragedies of all. I know that some of my colleagues have already mentioned this subject but I would like to emphasise a couple of points. The government has, in effect, completely undermined and eroded the SIRA program. Senator Collins, for example, must feel very disillusioned about the performance of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), bearing in mind the effort that has gone into developing the SIRA program. I do not necessarily accept that everything that could have been done in terms of that program has been done to improve the competitiveness of our shipping industry. But it is worth noting that there has been a significant reduction in the manning levels, the operating costs and the like in order to make the Australian coastal shipping industry competitive.

In the week the budget was brought down an agreement was reached by the Shipping Industry Reform Authority and the maritime union. In effect, the agreement actually removed 111 berths from the Australian coastal shipping industry. That was a reform that had to happen. The agreement translates into 240 positions or thereabouts.

The fuel excise changes that the government has made—a 55 per cent increase in the excise by August 1994 and a further increase of 9.2 per cent or 10.4c per litre within 12 months—will have the effect, in cost terms, of putting some 146 berths back into the industry or creating 320 jobs. That is going to create a situation that is almost untenable for the shipping industry in Australia. The impact of this legislation will reverse the whole of the SIRA reform program. Instead of Australian having an internationally competitive shipping operation, we will have one that goes back to what can be termed the bad old days. Cost increases will mean that a lot of the tasks will not be transferred to shipping. Industries are not going to develop around the Australian coastline. This fuel excise increase is going to inhibit the development of the mining industry in certain areas, particularly Western Australia.

There are many other points that could be made in this debate. In the time that I have left to speak, I want to touch on the situation in Western Australia with respect to road funding and the increase in fuel excises. It is worth reminding this chamber that the fuel excise was commenced for the purpose of raising funds to build new roads and maintain old ones.

In the 1992-93 budget, Western Australia's share of road funding was $162 million. In the 1993-94 budget, it has been reduced to $99.4 million or, in round figures, just under $100 million. That is a reduction of some $63 million, yet we will have foisted upon our productive sector this enormous increase in fuel excise.

The figures show that Western Australia's share of total Commonwealth grants, including those for local government roads, has decreased from 18 per cent prior to 1969 to 8.2 per cent in 1993-94. That rate of decline has been most pronounced over recent years, particularly from 1988-89 to 1993-94. Western Australia's share of the National Highway funds is only 7.1 per cent, yet Western Australia has 25 per cent of the total length of the National Highway. Once again, Western Australia is being severely disadvantaged with respect to road funding.

We can go further with this. Western Australia has 25 per cent of the total length of the National Highway. It gets 7.1 per cent of road funding. Ten per cent of the vehicle kilometres travelled in Australia are in Western Australia. If we measure the 7.1 per cent against the 10 per cent, and not against the 25 per cent which I initially mentioned, once again we are significantly disadvantaged. Western Australia also has 9.5 per cent of the population.

When we analyse these figures and what the Commonwealth has done with respect to funding and the raising of revenue through the utilisation of the fuel excise, we find that Western Australia fares very badly on all accounts. It is the state which has the greatest potential to lift us out of our current crisis—that is, our recession, our current account problems and our national debt—yet we are being penalised as a state.

I have not touched on all the aspects that were raised with us at the committee hearings and elsewhere. I put it to the government that, as far as its policies on road transport, rail transport, shipping transport and, for that matter, any form of transport are concerned, it is time to have another look. The transport system is the lifeblood of this nation. It is the mechanism by which we move our goods and services around. Unlike most other countries, our population fits into a very small area of the nation. It is basically on the coastline and, as such, there are enormous distances to travel. We are unique in that respect.

As far as our transport is concerned, we still have the incredible situation—this is where I talk about exports—where it costs no more to cart a load of wheat on a ship to Europe, for example, than it does to take it down to Tasmania. We could go through a whole host of examples. But these bills do not deal with that aspect of transport. They deal with putting up costs for our miners, our farmers, our shipping industry and our everyday users of goods and services. One of the things about these bills that need to be borne in mind at end of the day is that those costs will be passed on to the final consumer.

In the hearings, evidence was given to us—this is where the secret GST comes into it—that the average cost of a carton of groceries, as a result of these additional charges on the transport industry, would amount to close to $3 per trolley. The Australian public needs to be well aware of the impact that these secret taxes which are put in place have on everyday living—whether it be for groceries, fuel to run motor cars or whatever.

At the end of the day, the tragedy of it all is that it means that we will have a number of industries in this country, particularly agriculture, mining and those that are developing in terms of value adding, that will be significantly less competitive than they could have been, and that is no credit to the government. In fact, I would say shame on the government for not having analysed this a lot more carefully. When the committee asked what economic analysis had been done on the impact on the Australian economy, the answer was either virtually none or none. Because of that, I say shame on the government for having put this extra impost at a time when we needed assistance to become competitive.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I have just read the Hansard pink and I realise that I made an error in the short comment I made after question time this afternoon. I was talking about the increased cost to the Commonwealth if the tax concession had not been withdrawn for the defence forces in Cambodia. I did the mental arithmetic as I was speaking and I said that the saving would be somewhere around $30 to $40 per week. I should have said $30 to $40 per day. I worked out from that that it would have been a saving of about $20,000. Obviously, that should be multiplied by about seven and the true figure, as I calculate it, would be between $160,000 to $180,000. That is a saving to the Commonwealth by withdrawing the taxation benefit or concession that it granted to the ADF. I apologise to the Senate for having made that slip and I hope that sets the record straight.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993[COGNATE BILL:EXCISE TARIFF (DEFICIT REDUCTION) BILL 1993]

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor is building a wall of silence around the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. When I looked at the speakers' list distributed by my whip, I noticed that it contains some 20 speakers, which indicates the importance of this particular piece of budget legislation. However, the only Australian Labor Party speaker in that list of 20 speakers is the minister in response. Not one other Labor minister has been prepared to come in here and talk about the effects that this legislation will have on their states, the electorates that they represent and the interest groups that they have been drawn from in the past.
—No Labor backbench support.

—No Labor backbench support and not one in here now—there is one Labor senator just walking in. There is not one Labor speaker on the list. I think that is disgraceful when one considers the economic impact of this particular legislation and its import. The government is taking a very hard line from the point of view of its budget; yet not one speaker on the Labor Party side has been prepared to come in here and put a view.

PARA.TAB: We have heard since budget day about how the fuel oil excise will impact on the transport industry, particularly on rail, road and shipping.In addition to the compounding effect that the fuel excise will have on the costs of living throughout remote and rural Australia, in the Northern Territory there is an impost on fuel oils that will impact on the generation of electricity in one of Australia's leading export industries, the Nabalco alumina and bauxite production in Arnhem Land. Without any warning whatsoever, these bills will stick an impost of $25 million on the operation of one particular mine.As I said, Labor is building a wall of silence around this legislation and, I would argue in particular from the Northern Territory's point of view, around the operations of Nabalco at Gove.

Where has the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) been on this legislation? He has been totally absent from any of the debate. In fact, after I had issued some press releases last week, he was trapped by an ABC interviewer and asked a question about the implications of the legislation. This was his reply on ABC Radio on 11 October:

SPEECH.PARA: I met with Nabalco in Canberra with Bob Collins last week. We're sympathetic to their position and we've had discussions. I had a discussion in fact last week with the Treasurer about it but I am hopeful we'll be able to do something.

Hopeful but totally neutered; not one result has yet emerged from the government. Where has the support been from Senator Collins? Nearly four weeks ago in this chamber, Senator Collins was asked a question about the impact of this legislation and he said that the government has had it under consideration. Well, so damn what! Four weeks later it is still under consideration and members of the government are not even game to come in here and talk about it, let alone propose some administrative or technical amendments of any nature to the legislation.

PARA.TAB: My side, the Liberal and National parties, have foreshadowed some amendments which Senator Watson has already spoken about; the Australian Democrats have foreshadowed some amendments; the Greens have foreshadowed some amendments; and Senator Harradine has been speaking about the impact of this legislation on Tasmania. It seems that everyone else, except the Labor Party, has taken a very keen interest. I am disgusted that so far as I am aware the Labor Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory, Mr Brian Ede, has not said a damn thing about the legislation. I am not aware that the member for Nhulunbuy, Mr Sid Stirling, has said a damn thing. Of course, we all know that the shadow minister for mines and energy, Mr Maurice Rioli, has been preoccupied and certainly has not said anything in the past few days. So much for the recommendations of the past few years of the Prime Minister's country task force. It makes a mockery of the new regional task force that has been created when the impact of this legislation does nothing more than prove that Labor is all talk and no action.

When this legislation hit the parliament, on the initiative of the Liberal and National parties the bills were subjected to an inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. That Senate inquiry came back with a majority report—the Labor Party had the numbers—which gave a one sentence summary of what the committee had done and a one sentence recommendation that the legislation should be agreed to without amendment. Thankfully, my colleagues—Senator Campbell, Senator Kemp and Senator Watson—put down a very detailed and comprehensive minority report which fully summarised the impact and the flaws of this legislation. But still there was no response whatsoever—nothing was said about how it will increase the cost of living of people throughout Australia who are affected by all of the transport industries or in any other way.

This evening I want to confine my remarks to looking specifically at how this legislation will impact on the operations of Nabalco in the Northern Territory. The budget increased duty on fuel oil from 5.512c per litre to around 10.828c per litre next August, a staggering rise of 96 per cent. This is a higher Commonwealth rate of tax than is imposed on diesel, petrol, cigarettes, spirits or beer and about nine times the rate that was proposed on wine.

In 1992-93, one project—the one I am speaking about, Nabalco's bauxite and alumina refinery at Gove—paid over 60 per cent of its revenue collected from inland fuel oil sales. Unlike many other industries and companies, Nabalco has no opportunity to pass on the $25 million increased cost to its customers, because Nabalco exports all of its products on competitive world markets.

Nabalco is one of six alumina refineries in Australia, all adding value to our mineral raw materials by processing and upgrading the raw material, bauxite. But all Nabalco's Australian competitors have access to competitively priced natural gas, which is not taxed. Nabalco's pre-budget fuel oil tax burden of around $25 million was a substantial handicap in a competitive market. Dr Terry Gardner, General Manager of Nabalco, in giving evidence to the Senate inquiry on 1 October, said that the new tax burden of around $50 million `just doubles that disadvantage'. It has always been a principle of tax policy to ensure taxpayers are treated fairly and without discrimination. Nabalco stated in its submission to the inquiry that `it is a challenge to think of any more offensive transgression' of this important tax principle.
In 1968 Nabalco signed an agreement with the Commonwealth to regulate the operations on the Gove Peninsula. Clause 12 of the Gove agreement provides, inter alia:

SPEECH.PARA: 12(1) The Commonwealth will use its best endeavours to ensure that no Act or Ordinance is passed that will impose . . . discriminatory taxes, discriminatory rates or discriminatory charges of any nature whatsoever on or in respect of the titles, property or other assets, products, materials or services used . . . in the conduct of business incidental to the company's business under this agreement.

This is not simply a matter of tax principles, but a matter on which there is a specific Commonwealth undertaking not to do exactly what it has now done. The tax on Nabalco is not only discriminatory but the government's political handling of it has been arrogant and brutal. When Senator Schacht listened to the Nabalco evidence in the Senate committee he was obviously visibly shocked, and he had the decency to admit:

I suppose you could always say that any individual company that is paying, in revenue terms, about half of one tax obviously has a reasonable case to say, irrespective of what association it is in, that this may be the Nabalco tax rather than anyone else's tax. I am sympathetic to that point of view, so I will refer that particular case to the Treasurer.
It seems that Mr Snowdon, Senator Collins, Senator Schacht and everyone else refers it to the Treasurer but nothing gets done.

PARA.TAB: What about the issue of sovereign risk that this poses to Australia? The truly damaging repercussions for Australia of the $25 million Nabalco tax hike relate to sovereign risk. If the tax and its consequences were deliberate, the government would be giving notice of a preparedness to level highly discriminatory taxes on any project with no option but to pay up or shut down. We need to look very carefully at all of those issues and the implications that arise from this whole area for investors as to how this might affect other projects. Nabalco, Savage River and Mount Keith are all major processing projects. This is the sharpest signal that is being delivered to the mining industry.

Again back to my friend—or perhaps he is not my friend on this issue—Senator Collins. He stood out a lot more than like a sore toe on the issue of Coronation Hill. He went so far as to castigate the cabinet and to rudely describe the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in various ABC programs. That was Coronation Hill. Where is he now on Nabalco? He is nowhere to be seen, and certainly to be hidden. The significance of the fuel tax increase for future project investment may take a little more time to be fully appreciated, but the government would be deluding itself if it harboured any hope that failure to correct the mistake would go unnoticed by investors. This legislation will lead to higher sovereign risk, revealed in an increased reluctance to invest and higher rates of return required by investors. It will lead to the unavoidable consequences of lower investment, lower growth and fewer jobs.

What else will it lead to? This is an outcome that will not be confined to the resources sector. It is one that Australia simply cannot afford. In the area of incentives for investment and efficiency improvement this legislation makes a mockery—as Senator Watson said earlier this evening—of a whole range of policies that the government has supposedly put in place. Doctor Gardner of Nabalco told the Senate committee how Nabalco had invested $120 million in its operations at Gove since 1991—I remind honourable senators that that is only two years ago—in order to reduce the cost per tonne of alumina produced. That investment program succeeded in achieving cost reductions amounting to $10 per tonne, and then the 1993 budget comes along, hitting the project with a tax that raises costs by $15 per tonne. As Dr Gardner said:

SPEECH.PARA: That just eliminated that investment, that hard work, and then some—it just wiped it away.

The experience of coastal shipping companies in shipping reform is exactly the same. Where have the unions been throughout this debate? I would have thought that the unions, with their attachment to a project as important as Nabalco, would have been talking out on this issue. It makes a mockery of their policies, of union investment in the whole of Australia. And it does not end there. Whose money is behind the participants in the Nabalco joint venture at Gove, for instance? The answer is very simple—two well-known Australian institutions, CSR and AMP, as well as Alusuisse. The Labor Government encourages employees and directs enterprises to invest in superannuation schemes that, in turn, invest in companies like CSR only to find that CSR's investments are able to be raided without warning and value appropriated by this Labor government.

PARA.TAB: What about the assets of AMP policyholders that have been raided by the discriminatory fuel tax in exactly the same way? How many Australian AMP policyholders must now be waking up to the real motives of this government? The new National Investment Council would be well advised to have a look at this Nabalco tax because compiling a believable strategy to promote investment will be an impossible task unless the heightened level of sovereign risk, the risk of appropriation of asset value by government, is demonstrably reduced. Interestingly, Treasury papers state:

SPEECH.PARA: One specific issue for which the Council has been given responsibility is to advise the Government on strategies to facilitate the establishment of regional headquarters in Australia while maintaining the integrity of the tax system.

I kid you not. Would honourable senators be surprised to learn that one of the big international companies singled out by the government for encouragement to set up its Asian headquarters in Australia—and in the very process of doing so, I believe—is Alusuisse, the 70 per cent joint venture partner of the Gove project? The fuel oil tax is understandably at the forefront of their minds when government officials talk about the integrity of the tax system.

PARA.TAB: What about the Treasury's new committee, the Wran committee, to look at northern Australia's export potential? This legislation makes a mockery of what that committee has to do. I can assure you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that I will be making a submission to Mr Wran and his committee pointing out what this idiotic, stupid legislation has done. The budget increase in fuel oil tax flies in the face of sound economic logic and in the advice of the government's own economic advisers.

The Industries Assistance Commission reported on a directly relevant reference as recently as 1 November 1986. In that report, entitled Certain Petroleum Products—Taxation Measures, important recommendations included:

SPEECH.PARA: The revenue which petroleum taxes are expected to generate is too high. They are distorting production and consumption decisions, thus reducing Australia's economic efficiency. The Commission's judgment is that, in the long run, a sound case can be made for all intermediate use of petroleum products to be exempted from revenue raising taxation.

We have these sorts of distortions. Arguments against imposing petroleum product taxes on intermediate users noted by the IAC are that they penalise petroleum intensive industries like Nabalco, distort the import mix of industry, encouraging, for example, the inefficient use of natural gas, impact disproportionately in communities in remote areas—which also bear all of the high transport costs that are going to be further compounded by this damned legislation—and impact severely on industries like Nabalco competing on world markets. This damages Australia's export competitiveness and trade performance.

PARA.TAB: Inexplicably, the government has taken this budget decision at a time when it has the Industries Assistance Commission working on another reference on petroleum. Would it not have been more responsible to await the commission's latest findings before barging in blindly with a huge increase in a form of tax that the IAC only seven years ago recommended should be abolished? I am naturally angry at the government. I am angry that this evening not one Labor Party senator has had the courage, the guts, to come in here and argue a case for the government. The committee that was chaired by Senator Coates put in an insulting report—one paragraph and a one-sentence recommendation—and did not in any way even seek to put down some issues that compounded it.

As I have said, I am annoyed, insulted and disgusted that Senator Collins, representing remote and rural Australia, appears to be hiding in a hole on this particular issue. Mr Snowdon, a member in the House of Representatives, said, `We might be doing something' last week. But the government did nothing this week and he has nothing to colour it with.

How could the government fail to appreciate the implications of this particular legislation? It should not be arguing what the unintended consequences are. They will stand out as the effects on the Northern Territory and the rest of remote Australia. They will stand out in Aboriginal communities right throughout Australia where the cost of living, which impacts straight back into the government's budget, will be felt. The power generation itself not only affects the mine at Gove but also affects every family and every person in that part of Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, rise to speak against these particular increases in customs and taxation proposed in the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. I support the comments of my colleagues. I can understand why Senator Tambling feels so upset—
—Aggrieved.

—And aggrieved by these particular measures that have been proposed by the government without any warning to the Australian people before the last election. He, like myself and many others in this place, sees what is happening to rural and regional Australia every day of the week.

PARA.TAB: I note that in the draft amendments that the Greens have circulated they, too, have mentioned the effect that these taxes will have on rural and regional Australia. In fact, they have taken note of the effect that this fuel tax increase will have on sea and rail freight. Being a Tasmanian, this is the area that concerns me most, along with all the other concerns that have been expressed by my colleagues from around Australia.

As far as the rural area is concerned, it seems to me that every week another disaster comes along. If farmers have not been fighting off drought, they have been facing floods in a lot of areas of Australia. When the farmers who are lucky enough to have had a good season get through that, they are faced with another disaster. For example, Senator Brownhill's son had the best wheat crop and the best crop of faber beans he has ever had, until half past five this afternoon when a hail storm wiped them out.

That is when we ask ourselves, `Why do people stay on the land? Why do they remain farmers?' It is the way they have been brought up; it is the challenge, the life they are used to. I guess the most upsetting thing is the continual taxing of their lifelines by governments that do not seem to care about what they are trying to do. These people are not only producing the food we eat but also producing huge amounts of export income per head of population even now with depressed prices, droughts, floods and everything else that goes with them. Yet it is these people that this government sets out to tax, one way or the other.

As far as my own state of Tasmania is concerned, the content of these two bills spells disaster for not only the producers in Tasmania but also the men and women in the street and their families. The petrol excise increases contained in the budget will cost Tasmania $61 million. This equates to an additional $129 per head for every man, woman and child in the state—that is just one particular increase.

It is a regressive tax. I remember that during the last election campaign the government members ran up and down my state of Tasmania bashing us for our GST and the effects it would have. I remember well not only the lies but also the frightening statements that were made—15 per cent on this and 15 per cent on that. The man in the street was frightened because he thought he would be absolutely taxed.

But in our tax package we were going to reduce the excise on fuel by 19c a litre. Even the man in the street could understand the flow-on effect that that would have through the whole community because of the savings in freight and how, particularly in my state and, I guess, in Western Australia where they rely on a lot of road freight, the reductions in excise on fuel would flow through to everything that the country people rely on; they would become automatically cheaper. That was a wonderful offset for the proposed GST. Yet here we have this other government measure increasing excise on fuel with no offsets whatsoever—not one. So the people in rural and regional Australia and isolated areas such as Tasmania and Western Australia will have to suffer because they rely on freight to a greater extent than the more urban populations of Melbourne and Sydney.

Because of our geographic disadvantage in Tasmania, we have some of the highest consumer prices in the country. These are continually being pointed out by the Minister for Justice, the honourable Duncan Kerr, in his price watch committee. But the major reason why our prices are higher in Tasmania is that of the freight component. I think even Senator Coates would have to admit that.

It is important to note, too, that because of that particular concern, just last week a bipartisan delegation came to Canberra from Tasmania to push the case for Bass Strait to be recognised as a national highway. I think the delegation was going to call it Highway 1. I was contacted by Leanne Martin from Devonport who was heading up that delegation, which included representatives from all sides of politics. In fact, she wrote the letter to me from Silvia Smith's office, so I just wonder how Silvia Smith will explain to her constituents in Bass the increase in the prices of goods and fuel. How will she explain to those battlers in the community, who live in her electorate and drive old model cars because they cannot afford to buy more modern cars that use unleaded fuel, the increase in fuel tax and that, therefore, more dollars will go out of their pockets into the tax collection agency at the petrol pump every week?

I wonder whether Senator Devereux, for instance, will cross the floor and support the Greens after having said what he said about the Green parties in Tasmania and what he has not said about the Labor Party there. It was quite fascinating to see a neighbour of mine who has been, I must admit, concerned about environmental issues, criticise his own party in his own state in supporting Christine Milne. I presume there is a lot of frustration there and that probably comes from the fact that he has to talk to his constituents and tell them that there is not much he can do about this increase in fuel prices.

It has been estimated that the increase in fuel excise will increase the cost of the contents of every grocery trolley that young mothers in Tasmania have to push every week by about $3. The cost of other goods, particularly the heavy items that are freighted into Tasmania, will rise by a greater degree.

Tasmania has the peculiar situation, too, that wholesale sales taxes that are also imposed on us have been increased because most of the goods are sourced out of Victoria or New South Wales. There is a fair amount of freight component in those wholesale prices. The freight will go up because of the increase in excise and the wholesale sales tax, by definition, will also rise, so Tasmania will be hit with a double whammy. This comes on top of increases in tobacco taxes that will cost Tasmania $7.5 million or $16 a head, if one happens to be a smoker. As I said earlier, the increases in wholesale sales taxes which have gone through this place will cost Tasmania $35.7 million or $75 a head.

The reductions in income tax, which have been promised but have yet to be delivered, will return a paltry $72.5 million to the states. So the net result is that Tasmania will be $31.7 million worse off. Every man, woman and child in Tasmania is going to be $67 per head poorer. For the average family, with two children, that equates to about $268 a year. That does not take into account the flow-through effect of all these freight increases. It is obvious that an island state like Tasmania, which has a heavy reliance on coastal shipping, is really going to suffer.

I think Senator Watson mentioned earlier that these budget measures will increase the excise on low quality petroleum used by coastal shipping from 5.441c per litre to 10.441c per litre by this time next year. This is going to raise industry costs by something like $16 million per year. The National Maritime Association calculates that this will raise the average cost for a coastal vessel by a staggering $358,387 a year. So it is no surprise that my colleagues have been pointing out that, even though Senator Collins has been coming in here week after week and month after month espousing the advantages of the waterfront reforms, the industry will be wiped out in one fell swoop if this tax comes into effect.

Just recently—I think it will come on 29 November this year—the Tasmanian government purchased a new vessel for our interstate tourism trade and freight between Victoria and Tasmania. This is our new highway. This vessel will introduce people into Tasmania. It is the former Peter Pan, a European state-of-the-art luxury cruiser, which has been renamed the Spirit of Tasmania. It is going to replace that great old ship the Abel Tasman—it is not all that old, and it has proved to be a wonderful acquisition of the state.

There is no doubt that a lot of hype will go with this particular new ferry coming on line. It is a lot larger. As far as I am aware—Senator Sherry might be able to tell me the exact figures—it has included on board a casino and three absolutely wonderful restaurants. I understand that the interest in this particular vessel is so high that 8,000 calls about the ship, bookings and inquiries, have been received in half a day. It is obviously exciting tourists on the mainland and it is obviously exciting people in Tasmania.

Of course, if it brings more visitors to Tasmania it will create more jobs. The way things are in Tasmania at the moment, with the highest unemployment rate in the nation, we certainly need more jobs and I think tourism is probably the best way to go. This new ship coming on will certainly make a huge difference.

Unfortunately, the engines and generators of the Spirit of Tasmania use heavy fuel oil. The Labor government's increases in excise will mean an increase of $54.58 per tonne on the price of fuel oil for the Spirit of Tasmania. This means that the operating cost will rise by $2,401 per voyage. I do not know where the $1 comes from, but that is the estimation I have been given. That is a massive $743,310 per annum.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that per ticket?

—It does not matter what it is per ticket; it is something that was not budgeted for. As Senator Sherry would know, there has been a lot of controversy about the fact that the ship was originally ordered by the previous Labor government and is supported by the present government. There has been a lot of speculation about the funding arrangements, but I think we all know that when one is borrowing the amount of money that has been borrowed for this particular vessel, any increase in costs will bear heavily on the running of it.

PARA.TAB: It might be easy to say, `Well, just pass it on', but the tourism industry is so competitive at the moment. Why should shipping be slugged when its competitors, the airlines, are exempt from tax across Bass Strait? It goes to the old argument from when the Sea Cat was on line. Why did the Sea Cat have to pay excise on fuel when the aircraft flying across the Strait did not? It is an unfair advantage that shipping has to face right from the beginning, when any advantage it could have would have been good. But it seems the government is not particularly interested.

I note with some delight that the Green amendments exempt fuel for sea freight. If those amendments were passed it would certainly help Tasmania. I hope that some of the Tasmanian senators who think more of their state than others will support that amendment.

The other thing I noted in the media—I do not know whether it is right or not—is that there may be some inducements being made to Senator Harradine in the form of increasing the freight equalisation proposals. I just hope that freight equalisation does not become a political football. It has worked and served Tasmania very well. It is something that I do not think should be tinkered with. I would go along with its being increased; I do not think most people would. But there is a danger of course. Once it has been used as a bargaining chip, further down the track it could be pulled out by any government. This is one of the success stories over many years now. Freight equalisation has helped somewhat to alleviate the problems our industries face.

Tasmania also has a high dependence on mining industries. These announcements have already resulted in the major Tasmanian iron ore pellet producer, Savage River Mines, announcing that it is going to bring forward its closure. Only last week when I was down there we flew over and noticed the 40-mile pipeline that the mine uses to pump its iron ore pellets from the west coast. It has always been a reasonably marginal operation and this particular increase in excise looks like it might have sounded the death knell. Unfortunately, north-west Tasmania, where Senator Sherry used to come from—still comes from, I think—

TALK.START.PARA: —I live in Burnie.

—He moves around a bit these days, but he lived in Burnie. Three hundred jobs going from Savage River is something that I do not think the north-west coast can afford. In the north of the state we have Comalco, which has been shedding labour and trying to become more efficient. It has to bring its bauxite in by sea from Weipa and any increase in fuel oil on freight would certainly not be the sort of thing it would be looking for at the moment, when it is trying to streamline its operation.

PARA.TAB: Only last week in the south of the state we had Pasminco Metals announcing that economic circumstances had forced the company to shed up to 350 workers. That is still going on and hopefully the number of workers it initially talked about shedding will not be shed. Nevertheless, it finds in these hard economic times that it has to become more efficient. Increases in freight caused by increases in fuel oil tax certainly will not be to its advantage.

On top of those job losses, we have the company announcing that another 40 workers are going to be sacked because of the closure of the fertiliser plant. Where are the rural industries in Tasmania going to get their fertiliser from? If something is not done soon, they will have to start importing it from the mainland. Already I note that the vegetable growers, whom we rely on so much for our primary income, are talking about bringing fertiliser in from the mainland. There again it is freighted in. There again it is going to be at an increased cost and, therefore, it reduces the small profits they might be getting.

On the last sitting day when this matter was debated previously, I noted with some distaste that Senator Bell stood up and, quite ironically, gave a notice of motion in which he criticised the loss of jobs at EZ. He then proceeded to blame everyone else for the problem. I think we now know the Democrats' position, but certainly those workers at EZ would have liked to have known what Senator Bell and the Democrats contribution was to be. By voting for this increase in excise on fuel which will affect Pasminco so much, the Democrats were doing their bit to contribute to the misfortunes of the EZ workers.

Finally, I note that Senator Margetts of the Greens said earlier that the only reason they were supporting this was the effect it would have on leaded fuel. Why not look at doing something similar to what happened with low alcohol beer? By reducing the price of low alcohol beer, the desired effect was achieved. If the price of unleaded fuel were to be reduced, perhaps it may have the same effect—but not on the battlers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The excise increases initiated in the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993, particularly those on leaded and diesel fuel, will devastate rural and isolated Australians, especially the less well off in our community. These taxes will detrimentally affect the standard of living of not just those who use motor vehicles but indeed of all Australians. The price increase at the bowser as a result of these taxes will not just rip money from the pockets of drivers who pull in to fill up; it will be an additional cost for millions of Australians who depend on transport for their own livelihood, who depend on it for services and supply of goods and for their very survival.

PARA.TAB: The leaded fuel excise increase alone is expected to raise for this government over $1,200 million in revenue each year by 1996—$1,200 million extra in just three years. This is monstrous and will cripple already embattled ordinary Australians as well as those struggling in industry. Taxpayers just cannot go on digging into their pockets and paying hand over fist for more government hatchet jobs at balancing the books. Yet the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) continues to come up with unbelievable ways of screwing additional revenue out of people, and these fuel taxes are just one more example of that.

Generally, Australians hang on to their cars; they are not prone to trading in a car on a new model every year or so. Those who drive cars manufactured in the 1970s and early 1980s have to use leaded fuel. We hang on to our cars even longer now because of what this Labor government has done to our economy; and we hang on to them because we cannot see this bludgeoning budget making any improvements to our economic future. There is precious little confidence in our economy, and there is even less confidence among struggling families and businesses who are unable to afford basic requirements, let alone a new car, because of the parlous state of our economic conditions.

Added to this is the ever present prospect of unemployment which looms large over the heads of many family breadwinners. That is reason enough to put off any purchase of a major household necessity, let alone an expensive new pollution-free family car. Consequently, the discriminatory and unfair excise on leaded fuel will most affect those unable to afford the purchase price of a new car—which is not insubstantial these days. It will affect those Australians who live in the country, many of whom are not in a position to go out and buy the latest model of anything, let alone a new $30,000 family car. They have no choice with fuel. Because they cannot afford a new vehicle, they must buy leaded petrol.

So the Labor government slugs those who are least able to pay, all because it pretends to have turned `pollution friendly' and wants to tax pollution. With more than half the cars on our roads nearly a decade old, the government has found itself a veritable gold mine with this proposed excise increase. The excise itself, because it will mean people paying more for their fuel, will ensure that it takes even longer to save to purchase a newer, more fuel efficient, less polluting vehicle. This fact gives the lie to any claim that this is an environmental measure.

But the government has become very good at lies, or at least at making lies appear to be the truth. The real truth is that this measure is nothing more than a revenue milch cow. This rise is directly counter-productive to reducing lead pollution in the air as it puts new cars even further beyond the reach of ordinary Australians.

I have only recently presented to the Senate more than 16,300 signatures on a petition which calls for the excise on leaded fuel to be reversed—and there are thousands more protests still coming into my office. In other words, 16,300 drivers in South Australia have voted with their pens and refuse to be bullied by this Treasurer into paying yet more for their fuel. The Treasurer, and indeed this government, cannot dismiss these signatures which call for this key, regressive, revenue earning measure to be thrown out. Indeed, one sees from the Senate records that any petition which has 16,000 or more signatures ranks amongst the most supported petitions in recent years in the Senate. Any petitions presented to this Senate containing 5,000 or more signatures are very big petitions, and most of those take a year or more to collect. The 16,000-plus signatures on this petition were collected in just a few weeks.

Voters have every right to reject this tax when no legal authority to levy it actually exists. The situation as it currently stands has the budget announcing an increase in petrol taxes on both imported and locally refined petroleum products. Unfortunately, though the relevant clauses state the proposals are to be effective from the day after budget night, 18 August, the clauses are not binding until the relevant bills have actually passed into law. Hence, there is no legal status to the commencement date of this tax until the legislation of which it forms a part is properly enacted.

On the morning after the budget drivers were greeted with prices at the bowser 3c a litre more than they were when the petrol station closed the night before. Also from that time, the oil companies commenced payment of an extra 3c a litre for shipments of petrol made on or after 18 August.

Hence, what we have is a demand for taxes without the appropriate authority to do so—taxes which Australian voters are already paying and have been paying for nine weeks. This is a disgrace. It is bad enough that additional taxes are introduced when times are tough, but to do so immediately without any assurance that the required legislation will pass through the parliament is sublimely arrogant.

Vehicle owners already pay more than 12 per cent of total government receipts, and for the privilege drivers are slugged mercilessly for using some of the most poorly maintained roads in existence. The creation of a price differential between leaded and unleaded petrol by this government is nothing more than a money grabbing exercise under the thin veneer of environmental friendliness. Australia has seen seven years of unleaded petrol in passenger vehicles, but it still has not become the principal fuel, since new car sales dropped to a 20-year low in 1987, the year after the government's change towards unleaded petrol.

More than 50 per cent of Australia's cars are at least nine years old compared with only 35 per cent a decade ago. Leaded petrol will remain at least 20 per cent of petrol purchased until the year 2,000. The prospect of paying a few dollars extra to run a car each week will not force a rush on new car yards. Drivers who are hard pressed to keep their heads above water now, will not feel inclined to give up their lead-using cars easily given the changeover cost.

Instead of raising the price of leaded petrol, the government, if it were at all serious about its own commitment to greenness and environmental friendliness, should have dropped the price of all fuel, and of unleaded fuel by even more. It would thereby make it easier for consumers, first, to save more money so they could switch to new cleaner cars; and, second, it would make it more attractive to use cleaner, unleaded fuel by offering realistic tax inducements rather than tax penalties.

New, less polluting, environmentally friendly, high technology, unleaded fuel motor vehicles are well beyond the price range of the average Australian in these tough recessionary times. It is no wonder that we are keeping older cars on the road. What hope does the average Australian family have these days if it has to fork out the equivalent of a reasonable house deposit—between $25,000 and $30,000—to pay for a family sedan? It is criminal. To boot, this Labor government, the so-called friend of low income earners and battlers, turns around in the budget and hikes up the price of leaded fuel at the bowser for all and sundry.

The only way in which we are going to get drivers into more environmentally friendly, less polluting vehicles is to make the price of those vehicles lower—to produce cheaper motor vehicles. Indeed, that is what this country desperately needs: cheaper new cars. Apart from belatedly and slowly reducing tariffs on motor vehicles, this government has done nothing to achieve this goal. It has done nothing to free up the industrial relations structures and restrictive work practices in this country to ensure that motor vehicle manufacturers can become more productive and more efficient. It has done nothing to lift the tax burden off business by removing wholesale sales taxes, payroll taxes and the myriad other taxes that impact on business and on the costs of production and, therefore, the ultimate cost of motor vehicles. The government simply goes on its merry way, taxing more but doing nothing of real benefit to business.

If we are going to really pursue the goal of having less polluting vehicles on the road, it is essential that we have cheaper motor vehicles. It is not just from motorists that we have had a cry of foul about the fuel tax increases in this budget; the road transport industry has also come out in strong condemnation of these tax hikes. It has no choice except to pass them directly on to consumers and customers or else to cut even further existing operating costs.

Diesel fuel is being bumped up by 5c a litre. On top of that, an increase in wholesale sales tax of two per cent will affect the transport industry. In industry language, that represents a 19 per cent increase on the existing diesel rate of 26.73c a litre and a 10 per cent increase on the typical sales tax rate of 20 per cent in wholesale sales tax. With the recession having bitten hard into the road transport industry, and with the fiercely competitive nature of that industry, margins are right down to the wire in any case.

The road transport industry already pays double the amount of indirect taxes of any other industry group. For each dollar spent on road transport, one-third goes in taxes and charges. For the Treasurer to claim that such fuel tax charges would have no impact on jobs in the trucking industry is quite ludicrous. What he seems to have forgotten is that the transport and storage sector in this country contributes five per cent of our gross domestic product.

A total of 385,000 people are employed directly in the transport industry. Road transport dominates total transport in this country. This sector alone contributes 2.4 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. It moves 75 per cent of all freight nationally, the vast proportion of which cannot be transferred to rail or other transport methods due to the nature of the freight and operations. That figure represents about 990 million tonnes of freight. This sector directly employs well over 177,000 people, which is about 49 per cent of transport employment.

According to the Road Transport Forum, based on the estimated operating cost increase of $6,400 per long haul vehicle and an average wage of $40,000 per annum for operators, one in six jobs throughout this sector alone will be lost as a consequence of this tax increase. Given our current levels of unemployment, that is a very significant figure and one which I would have thought the government would have taken into account. The Treasurer appears to have conveniently forgotten about it—or else he is totally unaware of that impact.

Thousands of individuals whose families depend on the small road transport business end of the industry will have to bear these unfair costs. Small transport companies make up the bulk of the industry. Approximate cost increases of $372 a week will be offset against possible government payments of only $8 a week. How can the government claim that this is a budget that will build jobs? It is a monstrous ruse and an enormous trick on the Australian population.

The proposed diesel and sales tax increases will result in an average 2.6 per cent increase in short haul operating costs and a 3.3 per cent increase in long haul operating costs. Some sectors will be asked to withstand increases of up to five per cent, which they will clearly be unable to do. Profits will be all but wiped out. Overall, the impact of these taxes on vehicle operating costs represents a total industry operating cost increase of $275 million a year. Whichever way we look at the equation, it is crystal clear that the diesel and sales tax increases proposed by the government cannot be absorbed by the road transport industry.

If we look at the Bureau of Industry Economics performance indicators on road transport from 1992, it is obvious that, in terms of tonnes per kilometre hauled, the major customer industries to road transport are the agricultural industry and the mining and building industries. Agriculture is predominantly export oriented, as well as domestic in nature, as is the mining sector. Neither can afford to sustain further tax increases handed down to them by the road transport industry.

The cold hard facts of day are that if costs are passed on by the transport industry, which it will have to do to survive, all consumers will pay an additional $2 to $3 for an ordinary sized shopping trolley of goods from the supermarket. Those living and working in rural, isolated and regional areas of Australia will suffer as industries are forced to the wall, relocate or close down. If industries relocate from regional areas to major cities because of the burden of these costs, pollution, congestion and the deterioration of the urban environment will increase.

Companies which do not relocate or close down, which instead elect to cut operating costs, will do so by reducing the repair and maintenance of their vehicles as well as by reducing employment. This will lead to older, less safe, less well-maintained vehicles travelling on our roads. These areas alone fly in the face of industry efforts to maximise fuel efficiency and use equipment manufactured to world environmental standards.

The road transport industry in particular believes it has been completely sold out by this Labor government, which has long promised to investigate the level of taxation it pays. The industry has every right to believe that. In the budget statement on 17 August the Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: The primary objective of this budget is jobs . . . this is a budget to strengthen the recovery and make it sustainable.

The Treasurer's moves to increase indirect taxes and charges which affect the productivity of industry do absolutely nothing to instil confidence in his claims. Australia is one of the largest countries in the world. Compared with the United States and Canada, it is much more sparsely settled. It is, therefore, arrant nonsense to compare our fuel prices with those of smaller European countries. Indeed, we should be aiming for lower fuel prices than either America or Canada. Unless the government initiates this, its claim to commitment to international competitiveness will be shown to be mere lip-service.

PARA.TAB: Australia should be seeking to have the cheapest road, rail and shipping transport costs, rather than imposing extra taxes on business inputs. Without the burden of taxes, the Australian transport industry would be the world leader in efficiency. But with the taxes and charges levied by this government, road transport efficiency in Australia has been relegated to a position well behind that of our major trading competitors.

In short, the scheduled diesel excise increases and wholesale sales tax increases will impact on rail and road safety, as well as social, economic and environmental concerns within our community. This government seems quite indifferent to this fact. It stands condemned for ignoring the pleas of industry groups struggling to maintain a standard of service and make a living in what are very difficult financial times.

What industry and thousands of voters collectively say is that they have no faith in this government to deliver economic prosperity. The Liberal and National parties stand firmly in support of that stance. Perhaps the height of this government's hypocrisy—and it is ironic—was when it so distorted the issues at the last federal election. Above all, it was the cost of fuel that would have been reduced so significantly under the Fightback package offered by the coalition, with a 24c per litre reduction in the price of fuel for business purposes and a 19c per litre reduction in the price of fuel for private use. This government promised no tax increases at the last election and it told lies about the coalition's proposals.

Yet at the first opportunity, we see the government heading in exactly the opposite direction to that in which we would have been heading under a coalition government. Instead of reducing the price of fuel, which is what this country desperately needs, this government is increasing the price of fuel. That is a lesson that I hope the voters of Australia have learnt. It is a lesson that I hope the voters of South Australia will be mindful of in the state election due in the next few months. When they are told similar lies by the state Labor government about what might happen under a Liberal government, they need to remember what happened under a Labor government immediately the election was out of the way.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993—one to increase the duties of customs and one to increase the duties of excise on tobacco and petroleum products. These bills mean that we are going to tax those products produced in this country and that we are going to tax those products that come into the country from outside. I take it that not a great deal is made of the increase in excise and customs on tobacco.
—If you are a tobacco farmer, there is.

—Senator McGauran says that the tobacco farmers are protesting about that. That is the point I want to make: they are protesting about it because it affects them. I do not smoke. In fact I disapprove of smoking; nevertheless, it is a legal activity. The tobacco farmers, as Senator McGauran says, protest about these increases because they are affected by them, and that is a reasonable position from their point of view. In saying that, Senator McGauran brings out the difficulty in this whole argument. Much was made in the speeches that preceded me about the effect that the increased taxes on petroleum products will have on a range of people and activities, just as an increase, according to Senator McGauran, in the tax on tobacco will have an effect on the tobacco farmers.
—The lowering of the tariff.

—I say to Senator Sherry that the difficulty is that no matter whom we tax, they will be affected. The argument we have heard tonight is really an argument that there should be no taxes at all on any activity or on any particular person.
—That is the Liberal Party's new policy.

—Senator Sherry's suggestion is right: it seems to be the coalition's new policy. I will illustrate the point that Senator Sherry, as usual, so ably makes. These two bills, one dealing with excise and the other dealing with customs, appear before us as separate bills because that is the constitutional requirement. We have had a series of bills which deal with the accounts of this country in a particular way. As each bill comes up for debate, protests are made. Senator McGauran made the shrewd observation that the tobacco farmers are protesting. Perhaps we should not tax tobacco because it will affect the tobacco farmers; we should not tax fuel because that will affect a range of people; when the wine tax came in, we must not tax the wine growers; when there is an increase in sales tax, that should not be allowed because we should not increase sales tax. The argument from those on the other side is not that the fuel taxes are the problem; the argument is that any tax is a problem.
—Except the GST.

—Except the GST. If those opposite had said, `There is a series of taxes. We understand that these are all part of a strategy to reduce the deficit, but when you come to the fuel tax, that is a problem and we think something ought to be done about that', that argument might have convinced people. It would not convince me; it does not convince this side, but it might reasonably convince people generally. But when the objection to the fuel tax is joined with an objection to any tax that is put up by the government, the problem arises as to whether or not the opposition has any real conviction in opposing this particular tax when it simply is one of a whole series of taxes that it has opposed.

PARA.TAB: As I understand what the opposition says, there must be a reduction of the deficit. That seems to be a matter of agreement across this house. If there is going to be no tax increase anywhere, and if we are going to have—as was promised by the government—a reduction in income tax, where is the money to come from?

TALK.START.PARA: —There are other ways of doing it.

—Senator Reid says that there are other ways of doing it. It would have helped this debate if people opposite had got up and said, `This is what you ought to do. You should not tax fuel, you should tax land', and so on.
—What about the $125 million capital expenditure in Canberra?

—The issue has become one of reducing the deficit by cutting expenditure. What is meant by the coalition when it uses the expression `cutting expenditure'? One suggestion from those opposite is that we should cut expenditure on the city of Canberra which—
—You do not spend any here any more.

—As Senator Reid has so clearly pointed out, we do not spend money on Canberra any more. So we have one member of the coalition who says, `Let us cut the expenditure you make on Canberra'. That might be the way we can do it. We reduce the money spent on Canberra—and we take it that Senator McGauran is well briefed in the party room and that his instructions were to come in here and shout across the room, `Reduce the expenditure that is going to be made on Canberra'. I think Senator West was noting that down. As she was, Senator Reid, a person who represents the ACT—and, may I say, very ably—said that there is no expenditure at all by this government on the ACT. This may be the problem we are facing from those opposite: they do not quite know what is going on. We have a demand to cut what cannot be cut because it was never there.

PARA.TAB: Senator McGauran also says that we should cut funding to the arts—cut those things that go towards making up the culture of this country. We need to work together as a nation, we need to pull together and we need to have that unity symbolised. What better way to do that than the arts? What caters for the heart and the soul—I thought Senator McGauran might be interested in things of the heart and the soul—better than the arts? Nevertheless, that is what he said should go.
Where else might the coalition cut? We might look at where other coalition governments have cut. For example, in Victoria, funding has been cut to schools, hospitals—

TALK.START.PARA: —Rural schools, too.

—Yes, rural schools, as well as kindergartens, child care, universities and research. We are supposed to become a clever country. That is where the opposition will make deficit reductions. It will cut the old age pension, and no doubt roads will go.
—You're one to be talking about cutting roads! You cut about $600 million off a $1.3 billion budget. Come on, Barney, be honest.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee is following me in this debate. He says that I have to be reasonable. I know that Senator O'Chee will be able to answer these questions as to where cuts will be made if they are going to be made. If they are not going to be made, how will we raise the revenue to carry out the normal affairs of the nation?

PARA.TAB: We talk about taxpayers, but we are not only taxpayers; we are citizens of a great and noble land and recipients of what that great and noble land gives us by way of public facilities, schooling, transport, the arts, hospitals and our old people being properly looked after. If the opposition is going to cut those areas, let us hear about it. If it is not going to cut those areas, where will the taxes come from? One of the answers is, `We don't have to worry about that because this is an exercise in punishment'. In the coalition's view, this government lied at the last election. That is an insult to the people of Australia, who are able to judge the realities. When this government does carry out its promises, as with the tax cuts, it is criticised.

Instead of getting up and making noble speeches about the rights and wrongs of things and generalities about what the people of Australia want and how the last election was conducted, those on the other side should do a bit of solid work. They should point out, firstly, whether or not they will increase any tax measures at all; secondly, whether they will reduce any expenditure; thirdly, whether they will do both; and, fourthly and most importantly, where and to what extent. Then there can be proper debate across the chamber.

If Senator O'Chee, with his acute mind, gets up and says that we should not impose taxes on petroleum products or increase customs and excise duties on petroleum and then explains where else we can get that amount from, the debate can go on. But instead we will get from those speaking after me a description of how the last election—which was in March this year, after all—was conducted. I would have thought the people of Australia would be interested in knowing what will happen in the future. But that is what we will hear. We will also hear about how badly people are affected by an increase in fuel taxes. I am sure anybody who has to pay an increase in tax, or tax at all, is affected. That is the reality of living in a society such as ours. If, on the other hand, there is a way through that can be properly put by the other side that maintains the overall strategy of this government—and, I understand, the overall strategy of the opposition—to reduce the deficit and at the same time keep us in the sorts of public services we all need, let us hear about how the opposition will do it and let us hear it with some particularity.

Senator O'Chee is straining at the leash. It will be interesting to hear what he has to say about this, with his ability as an economist. After Senator O'Chee has finished, Senator West will speak. I will leave it to Senator West to balance up what might otherwise be a very robust display that I hope does not stray too far from the realities with which we are faced.

TALK.START.PARA: —We should talk about the realities with which we are faced. The reality facing Australia today is that the people who sit opposite have taken the big stick to rural Australia and they are caning the people who live outside the capital cities. They are caning the people who produce the wealth that makes this country run. I ask Senator Cooney to please not leave this chamber. Senator Cooney—the great defender of people's civil liberties and the great defender of human rights—fails to understand that many of the people who are most severely hit by these bills and by the increases in fuel taxes are the very people who have the greatest distance to go. They also happen to be—this is quite an interesting fact—the people who live on the lowest median income.

PARA.TAB: Before coming into the chamber I got a publication from the Department of the Parliamentary Library entitled Comparisons of 1991 census characteristics: Commonwealth electoral divisions. This is an interesting document to read. At least the first 20 electorates—that is, the 20 electorates with the lowest median family income—all happen to be electorates that are outside capital cities. Wide Bay, Lyne, Cowper, Fisher, Richmond, Fairfax, Page, Gwydir, Barker, Wakefield, Maranoa, Mallee, Gilmore, Grey, Lyons, O'Connor, Braddon, Bendigo, Parkes and Hinkler are all electorates outside capital cities. These electorates have the lowest median family incomes. What is this government going to do? It will hit them with a massive fuel tax because they are the people who have to travel the greatest distance to get to work or to get to a doctor, a lawyer, an accountant or their local member of parliament. They are the people who will be paying more fuel tax and they are the people with the least money in their pockets.
This despicable government, this despicable collection of individuals on the other side of the chamber who claim to be interested in social justice and equity—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! You cannot use that adjective when speaking about members on the opposite side.
—I withdraw, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—In fact, you cannot use it when speaking about any members in this chamber.

—I withdraw, and say instead this collection of individuals who amazingly say that they are interested in social justice and equity. They are the people who are punishing regional Australia and the low income earners in this country. It is interesting that the people Senator West wants to hit in places such as Richmond have a median family income—this is for the whole family, both parents—of $24,528 a year. That is sick and depraved. That is the taxing regime of this government which comes before the chamber and says, `We want to increase the fuel tax on the people who are least able to pay it'. It is not just the fuel tax they pay at the bowser—and, heaven knows, they pay enough at the bowser. Those of us who live outside the capital cities know exactly what fuel tax does at the bowser. It is not the same price in Cairns, Wallabadah or Gippsland as it is in the capital cities. It is much higher.

PARA.TAB: Heaven knows, it is not just the impact at the bowser; it is the impact on the transport costs for the people who live in those electorates—the impact on the cost of every single thing that we buy in the supermarket. Members of the Labor Party ran around this country with their hearts on their sleeves—I will not say wearing them on their sleeves, but embroidered on their sleeves, because they were fake—telling us about how they were concerned about the cost of what people bought in the supermarkets. What does this bill do? It pushes up the cost of what people buy in the supermarkets by pushing up the cost of transport.

These are the people who have backed the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) who says that we have to have value adding and manufacturing in regional Australia. What will happen? This bill will make value adding and manufacturing in regional Australia a sick joke. The only defence that we heard from the other side is, `But we have to make up the deficit somehow'.

We were challenged on this side to come up with suggestions as to how we should cut the deficit. There is one very good way of cutting the deficit—it is not the only way—that those opposite, including Senator Cooney, for all his rhetorical eloquence, forgot. This government gives over $1,200 million a year in foreign aid, sometimes to the most preposterous causes. As Senator Panizza well knows, $17 million was given to Nelson Mandela. As Senator Harradine has acquainted the Senate on many occasions, we give millions of dollars to the government in mainland China so that it can do sex tests on children that will give people a better chance of aborting a girl than a boy. This is where our taxpayers' money has gone.

A few years ago we gave $43 million to the mainland Chinese government, supposedly in aid, because it was hard up for cash. What did it do? It bought a prime wool growing property on the border of Queensland and New South Wales for cash. Australian farmers are struggling to pay the interest—

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet the farmer did not knock back the money.

—Senator West says, `I bet the farmer did not knock back the money'. I will bet the farmer who sold the property was forced to sell it because the government drove interest rates through the roof. It pushed up the costs until, once again, yet another farmer went out the door. What is it doing in this bill?
—She is malicious.
—Senator West is malicious. The government is pushing up the costs yet again. I see that Senator West wants to take a point of order.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! Senator West may raise a point of order. I will announce the fact. You, Senator O'Chee, do not have to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I find the description of my behaviour as `malicious' offensive. I seek to have it withdrawn.
—I uphold the point of order. I ask Senator O'Chee to withdraw the comment.

—I withdraw. If it was not malicious, it had to be clearly negligent, and that is not a point Senator West can debate. Either this government does what it does by design or it does it through stupidity and ignorance; it is one or the other. It does not want to believe that it does it by design; it has to be by stupidity and ignorance. One would have to be stupid and ignorant to put massive costs on regional Australia, intolerable costs on business, and then complain that business is not employing people.

PARA.TAB: That is what this government does. It pushes up the costs, pushes them a little further, and stands back in amazement and surprise that yet another business has gone to the wall. Goodness gracious! How many businesses have gone to the wall because of this sick mentality on the government benches?

Let us talk about the cruise boat industry in far North Queensland. In Cairns alone the 5c per litre increase in the cost of the fuel tax that will flow from this bill will add $600,000 a year to the operating costs of the biggest cruise boats in that industry. That $600,000 does not include the small fishing boats or the small cruise boats, just the big ones. They cannot make up that money by upping the price or pushing up costs. The government seems to think that that is all it has to do. That money comes straight out of their profits. That $600,000 comes straight off the top. What a great achievement from this government! It will get $600,000 from the big operators in the cruise boat industry in Cairns alone.

Let us look at the Mourilyan sugar terminal. Struggling canegrowers and a struggling sugar industry are trying desperately to compete because this government has pushed up their costs, reduced tariffs and thrown this country open to subsidised sugar from overseas, should importers wish to bring it into this country. What will it do? For the Mourilyan bulk sugar terminal alone it will mean an extra $80,000 in fuel costs, because all that sugar—bar sugar from one mill—has to come in by truck.

Surprise, surprise! The people on the government benches forgot about it. Maybe they did not know about it. Maybe they ought to wake up and look at the real world. We are asked to look at the real world. This is the real world: people's jobs and people's industries. I am amazed that government senators did not understand that this is what it was going to do. Perhaps they understood, but they just did not care.

This increase will impact not just on North Queensland. I was in northern New South Wales recently. This fact might jolt Senator West: there will be hundreds of thousands of dollars in additional operating costs for the sugar mills in northern New South Wales at places such as Condong, Broadwater and Harwood. Think about them. Think about what electorates they are in. You hold them now. You will not hold them in three years because you, as a government, despicably misled the people in those electorates. These bills will cost them hundreds of thousands of dollars.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee, direct your remarks to the chair.

—This government despicably misled the people of northern New South Wales in those two electorates. Hundreds of thousands of dollars will come off the profits of the sugar industry just through the transport costs on those three mills alone. The sixth poorest electorate in the country is Richmond. The seventh poorest electorate in the country is Page. Those electorates are in regional Australia. That is the human face of this government's dreadful decision making.
