That is the human face of this government's putting up tax and gobbling other people's money.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cooney said that we are the inheritors of a great legacy in this nation. We are, but will we pass on a great legacy in this nation? No. Why not? It is because the wealth upon which that great legacy was built is being taxed out of existence by the Labor government.

Senator Cooney was foolish enough, or perhaps naive enough, to raise the issue of road funding. He suggested that the coalition would have cut road funding. I have the greatest respect for Senator Cooney. He would not deliberately tell a lie. Maybe he was ill-informed or did not read. This government has just cut $600 million off a $1.6 billion road funding budget in just one year. These people make Jack the Ripper look like a second-rate seamstress, for goodness sake!

There has been a $600 million cut in a $1.6 billion road funding budget. At the same time the government is upping fuel tax by another 5c a litre. What happened to the concept of the fuel tax paying for the roads? According to Senator Richardson, that `hypothecation'—he uses that lovely word because he does not want anyone to understand what he is talking about—never existed. Goodness gracious! He could have fooled me.

I represent cruise boat operators in Queensland. My colleagues in other states represent them as well. Senator Gibson represents cruise boat operators and trawler operators and so on in Tasmania. Senator Panizza, Senator McGauran, Senator Parer from Queensland and Senator Sandy Macdonald all have constituents in either the cruise industry or the fishing industry who pay enormous amounts of fuel tax. But they never use their boats on the roads.

Surprise, surprise! When was the last time honourable senators saw a trawler heading down the highway? Never. But this government does not have any qualms about putting up tax. It does not have any qualms about putting up costs. It does not have any qualms about telling any story it wants.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Democrats?
—What about the Democrats? That is a good question, Senator McGauran.
—Where are they?

—Well, they are not here in the chamber because they have already done their deal with the government. These are the people who tried to tell the electorate that they were going to stand up to the government and be the only true opposition. What have they agreed to? They have agreed to the sales tax hikes. They have agreed to the fuel tax. They have agreed to all sorts of tax increases that this government has brought in. The only time they looked like they were going to stand up straight was in relation to the increase in tax on the wine industry. Now they have rolled over and gone with the government.

PARA.TAB: It is no surprise that the Democrats wanted to support the government in relation to the increase in fuel tax. That was one of their election policies. That was what they went to the people on. Unlike this government, they actually had the honesty to say, `We want to push up your fuel tax'. But that was not something they said terribly loudly when they went out into the rural constituency—no siree. That was not something they wanted the rural people to know. That was not something they wanted to shove down their throats. That was not something that they were campaigning on out there. Back in the cities, where it does not have so much of an impact, they at least had the honesty to say it—and that is better than we can say for this government. But that is why they are going along with it.

One has to ask oneself: at the end of all this, do we really need a 5c a litre increase in fuel tax; do we really need to add millions of dollars to the operating costs of the road transport industry as a whole and thousands of dollars to the cost of single road transport hauliers? No, we do not need to do that. We do not need to push up the cost of groceries in regional Australia. We do not need to push up the cost of the sugar industry. We do not need to push up the cost of the fishing industry or the cruise boat industry. We do not need to push up the cost on the transport of wool. Goodness gracious—how much are woolgrowers getting?

TALK.START.PARA: —Here are the Greens.

—I understand that the Greens are going to support it. I listened with great interest to what Senator Margetts had to say. I did not agree with her, but at least she was trying to rationalise. But not even the Greens believed that the government was going to pump this into cleaning up the environment. They do not even—
—And quite right.

—Senator Chamarette says I am quite right. The Greens do not even trust the government to make such a promise. The Greens want an amendment to force the government to put this in the legislation. But they were not naive enough to believe that the government would put in a 5c a litre increase; they were pumping for 1c a litre. I bet they would be lucky to get that because this government knows only one thing—
—Spend.

—Spend and tax. But how much tax will come from an electorate like Wide Bay where the median family income is $23,653 a year? There is not a lot. There is not a lot if one is a struggling farmer from Lyne or Cowper. There is not a lot if one is a struggling wheat grower from Gwydir.

PARA.TAB: Is it not surprising that the people who are most severely hit are the people who are not, on the whole, in Labor Party electorates. It is not surprising that the same tired old government is pushing up the taxes on the productive sector in the hope that it will pay the burden.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, how would you cut costs?

—We have already heard how we would cut costs. Maybe we should stop the grants to the trade unions. That would be a good one; that would be a very positive one. I will be pleased to hear whether Senator West is willing to cut the grants to the trade unions.
—Or the ILO.

—Or the ILO. I bet the government is not interested in doing that. Of course it is not. The government has to pay off its mates? It is going to do so by getting the money from somebody else. The government is not going to pay off its mates with its own money; it gets it from somebody else.
—You were real good at paying off your mates back in the`60s and`70s.
—Senator Murphy brings before the chamber an astounding interjection. It must have taken him all of 20 minutes to dream it up and it is not worth 20 seconds of comment.

PARA.TAB: This government is sick; this government is depraved. This bill will punish the productive people. This bill will punish those of us who live outside the capital cities. This bill will push up the costs of people who live north of the Daintree, for example, who do not even have electricity. They have to use diesel fuel to generate electricity. The government did not remember them. It did not remember the low income earners. It did not remember the people who live outside the capital cities—no siree. This sick government is doing the only thing it knows; that is, tax and spend, and there is nothing left. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney in his contribution tonight summed up what we could expect from the opposition. He was correct when he said that there will be very little in alternatives put forward by the opposition.
—Yet again.
—`Yet again', says Senator Loosley. The only one we have heard from Senator O'Chee was that we should cut the foreign aid spending.
—And the ILO.
—And the ILO. Fine—that is great; good. And the trade unions as well. We have just shored up about three-quarters of the votes we need from all our friends for the next election.

PARA.TAB: I want to discuss the issue of fuel pricing. I get a lot of comments and information about the cost of fuel.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet you do.

—Senator Parer might care to look at and listen to the comments that I am getting from the rural people in two different states about the price differentials between city and country areas. I am told by a constituent who last week or the week before was in Bundaberg that petrol in Bundaberg is 18c a litre cheaper than petrol in Orange. Orange is less that 300 kilometres from Sydney, which is the fuel distribution point. I do not know how far Bundaberg is from its nearest distribution point, but I would consider that it is probably a significant distance away—a lot further than Orange is. Yet petrol is 18c a litre cheaper in Bundaberg than it is Orange. No-one can tell me why this is so.

PARA.TAB: I know that there are state differentials and state taxes. I think the fuel taxes in New South Wales are about 6c a litre dearer than the taxes imposed in Queensland. But that still leaves 12c to be accounted for.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your point.
—The point is that there is a huge price differential and it is affecting people out there in the rural areas. People are blaming the government; they are not looking at the other potential sources.

PARA.TAB: Wally Mitchell, the highly respected chairman of the shires association—if he is not a member of the National Party at present he certainly has been on previous occasions; he is not a member of the Labor Party—estimates that the transportation component in getting fuel around most parts of New South Wales is at the most 4c. Yet we see price differentials that range from 65c in Sydney to 84c in Bourke. That is a difference of 19c a litre. How can that be accounted for?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no price war in Bourke.

—The 65c that is being paid in Sydney is not the result of a price war. That is what appears to be the general amount at the bowsers. I am sure my colleagues from Sydney will tell me that petrol is certainly not more than 70c a litre. I know that in Bathurst it is 77.9c and in Orange 78.9c.
—In some parts of Sydney it is 59c.

—In some places in Sydney where there is a price war it is 59c. We in the country areas are not getting the benefits of that. We should not be asking what the government has been doing. Rather, we should be asking why there is anything up to a 19c to 20c price differential between fuel purchased by people living in city areas and people living in country areas. That is the issue that people should be addressing.

PARA.TAB: The government chose to address this issue by referring in May of this year the to the Industry Commission a matter relating to the petroleum industry. I would encourage everybody to make sure that they monitor this reference very closely. I have been encouraging as many people as possible from rural areas to make submissions to the Industry Commission. It is of vital importance that we encourage the Industry Commission to look very closely at precisely what this issue is and why this price differential exists.

We are asking the commission to report on institutional, regulatory—including environmental and safety issues—and other arrangements subject to influence by governments in Australia. We are also asking the commission to look at the current structure and competitiveness of the industry, including cost and pricing structures, and the scope for improving the efficiency of the industry.

These are the sorts of things that will help Australia's fuel users, particularly in the rural areas, as opposed to us sitting here being critical, slinging off at one another and trying to score points when points do not need to be scored. We need to get to the real nub of the issue, which is why there is this huge price differential.

People do not like paying more for commodities than they have to, but in this area we know that something funny is happening. One has only to listen to Matt Abraham on the ABC morning program to know that, in the week leading up to school holidays, the petrol prices in Canberra suddenly start to go up. They remain at their highest levels during school holidays. But what happens when school holidays finish? We start to have price wars again. These are the sorts of things that I hope the Industry Commission can get to the bottom of. By removing this apparent manipulation, these price discrepancies and these fluctuations, we will do more for industry in this country and more for rural people than any other contribution that we may care to make.

I ask whether honourable senators can tell me why it is that, on occasions, petrol can be cheaper in White Cliffs than in Broken Hill. If they can answer that question, then they have solved a lot of riddles. White Cliffs is far more isolated than Broken Hill and further away from the refining sources. In Tamworth fuel is 78c a litre. Tamworth does not get its fuel from Sydney; it comes from Brisbane, yet it still happens to be more expensive because it appears that the further away one gets from Sydney, the higher the price of fuel. The same thing happens in smaller places outside Dubbo or Orange. The price of fuel is 1c or 2c a litre cheaper than it is in the major centres.

These are the issues that I want to look at. These are the issues that have to be addressed and, I am sure, will be addressed in the Industry Commission inquiry. I urge everybody who has an interest in this matter to make sure that they monitor what happens in the Industry Commission inquiry, to get a hold of the draft report when it comes out next year and continue to make submissions to ensure that the Industry Commission investigates fully these price differentials in fuel that cannot be accounted for and that are passed off as being part of transport costs.
A small article in the Goulburn Post of 12 October, referring to the Premier of New South Wales, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fahey is convinced that the price differential in country areas is the result of freight costs and pricing policies by individual service stations . . .
I do not know about the last bit, but he is certainly at odds with some other people whom I have read about or spoken to in various areas around this state.

PARA.TAB: I close by saying that we have seen nothing further from this opposition as an alternative for fundraising, budget balancing or anything else. As usual, it is bereft of ideas and can do nothing but be negative in all of its forms. We are aware that there are problems within the fuel industry. We have asked the Industry Commission to look at it.

We must be aware that with respect to the petrol pricing issue, the states have some responsibility because they put their imposts on. We also need to be aware that a lot of questions need to be asked and answered elsewhere within the industry. That is one reason why I would urge all people involved with and concerned about this issue to watch very carefully and to monitor and to contribute to the Industry Commission report. It will benefit fuel pricing in this country more than anything else that I can think of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before Senator West leaves the chamber—and I consider Senator West to be one of the more reasonable senators on the other side of the house—I would like to put her straight on a few things. She compared the price of fuel in Bundaberg with that in Orange and wanted to know why Bundaberg, which is farther from Brisbane, was cheaper. Unless I am wrong, Bundaberg is a port. It is the same in Western Australia. Fuel is definitely cheaper in Esperance, Albany, Geraldton and Karratha than it is in places such as Merredin in the central wheat belt, which is where I come from. It is because they are ports.

PARA.TAB: Senator West was under another misapprehension. She said that petrol in White Cliffs, which is a smaller town, is cheaper than Broken Hill, which is a bigger town. There is an obvious and easy explanation for this: that small place probably has far fewer overheads than the bigger town and it probably has service stations run by mums and dads. The same situation applies in any of those places along the Great Eastern Highway in Western Australia. Senator West should compare apples with apples—not apples with oranges.

TALK.START.PARA: —The one at White Cliffs is run with a diesel fuel generator, so that statement you made is not right.
—Before I get into this debate any further, I declare my interest as a rather large diesel fuel user. Having got that out of the road, let me read you—
—Is Senator Murphy on the speakers list? If not, he should put himself on it. In his budget speech, Treasurer Dawkins said:

SPEECH.PARA: The primary objective of this budget—
that is, the 1993 budget—

is jobs: jobs in the short term by providing a further fiscal stimulus to the economy this year—to sustain Australia's economic growth until the motor of world recovery kicks in. And jobs in the medium and longer term by boosting the capacity of Australian businesses to expand production on a world-competitive basis. This is a budget to strengthen the recovery and make it sustainable.

Treasurer Dawkins then spoke of Australia becoming more competitive and of the need to remove Australia's inherited tyranny of distance. He does not have to explain to me the tyranny of distance, as I come from a remote area of Western Australia. What has he done? He has given Australia the tyranny of taxes. We are debating the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill, which raise an extra $1.55 billion in a full year.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cooney said that our arguments go back to last March. In the last three months, Senator Ray, Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Collins have gone back to 1982. Senator Murphy should check the Hansard to see that this is so. We have committed the crime of going back to March. Our position was very transparent last March. We had the Fightback package, which stated what Australia would get if it elected us—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was honest.

—It was honest and costed. But this government was not. It told Australia that there would be no new taxes and no increased taxes. The sales tax bills we debated recently will raise another $1 billion. The bills we are debating tonight will raise an extra $1.55 billion. Where is this money coming from? It is mainly coming from the roads, through fuel. Australia runs on fuel. It runs on nothing else, and 80 or 90 per cent is diesel fuel. That is what it runs on. The government is throwing its net around, trying to gain more revenue, rather than attacking spending. It wants to get the money from the people who keep Australia going. That is the problem. It goes into transport and transport goes into everything else. Everything in Australia, one way or another, is concerned with transport. We cannot get away from that. Whether it is in Canberra or in Sydney, at one stage every item is transported, even if it is in a wheelbarrow. The government will increase the sales tax on the wheelbarrow and on the tyres on it.

PARA.TAB: These bills will impose an additional 5c per litre excise on diesel fuel, which is a mere 19 per cent increase on the existing excise. I might have forgiven the government if it had increased it along the lines of the CPI, but it had told people there would be no increase. This additional 5c will be implemented through an extra 3c from 17 August—which has already gone—1c in February and 1c in August 1994.

Of course, there are special provisions in respect of unleaded fuel. Australia moved towards the use of more unleaded fuel when we were importing five-year-old cars from Japan that used such fuel. Do honourable senators remember that? Former Senator Button, friend of the motor industry of Australia, decided to put an impost of $12,000 on such cars. In that action he was supported by all the Labor senators, by the Democrats, and at that time by the one Green senator. Those imports were stopped, otherwise we would have had more cars in Australia using unleaded fuel. I understand that the government is now thinking of undoing that situation.

I do not need to underline the fact that the road transport industry is vital to Australia's economic performance and therefore to community wellbeing. The federal government itself recognised this when it conducted an inquiry which led to the setting up of the National Road Transport Commission to rationalise transport in Australia and bring down costs. After all, the transport sector in Australia contributes about five per cent of GDP and employs 385,000 people directly. Then, of course, there is the flow-on effect. The road transport component alone contributes 2.4 per cent of GDP. One sees from the figures that road transport moves 75 per cent of all freight nationally, directly employs 177,000 people and contributes $6 billion to our gross national product. Yet again the government is getting stuck into that industry.
I believe in shifting goods from road to rail, but even the rail experts agree that 70 per cent of Australia's goods have to be transported by road.

TALK.START.PARA: —We haven't got rail—that's the problem.
—We have not got rail because of the short-haul traffic. Some 70 per cent of Australia's goods travel less than 70 kilometres. It is hardly worth while putting those goods on to rail.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the effect of these cost increases. When one increases the costs of road transport, there are two things that the industry can do. First, it can pass the costs on to the consumer. That is what will happen because the industry cannot absorb any more. We have already been told how the cost of an average shopping basket will increase by about $3 when these excise increases are passed on. Secondly, if the industry cannot pass it on, then it has to absorb it and cut costs somewhere else.

Australian road transport operates on a profit margin of about two per cent. That means for the operator a rise in costs of about 2 1/2 per cent. The government will wipe out any sort of profit operators may make. Having arrived at that situation, what do the operators do next? I am still in the transport game and so I know what they will do. In order not to eat into their margins, they have to cut costs further, make their vehicles and their tyres last a bit longer and service vehicles a bit less frequently. In other words, operators have to start cutting the costs of their plant. The plant then gets run down and is nowhere near as efficient. One of the worst things is that the plant may not be as safe on the road as it should be. If operators buy less new plant and equipment, it affects manufacturers and distributors all the way down the line. However, the government does not believe all this will happen.

I will give the Senate a rough breakdown of the impact of these increases on road transport operating costs. For example, the fuel taxes and levies will rise two per cent in the short haul urban operations and more than three per cent in the long haul operations. The total industry operating cost increase will be $275 million a year. However, the impact will differ from one industry sector to the other. That is the situation if one increases the costs of transport in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —But what did they do in the past? This isn't the first increase in fuel tax.
—There were other ways in the past. Those opposite promised that there would be no new taxes and no increased taxes. I remind the honourable senator that this is an increased tax.

PARA.TAB: What will these increases in fuel taxes do to our international competitiveness? After all, our Fightback package was all about getting the costs of our exporters down so that we can compete with overseas competitors. I have a graph showing vehicle operating costs in Australia compared with those in the United Kingdom, Canada and the United States, countries with which we compete. If one includes the fuel tax increases and other related charges, one discovers that we run a bad third. If one excludes those increases, Australia is well in front. As a result of the imposition of these provisions on the industry, Australia is killing off its competitive edge. What does this increase in road transport costs do to value added processes in the city or offshore?

TALK.START.PARA: —Operators go offshore.
—Of course, they fall short and go offshore. So what were the members of this government thinking about when they put together this budget?

PARA.TAB: Let me turn the Senate's attention to the subject of road funding. Senator Cooney dared to mention road funding, which is one of my favourite subjects. I cannot remember his exact words, but I think he said we on this side would cut road funding. Senator O'Chee picked up this point, but let us get back to what this government has done. This budget has cut road funding in Australia by $600 million in the last financial year. In the Fightback package we were going to give increased road funding. The 7c levy on fuel would have all gone back to roads and given a 20 per cent rise in funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Murphy might think this funny, but he was not here at the time. Some of the giggling advisers that this government has got should have been here to listen to the debate. All people should take this matter seriously. Under Fightback we were going to increase funding, even though Senator Cooney says the coalition intended to cut road funding. He wanted to know where we were going to get our money from and what we intended to do. The answer is that it was all spelt out in the Fightback package for everyone to see.

PARA.TAB: This legislation also delivers a knock to the mining industry. The government has given Australia's really big export earner a thump around the ear. Of course, the mining industry will not get the full rebate for fuel that is used off-road. My understanding at present is that the industry gets back 23c of the 26c-odd in the dollar as a rebate which will be cut further by this budget. That is for the actual mining operations, digging pits and so on, but when it comes to operating the treatment plant there is no rebate whatsoever.
Another element that the government picked up on was the diesel fuel rebate administration fee. Going back to 1957 when a levy was put on fuel to maintain roads—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who put it on?

—The Menzies government put it on. It was an admirable thing to do because it was used to maintain and bituminise roads around Australia, but any fuel used off-road was rebated. That system remained from 1957 until this Labor government came to power. When this Labor government came to power it decided to have some of it itself. So instead of the 7c that should be going on roads, this government is spending less than 6c. Twenty-six cents minus five or six leaves you with 20c in your pocket.

PARA.TAB: Now the government has imposed an administration fee. It claims that those who pay for the diesel fuel used in off-road operations are able to claim it back under the legislation. This government is giving us back our own money and calling it an aid to industry. It has brought in an administration charge to administer our money that it has had the use of, interest free, for months on end. And I can tell honourable senators from my experience that it is a minimum of two months.

This government has fallen flat on its face. Senator McMullan thinks he knows as much about taxation as Senator Watson does. He failed to pick up the fact that this administration fee would be tax deductible as a measure for ongoing business. It is a deductible item against one's income. The fee will raise $4.4 million from farmers and $5.5 million from the mining industry—a total of $9.9 million. How much of that is the government really going to get? It just shows how this government rushes in to see where it can get the extra dollar without doing its homework.

In the committee stage of this debate I am going to ask Senator McMullan exactly what the final result of that $9.9 million is, allowing for the fact that it is tax deductible—and it is tax deductible; I have had enough expert opinion from chartered accountants around the place that it is. So the government might in the final analysis still have fallen on its face.

The government stands condemned for bringing in such an administration charge on the basis of one per cent. Some farmers and other operators may lodge claims for $3,000, $4,000 or $5,000. I suppose they are fairly tedious claims to process in an office. But when a mining company lodges a claim that is worth $1 million, and there are plenty of mining companies that use more than $1 million worth of diesel fuel a week, a clerk only has to yea or nay for that one invoice—one does not even send an invoice thanks to former Senator Button's last amendment; I will give him that—and an administration fee of $10,000 is charged. That is totally ridiculous. If the government wants such a system it should at least charge people what it costs.

The government stands condemned on this legislation which imposes some $1.5 billion of extra taxes when it promised the taxpayers of Australia, who foolishly elected it, that there would be no new taxes and no extra taxes. Those opposite will be reminded of this every day that they sit in government until they are thrown out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 set out to increase the price of leaded fuel, unleaded fuel, unleaded petrol distillate and fuel oil. It is worth reminding the Senate of the increases that apply to distillate. There is an additional 5c per litre increase on diesel, or a 19 per cent increase in the existing rate of 26.73c per litre implemented through 1993, 1994 and 1995.

PARA.TAB: These bills are the by-product of the most dishonest political campaign probably in our history. The Labor Party promised the people of Australia that they would have tax cuts. In fact, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) went to great lengths to question the journalists when they queried him on this: did they not understand that this was already law? But no mention whatsoever was made of the fact that if the government was successful in the election it would go for this massive increase in taxes.

No matter what pious protestations we get to the contrary, that was the understanding of the Australian people. It is no good Labor members of parliament, Labor senators, Labor ministers getting up and saying, `We did not say we would not have any tax increases. We said there would be no new taxes'. That was dishonest. The understanding of the people of Australia was that there would be no tax hikes.

Who from the Labor side of parliament said during the election campaign that they would increase taxes on the price of fuel, that they would increase wholesale sales taxes and so on? These tax increases are at a time of the worst unemployment since the great depression and, I might say regrettably, with not a glimmer of light at the end of the tunnel that will make our import replacement and export businesses that much more competitive. They are just another nail in the coffin of the economic malaise inflicted on our country by yet another discredited Labor government, this time at a national level.

Great efforts have been made in recent years by industries to contain and reduce their costs to remain competitive. What they cannot control, however, are costs such as government imposts which introduce a major element of uncertainty into investment decisions, be they for expansion or new development. It raises again that matter of sovereign risk. The mining industry is the only major industry in Australia today which has saved the economy from total collapse. It is in the main export oriented and has the greatest potential for value added, something that I personally have been promoting for some 20-odd years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are ignoring tourism, Senator.

—I am glad that Senator Crowley interjected on tourism because the diesel price increases which the government has introduced will affect the tourism industry as well. Certainly there has been a growth in tourism and certainly that is something that we should nurture, but why does this government introduce taxes on successful industries? It seems to have some sort of a penchant to say, `If they are successful let us tax them'. The net result is that it ends up destroying them.

PARA.TAB: As I was saying, with few exceptions on the value added side—one is aluminium—the potential for value added has never been fully realised. It is not through want of trying. Many feasibility studies have been done over the years but the figures do not add up. I know that people within the industry would like nothing more than to go into value added. These sorts of tax increases help make the projects that are being studied even less feasible. I will concentrate on the mining industry and not regurgitate what other people have said. Senator Watson mentioned Savage River, an open cut mine approaching the end of its life with a feasibility which now is apparently doomed in the process of studying an underground operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know if that's correct.

—There will be a loss, if it does occur, of 300 jobs, which is a disaster for a place like Tasmania where Senator Murphy comes from. Let me tell honourable senators a bit about Savage River, because it is not just the mine at Savage River; it is not just the fact that 300 jobs will be lost. The mine exports from Port Latta and has been going for quite a long time. It used to be run by Mitsubishi.
—Where is it?
—If Senator Murphy wants to know any more about it he should keep asking questions.

PARA.TAB: For Senator Murphy's information, this mine produces a different type of iron ore than what is produced in the Pilbara. Hematite is produced in the Pilbara and magnetite is produced at Savage River. Magnetite has a unique property in that after being magnetised it does not retain its magnetism. For this reason, some 100,000 tonnes a year is used in the coalmining industry. The ore is crushed into a powder and it is used to adjust the specific gravity of water for fine coal recovery. It is then recovered on magnetic rollers and recycled—the very thing that people say should be done.

With the premature closing of Savage River, we will probably be back to the old days of the importation of magnetite. This is worth in the order of $5 million to $10 million a year—yet another nail in the coffin of the balance of payments and foreign debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are talking about it as though it is going to close, and you don't know that.

—For Senator Murphy's interest, the reason why the magnetite was imported in years gone by was that the cost of transportation by sea was so high that it was cheaper to bring it in from Canada than to bring it up from Port Latta.

PARA.TAB: One of the other things those smart people on the other side have done is penalise the shipping industry, which carts magnetite from Port Latta to New South Wales and Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it different shipping from Canada, Senator? If it is, spell it out.

—Senator Crowley is either showing the most incredible amount of ignorance or she is not listening to what I have had to say. In years gone by it was not imported from Tasmania because of the price of coastal shipping.
—Now you add the word `coastal', which is the word that was necessary. Now you make it understandable.
—Mr Deputy President, I know that Senator Crowley has great difficulty understanding. Let us not repeat it three times.
—You should be honest about the closure of Savage River Mine.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, if Senator Murphy wants to get up and try to defend his government on its attack on our import replacement and export industries, please invite him to do so.
—Our record stands. There has been a 25 per cent increase since 1983.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. We have found Senator Murphy amusing for most of this evening, but I suggest that you ask him to observe standing orders and allow Senator Parer, who does have an intelligent contribution to make, to make it without Senator Murphy's mindless interjections.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! I remind Senator Murphy that excessive interjections are out of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I really did not need any protection from Senator Murphy. In fact, I was looking on him as exhibit A.
—Senator Parer, you should not encourage interjections.

—Now let us move to Nabalco. Nabalco mines bauxite at Gove and goes to the trouble of using fuel oil to convert that raw material bauxite into alumina. In the process it requires substantial quantities of fuel oil. In fact, it has been pointed out by Nabalco that it uses over 60 per cent of total inland consumption and around 45 per cent of total fuel oil subject to duty in Australia.

PARA.TAB: That company is going to the next stage of value adding—it is converting bauxite into alumina. Yet what does this fuel oil price increase do to Nabalco? It increases its costs by $25 million a year. If that is not an encouragement for that company to say, `Why do we bother? Why not just move the bauxite across to Indonesia or somewhere else and convert it to alumina?', what is? Bear in mind that what Nabalco does is bring in the fuel oil directly by ship from a source of supply overseas. It hardly touches the coast of Australia without it being used to convert bauxite into alumina, in the value added process, and then Nabalco goes into the export business—another export industry hit by this impost.

The remarks made by Nabalco are interesting. One point that is very important is sovereign risk. When one invests in a major project, it is important that the rules that are laid down for that major project are not changed because massive amounts of capital have to be invested. This heightens the sovereign risk of investing in mining and minerals processing in Australia.

The question is often asked: why does Nabalco not use natural gas? The Northern Territory government did propose that Nabalco should use natural gas, but on all the offers made it was less competitive. Even if it was competitive today, because of all the other associated problems that did not exist in those days, it would probably be impossible because that pipeline would run through a lot of Aboriginal lands, heritage areas and so on.

The other thing that I think is important to recognise is that companies like Nabalco—and what I am saying is not limited to Nabalco; it covers anyone in the export industry whether they be wool producers, suppliers of coal to the export markets, or suppliers of anything in the export market—cannot increase the price because of government imposts. They must go along with world market prices. Everyone is aware of the fact that commodity prices are depressed. No-one is forecasting any massive increases. Even if anyone were, when these out of field imposts proposed by the government come in, they make life more difficult for those involved in the export industry. The fuel excise cannot be passed on.

The other thing that I think is worth drawing attention to is the fact that it is common knowledge today that there will be no more aluminium smelters in Australia. For a country that is so rich in energy, that is an absolute disgrace. The only increase we are seeing is the expansion of QAL at Gladstone. That is simply an extension of the pipelines. But it has been made very clear to me by all the people involved in smelting—there are not that many, but those who are—that any future smelter will happen overseas.

These are the sorts of things that this government should take on board. I mentioned earlier, following an interjection from Senator Murphy or maybe it was Senator Crowley—I do not know which—the submission made by the National Maritime Association. With all the SIRA reform programs under way and with the reduction in the level of the work force in shipping where savings of $270,000 had been made per ship—these things do not come easily; they come with years of negotiation with unions that are notoriously militant—

TALK.START.PARA: —Four years.

—Four years. They have reached that stage. Suddenly, the reduction per ship of some $270,000 has been wiped out and another $90,000 added to the cost per ship. For many years I have often questioned why a country like Australia—an island continent; one of the great trading nations—has never been able to have a decent merchant navy. It was always because our work conditions did not match those of the rest of the world and the manning levels on ships were too high. In fact, it is not so many years ago that when the Japanese, Koreans and other people were bringing in ships—not the rust bucket type ships—with crews of 19 and 20, the level on Australian ships was 45 and 46. They have got that level down and they get torpedoed by the government that is supposed to represent them. How do those opposite think the Seamen's Union feels now? What does it do?

PARA.TAB: Another item I would like to cover is the price of gas. One might ask, `What has the price of gas got to do with the fuel price increase?'. It is another unintended consequence of this dishonest tax because many of the people who made arrangements for the supply of natural gas had the price determined tied to the price of fuel oil, which included excises. This is the case, I understand, in Western Australia and it is certainly the case at Queensland Alumina in Gladstone. Just for interest, I would like to refer to a submission made by Queensland Alumina. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Following commissioning in 1957 QAL's refinery was the lowest cost producer in the world.
That is why it went there. That is why in the future the only way we will get industry in Australia is if those parameters come back in as they did in 1957. The submission further states:

This fact undoubtedly contributed to three major increases in plant capacity during the late 60's and early 70's. QAL's Gladstone refinery is now the largest alumina refinery in the world producing approximately 9% of world requirements.
It goes on to say:

Throughout the 1980's, however, with the advent of newer competing plants with modern technology QAL slipped significantly in world competitiveness. A concerted effort by all members of the workforce over the past six years has resulted in an improvement in competitiveness. . .

Mr Acting Deputy President, because of the fuel price hikes in the 1970s, do you know what QAL did? It switched to gas. Do you know what its gas agreement was? It was tied to the price of fuel oil, including excises. So yet again we have a major industry with another nail in its coffin because of an impost by a government which does not give a damn about import replacement, does not give a damn about exports and obviously does not give a damn about employment.

PARA.TAB: What we are seeing with, for example, Nabalco is pressure to sell bauxite on its own and not go into the value adding that this country so desperately needs and which this coalition offered in its Fightback program. That is what it was all about. We are berated by this government for opposing these tax increases, which we and the rest of Australia know is the height of utter responsibility; that is, if the government has any heart and it is worried about the million people out of work. Why is the government now destroying the very industries that can generate real jobs? The damage being done by this government is such that I regret to say it will take years to recover.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Customs Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 and the Excise Tariff (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 which are concerned with the increases in levy on oils—petrols, diesel and fuel oil. My major concern is to put into context these proposals with regard to the general investment climate here in Australia.

PARA.TAB: While our major problems in Australia are unemployment, the lack of true economic growth, and rises in incomes, the government's budget really does nothing to address these major concerns for the longer term and does nothing to encourage investment in this country. In fact, quite the contrary. The government's budget encourages higher costs to business and these additional levies on oil and fuels are good examples of that. As a consequence, it makes Australia less attractive for investment and hence the chances of us getting higher growth in employment and lower unemployment are receding into the future.

To put this into context, I want to talk about the investment climate here in Australia. I think there are two major matters which have yet to really sink into the consciousness of the Australian community. Those two matters are, firstly, globalisation and, secondly, the huge growth of the East Asian economies.

With regard to globalisation, I am really talking about the fact that, in all of our markets, we in Australia are now part of the world economy and can no longer look at ourselves in isolation. Since the freeing up of the exchange rate and the freeing up of our finance markets over 10 years ago, all businesses in Australia, regardless of whatever protection they have had in the past, are being forced to be internationally competitive—some slowly, some quickly. This is also having effects on governments with government businesses also being forced to be internationally competitive.

The implications for the Australian economy are that we all have to be efficient and we have to look to being internationally competitive with industries outside Australia and to servicing the world market. It is from that context that investments in Australia or any other part of the world will derive. In other words, if Australia is attractive for investment, if we are the lowest cost producer and provide good service, then investment will take place, be it from Australian or overseas dollars.

The other critical factor that has not sunk into the Australian consciousness is, I believe, the huge size and growth of the East Asian market. East Asia contains 1.7 billion people. It has had a GDP growth of over six to seven per cent a year in the last five to 10 years and the expectations for the rest of this decade are that its growth will be at least six to seven per cent a year, which means a per capita growth in real terms of four to five per cent a year. To put that into context for us here in Australia, we are talking about an annual growth to the north of us of two Australian economies per year.

We have no choice here in Australia but to face outwardly to the world and to face up to being competitive with East Asia. Mind you, the government does not like us making comparisons with East Asia, particularly on tax regimes, and insists on comparing us with the OECD. But what are the OECD countries doing? They are working hard to contain their budget deficits, they are endeavouring to encourage savings and they are also endeavouring to deregulate their labour markets. What are we doing? We are heading in exactly the opposite direction, swimming against the tide, yet we want to attract investment dollars to encourage growth and reduce unemployment here.

What are we doing? On the labour side, the government has obviously given in in relation to genuine enterprise agreements and given in to the ACTU. Currently, it is threatening to give in on secondary boycotts—again, contrary to what is happening in the rest of the world. It is the reverse direction and it is going to guarantee double digit unemployment in Australia for quite a few years to come.

What are we doing about savings? Savings in Australia continue to fall. In the last quarter, the June quarter, national savings fell by 1.2 per cent of GDP. That is about $1.2 billion. It was the largest fall in savings in this economy since 1974. Over the whole of the last financial year, national savings fell by $3.2 billion. As the Fitzgerald report aptly pointed out, the main culprit has been the federal government. Yet the government has the cheek to exhort business—
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Senate long. I wish to draw notice to the fact that tomorrow some 430 signatures will be presented on a petition on my behalf. They are part of an overall 5,000 signatures which have been collected in Hobart by the save the HMAS Huon campaign. I am pleased that Senator Faulkner is in the chamber. He would be aware that the government is intending to close the most efficient shore-based designated naval facility, the headquarters of the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: That base has a very long tradition. Its closure will risk the immediate future in Tasmania of some 25 permanent Royal Australian Navy personnel, 108 active reservists and 40 inactive reservists. In addition, it will deprive the naval reserve cadets of their Tasmanian divisional headquarters. And all that to save a miserable $250,000. I would have thought the government would be aware, that over the years, Tasmania has probably been the most lucrative recruiting area for navy recruits in Australia.

Tasmania was the second colony settled. It had the first official naval ship in Australia, the Lady Nelson, a replica of which we now have. We have had some marvellous old training ships, including the old HMAS Bass. I note that HMAS Ardent, which has been the only small patrol ship we have had in Tasmania, will not be replaced. And now the government will close this historical shore base that has been part of Royal Australian Navy tradition in Tasmania for over 80 years.

There are moves afoot to have the buildings of HMAS Huon classified by the National Trust because of their heritage significance. I know that the meetings which have been held by the save the HMAS Huon group have been very well attended. I do not believe any members of the Labor Party have been present, but I can understand that.

But I make the point once again: the save the HMAS Huon group has collected some 5,000 signatures, which is no mean feat in a place the size of Hobart. I think it is an absolute disgrace that, for the sake of $250,000, we are to sell off not only part of Australia's heritage but also something that the people of Tasmania have been so proud of for so long. It is just another case of Tasmania being left off the map.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Small Business, upon notice, on 4 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are there to be significant funding cutbacks in the temperate horticulture programs being conducted by the Entomology Division of The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO).
(2) What is the rationale behind these cutbacks.
(3) Are 35 staff members from the area of temperate horticulture to be made redundant.
(4) Does the Government support a reduction in the use of chemical pesticides in temperate horticulture.
(5) Does the Government acknowledge that the pheromone group of the CSIRO's Division of Entomology forms the centre of a network of Australian scientists working in the area of insect pheromones.
(6) Does pheromone research offer a solution to the problem of insect control with reduced use of pesticides.
(7) Will the Government give an undertaking to ensure that there will be no cutback in pheromone research at the CSIRO's Division of Entomology.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) While CSIRO's overall appropriation budget has been slowly increasing in recent years, the budgets of some Divisions such as Entomology have remained fairly constant. The decisions on the overall funding for all Divisions within CSIRO are made by the CSIRO Board and the Institute Directors, and the Divisions review the priority of each of their research programs, reducing or ceasing lower priority programs to allow higher priority work to be increased or commenced.

Through such a process the Division of Entomology has decided to reduce its work in temperate horticulture by June 1993. This program will then be terminated if adequate alternative funding has not been found. Financial support is being sought from external sources.

(2) Most of the work on pheromones has been funded from appropriation funds and the results passed on to the various interested parties without cost. Although the level of funding contributed by the horticulture industry for R&D has increased recently, the industry contribution is still quite low compared with that of other rural industries. For these reasons, the Division ranked this program as a lower priority than many other programs. However, it now seems likely that sufficient funding will be obtained externally to continue the most important aspects of the work.

(3) The figure of thirty-five referred to the total number of people in the Division for whom there may not be sufficient funds. To date, sixteen redundancies have been announced. Within the area of temperate horticulture, staff numbers have been reduced by five through an early retirement, a secondment and three transfers. Five people remain.
(4) A reduction in pesticide use is desirable for public health and for the environment and may become essential for certain export commodities due to decisions of Governments in importing countries.

(5) The Division of Entomology's pheromone group is the only one in the country with the collective expertise and equipment to carry out most facets of research into insect pheromones—from basic research into pheromones to the field testing of pheromone products for pest control.

(6) Pheromones have the potential to reduce the use of pesticides. They can be used to monitor pest infestations so that pesticides are only applied when the insects are actually present, rather than on a speculative basis. They can also be used to directly control pests, especially moths and beetles, by disrupting the mating of these insects.

A good example of the latter is the control of Oriental Fruit Moth in peach orchards, where a product developed from work done in the Division of Entomology has already achieved significant market penetration in Australia and is now on sale in the USA and Europe. This product completely substituted for pesticides and in some areas pheromone control has eliminated the insect pest altogether. Currently, trials are in progress using similar technology, to control Codling Moth in apples and pears where the industry has set itself a target of reducing use of pesticides by 50% by the year 1996.

(7) The Government encourages the establishment of research priorities and consequent reductions in lower priority areas allow higher priority work to be continued or increased. An important input in determination of priorities is the willingness of industry to collaborate in research.

PARA.TAB: (1) Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) Board of Directors. On 21 August 1988, there were nine (9) positions available on the ATC's Board of Directors. Ten (10) positions are now available.

Bureau of Tourism Research (BTR) Advisory Council. There is no limit on the number of positions on the BTR Advisory Council. There were eight members on the Advisory Council as at 21 August 1988. Three of these were Ministerial appointees. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services, upon notice, on 6 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: Have the recommendations of the Auditor-General's Report No. 49, released in June 1992, entitled Management of the Sydney Central construction project, been implemented; if so, which recommendations have been implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: All recommendations of the Auditor-General's Report have been considered in detail and implemented except for recommendations 3, 25(c)(d) and 26.

The outstanding recommendations are under review and yet to be implemented. These recommendations are reliant on the outcome of the Government's Building Industry Reform Strategy to determine the future course of action. The Reform Strategy is being implemented by the Construction Industry Development Agency.
A detailed list of actions undertaken on the recommendations implemented to date is attached.

4.6.8 ANAO recommends that DAS, when obtaining Cabinet approval for future office construction projects, also obtain Cabinet's decision on those Commonwealth departments and agencies that are to occupy the offices.

All office development proposals submitted to Government now include offer and acceptance documentation negotiated between AEM and the proposed tenants. In addition, a detailed financial analysis is undertaken to ensure that the project is a sound investment for the Government.
4.6.9 ANAO also recommends that DAS also obtain a commitment from prospective tenants of Commonwealth offices that they will meet any costs incurred by DAS if they are unable to occupy the offices.

When submitting a construction proposal to Government for approval, Australian Estate Management (AEM) includes written advice from the prospective tenants to the effect that they are committed to taking space in the new/refurbished building under general terms and conditions agreed between the parties. In addition, AEM now asks prospective tenants to certify under section 44A of the Finance Regulations that funds are available to enable them to enter into such a commitment.

Once Government has approved a project, tenants are asked to formalise an agreement to lease which reflects the specific terms and conditions agreed between the parties. This document is similar to a commercial lease agreement.

Although these documents are not contractually binding in the legal sense, in the unlikely event that a prospective tenant chose to renege on its commitment to AEM, they provide ample evidence of the intent of the parties. In such circumstances, AEM would seek compensation from the defaulting party for any costs incurred as a result of its failure to honour the terms of the agreement.

5.6.12 ANAO recommends that ACS consult DIR with a view to revising the tenderers' standard "schedule of understanding of compliance with government industrial relations policy" to a form that satisfies the Government's requirements.

Recommendation currently under review and yet to be implemented. The recommendation is reliant on the outcome of the Government's Building Industry Reform Strategy to determine the future course of action.

5.7.3 ANAO recommends that, when constructing, renovating or fitting out Commonwealth buildings, DAS should seek savings by arranging for relevant contractors to make purchases on DAS common use contacts.
It is current ACS policy to advise tenderers for all major works of the availability of DAS common use contracts but tenderers are not required to use same.

6.1.11 ANAO recommends that, when preparing contracts for large construction projects, ACS seek commercial advice via the Australian Government Solicitor's Office from private sector solicitors or management firms experienced in construction contract drafting, in order to draw upon the latest industry practices and to increase the effectiveness of contracts used by ACS in its new commercial environment.
This is normal practice on major projects and was done on Sydney Central.
6.1.14 ANAO recommends that on future construction contracts all relevant documents be consolidated into one document to eliminate cross referencing.

It is ACS policy to consolidate all relevant documents into one document. It was not done on Sydney Central as negotiations were conducted with two tenderers prior to signing a contract and this did not allow time for consolidation of the relevant documents. Whilst presenting a cumbersome set of documents it did not give rise to a single dispute.

6.2.12 ANAO recommends that future ACS construction contracts that provide for tenancy fitout at the Principal's discretion should provide that briefing dates for the provision of tenant fitout information by the Principal be nominated by the Principal on advice from the PM and the programmer.
It is ACS policy to do so when such contracts arise.
6.3.2 ANAO recommends that ACS:

(a) review the wording of the Contract to ensure that Contractor's claims for extensions of time are accepted only where they affect the project's critical path and that allowable delay types are clearly defined.
It is current ACS policy to do so when such contracts arise.

(b)in future construction contracts that also provide for tenants' fitout work, include specific extension-of-time clauses that reflect extensions to dates for information supply and effects on the project's critical path.
This will be undertaken when later versions of the contract are utilised.

(c) when using the Sydney Central form of contract in future, should provide for the possibility of other contractors undertaking fitout works concurrent with the main building works (eg with progressive handover of floors), at the discretion of the Principal.
In the opinion of ACS the Sydney Central contract had this facility.

(d) ensure that future contracts recognise the VQR system and contain time provisions stipulating the period in which the contractor is to respond to the VQR, and that the contractor provides regular cash flow reports and resources the project to meet the advised cash flow.
Future use of this form of contract will include a time bar to give effect to this recommendation together with cash flow and consequential resources.
6.4.9 ANAO recommends that:

It is ACS policy to have and enforce strict time bars and the Sydney Central contract contained an appropriate claims time bar.

This was the intent of the Sydney Central contract. Clearer definition is included in all later contracts.

Regular meetings were held—irregular at the time of Audit as non-conformances were of a minor nature.

7.4.20 ANAO recommends that ACS ensure that quality assurance system as detailed in the Contract specification is implemented effectively by both parties in accordance with their obligations in the Contract.

It is ACS policy that both parties fully meet their obligations under the contract. ACS believes this was done on building shell works for this project. The processes were less effective on fitout with major disruptions to the program through late tenancy identification and change.
8.1.3 ANAO recommends that ACS:
(a) revise its Contracts Administration Manual and review it regularly,
The Manual is under constant review and is to be expanded to cover industry contracts.
(b) consider issuing project-specific manuals for major or atypical projects.
This will be done where appropriate.

8.4.2 ANAO recommends that on future construction projects the PM and SR should formally engage ACS's internal resources on a project-specific basis.

ACS is continuing to seek improvements to systems in conjunction with its Quality Control systems.

This is being undertaken on an ongoing basis.

8.6.4 ANAO recommends that, in accordance with industry practice, the PM report monthly in a format revised to incorporate additional information to enhance the basis upon which the Steering Committee's decisions are made.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 17 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What percentage of positions in the Commonwealth Public Service are part-time.
(2) How many nominal and actual positions does this represent.
(3) Does the Government intend to increase the number of part-time and job-shared positions; if so, when; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) As at June 30 1993, 3.9 per cent of all permanent employees in the Australian Public Service worked part-time. This is made up predominantly by female employees—89 per cent of permanent part-time employees in the Australian Public Service are female.
(2) Data are collected on actual employees not nominal positions. As at 30 June 1993 there were 4963 permanent part-time employees in the Australian Public Service.

(3) The December 1992 Agreement between the Government and the Public Sector Unions, Improving Productivity, Jobs and Pay in the Australian Public Service 1992-1994 (the Agreement), established a Service-wide quota of permanent part-time positions at 6 per cent of all permanent positions. Prior to this, most officers were covered by awards which set a 3 per cent quota.

Usage of permanent part-time work and tandem arrangements, which are similar to job sharing, within the agreed quota is a matter for individual agencies, taking into account their work programs and responsibilities. The Agreement provides scope for higher levels to be agreed to in individual agencies within the overall ceiling figure.
While the Agreement provides for a review of the Service-wide quota from time to time, the current Service-wide usage of permanent part-time work is still well below the current ceiling.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 18 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the provision of legal aid by State legal aid commissions being reduced in most areas other than criminal justice: if so, what steps, if any, are being taken to reverse this trend.

(2) Are the litigation expenses of most private corporations including multi-national corporate chemical companies allowable as business expense tax deductions: if so, does this represent a form of public subsidy for these companies' litigation costs.

(3) Is this equitable when a private citizen or group such as toxic chemical victims seeking legal redress against such corporations find they can no longer rely on the previous assistance provided by State legal aid commissions.

(4) Will Commonwealth legal aid budgets be increased to enable matters of public interest to be run with direct federal assistance where State legal aid commissions have withdrawn from the provision of services in that area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised that nationally, the numbers of applications for and approvals of legal aid have been affected by the tightening of the eligibility criteria by a number of Commissions. Means tests have been tightened and the availability of legal aid for certain types of matters has been restricted. The impact of these changes has been felt primarily in the civil and family law areas.

ANSWER.PARA: Other factors which have affected the provision of legal aid include:

PARA.TAB: increased costs—the average cost of a referred case in 1992-93 was $1,444 compared to $1,383 in 1991-92 and $1,157 in 1990/91;

stricter requirements by commissions for the provision of a contribution by the assisted person towards the cost of providing assistance. This has affected the numbers of persons accepting grants of aid under the terms offered;

with the growing demands for the legal aid dollar, commissions have been diverting resources into non-litigation or solution oriented services such as classes, information sessions and telephone advice; and
reforms in some areas of law. Changes to penalties and the monetary jurisdiction of small claims courts have impacted on the need for legal aid in some areas.

With the exception of the legal aid commissions in NSW and Queensland which have severely restricted the availability of aid in civil matters, commissions continue to provide aid in civil law matters subject to the consideration of matters under their means and merit test guidelines.

Legal aid commissions are independent statutory bodies established under State and Territory legislation. While the Commonwealth provides funding to the Commissions, it is unable to direct the way in which commissions supply legal aid.

The Legal Aid Commission of NSW introduced new policies severely restricting civil law matters from 1 January 1993. Under these policies applications in respect of environmental matters are not eligible for a grant of aid. The Commission is reviewing these policies with the aim of reinstating aid for civil matters where possible. Further it should be noted that the Commission also administers funding for the Public Interest Advocacy Centre which provides assistance in public interest cases which would extend to toxic chemical cases.

The Legal Aid Commission of Queensland amended its guidelines on 20 July 1993 to rule out the provision of assistance in civil cases where there is a power to award costs. Since that time, however, the Commission has taken on the administration of a scheme utilising funds provided by the Public Trustee of Queensland to fund cases of this type on an outlays only basis, i.e. to cover the costs of solicitors outlays in providing assistance.

In the 1991-92 and 1992-93 financial years the Commonwealth has fulfilled its funding responsibility under its agreements with the States and Territories for the provision of legal aid. In addition it has provided additional funding in areas of non criminal law outside of the base funding provisions of the agreements to meet the impact of its initiatives on legal aid commissions. An example of this is the funding provided by the Commonwealth for the legal aid aspects of the Child Support Scheme. $5.7m was provided to legal aid commissions for this in 1992-93. The Commonwealth has also provided an increase of $7.4m (in 1991-92 dollars) in its contribution to commissions for the period 1991-92 to 1993-94, in response to an increased demand for legal services.

(2) I am advised that the question of whether litigation expenses of a corporation are allowable as business expense tax deductions depends on whether they have the character of losses or outgoings necessarily incurred in carrying on the corporation's business for the purpose of gaining or producing assessable income.

(3) Equity in legal aid must be viewed in the context that the demand for services will always exceed the capacity of the providers of legal aid to meet that demand. In this environment legal aid commissions must deliver their services according to perceived priorities. Historically, commissions have given priority of access to legal aid services to those whose liberty is at risk and to children whose interests are endangered.

Under Section 47(2) of its Legal Aid Act the NSW Legal Aid Commission is given indemnity from paying costs in excess of $12,000 awarded against its clients. The inclusion of such a provision in the act allows the Commission to provide aid without the risk of incurring a major award of costs against it by the courts, and is therefore a further factor in ensuring that a greater number of legal aid cases are funded.

(4) The Commonwealth has in place schemes which provide grants of financial assistance for litigants for the conduct of cases in courts and tribunals where ordinary legal aid is not available and where the circumstances constitute special cases of Commonwealth interest envisaged by relevant legislation and guidelines. These schemes are administered by the Office of Legal Aid and Family Services in the Attorney-General's Portfolio. There will be no increase in Commonwealth funds for these schemes.

These schemes include the Public Interest and Test Cases scheme for parties to proceedings involving a substantial point of unresolved Commonwealth law or where a decision is likely to affect a large number of disadvantaged persons. In the case of toxic chemicals there is also an Environmental Cases scheme for parties to environmental cases involving parts of the National Estate or other areas of national importance.
Applications for assistance under these schemes will be considered on their individual merits.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, upon notice, on 17 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a recent speech by the Director General of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (Mr Philip Flood) that "for every dollar of aid funding, three dollars worth of return to Australia have either been achieved or are expected", how does Australia's foreign aid program work to improve the economic situation of recipient countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The statement quoted by Senator Chamarette was taken from an address on the commercial benefits of Australian development cooperation which Mr Flood delivered to the National Trade and Investment Forum in July 1993. Taken in its original context the statement refers to the commercial benefits which have been estimated to accrue to Australia, not from the aid program as a whole, but from development cooperation with China over the last decade. The relevant paragraph reads as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Our [AIDAB's] study of the commercial benefits resulting from development cooperation with China over the period 1980-81 to 1991-92 found that $285 million in AIDAB funding generated $838 million in actual or anticipated business. In other words, for every dollar of aid funding involved, three dollars worth of returns to Australia have either been achieved or are expected.

PARA.TAB: The returns to Australia from the program as a whole are, of course, much harder to estimate. We know that on most recent estimates around 87 per cent of the aid budget is spent in Australia. While this figure does not take into account flow-on effects, it at least represents the lower bound of the program's commercial benefits. More generally, the economic development of the countries in our region, to which our development cooperation has contributed, has underpinned the large growth in trade between these countries and Australia.

The primary objective of the Australian development cooperation program is to promote the economic and social advancement of people in developing countries through an appropriate mix of measures to promote economic development and alleviate immediate suffering. The resources transferred to developing countries through the development cooperation program directly achieve this by meeting fundamental infrastructure, training, commodity and technical assistance needs. At the same time, given that in most cases the goods and services required for aid activities must be sourced from industrialised countries, and given the current economic environment, the Government would be remiss if it did not seek to secure a fair share of the returns from such activities for Australia.

While it has long been accepted that the aid program has a legitimate role to play in promoting Australia's commercial interests, commercial benefits are not sought where they would compromise aid quality.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 25 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the New South Wales (NSW) Government going to permit the importation of Tasmanian Pacific oysters; if so, how will this trade be affected by the declaration by the Tasmanian Government that the disease, bonamia, is endemic to Tasmanian waters.
(2) What assurances do the people of NSW have that affected Tasmanian oysters will not threaten the viability of the NSW oyster industry as a result of this trade.
(3) If the NSW industry is affected, what is the probability that oysters in other States will be affected.
(4) How does the possibility of diseased oysters in Australian waters affect Australia's international trade and fishing obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Any regulation of the importation of Tasmanian Pacific oysters into New South Wales (NSW) is primarily a State responsibility and I am unaware of any Commonwealth restrictions. I understand that live Pacific oysters can be imported into NSW for human consumption only. Bonamiosis is a disease caused by the protozoan Bonamia which affects only the native flat oyster, sometimes causing mortality. There is no scientific evidence that Bonamia can be spread on the shell or in the shell liquor of the Pacific oyster. As the Pacific oyster is not affected by the disease, there should be no effect on the trade of Tasmanian Pacific oysters into NSW.

(2) Because there is always some concern that bonamia organisms might be carried by other oysters, I am advised that live oysters can only be imported into NSW for human consumption, and must be processed at approved sites from where effluent enters the sewers resulting in the destruction of the bonamia organism. Therefore, the viability of the NSW oyster industry should not be affected.
(3) On the available evidence, I believe that there is a negligible chance only that the NSW oyster industry will be adversely affected by bonamiosis derived from imported Tasmanian Pacific oysters.

Regulation for the interstate movement of oysters is controlled by State and Territory governments. All governments are aware of the possibility that the movement of oysters, particularly for breeding/growing out, is capable of spreading disease and pest species. I am advised that appropriate controls, commensurate with the risks involved, are being taken by these governments.

(4) Bonamiosis affects only flat oysters; the disease is present in many countries and, I am advised, is not a disease of human health significance. In February 1992, Australia reported the presence of the disease to the Office Internationale des Epizooties which, in turn, advised all member countries. I understand that, to date, no concerns have been raised with the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. The impact on Australian exports of oysters should, therefore, be minimal.
