asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the cost of implementing the administrative arrangements attached to the nuclear co-operation agreements Australia has with Canada, Egypt, Japan, the Republic of Korea, Mexico, Philippines, Russia and the USA.
(2) What are the estimated costs of implementing the administrative arrangements attached to the Nuclear Science and Technology Co-operation Agreement which is to be signed with Indonesia.
(3) When will the Nuclear Science and Technology Co-operation Agreement with Indonesia be signed and will the attached administrative arrangements be published with the agreement.
(4) What amounts did the Government pay to support Australian Government delegates to the Liability Regime meetings of the International Atomic Energy Agency.

(5) With reference to a contribution of $5.7 million the Australian Government will make to the International Atomic Energy Agency in 1993-94, please provide a breakdown of what this money will be spent on.
(6) Will any of the 1993-94 Budget for the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau be spent on nuclear projects; if so, please provide details of these projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Responsibility for operating the bilateral network of agreements and administrative arrangements set up with these and other countries to monitor the flow of Australian obligated nuclear material in the international nuclear fuel cycle rests with the Australian Safeguards Office (ASO). The ASO has estimated these costs at about $280,000 for one year. ASO has advised that it is not possible to provide separate costings for the individual agreements cited due to the interlinking nature of the operation of the network.

(2)&(3) As I replied in the Senate on 7 September 1993 to Senator Coulter no date or place for the signature of the Nuclear Science and Technology Agreement has yet been set. The Indonesian Minister for Science and Technology, Dr Habibie prefers that the Agreement be signed in the context of a broader complementary science and technology agreement. The Nuclear Science and Technology Agreement has no administrative arrangements either as part of it or proposed to be part of it. Such arrangements are normal under Australia's nuclear transfer agreements for the export of uranium. The proposed science and technology agreement however, does not provide for commercial transfers of uranium.

(4) Following is an estimate for each year based on the airfare and travel allowance costs of non Vienna-based participants in the nuclear liability regime negotiations. It should be noted that in most cases Australia-based delegation members would, while away from Australia, attend at least one and possibly more meetings or conferences unrelated to nuclear liability. The following figures do not take such other duties into account, nor the time and salary cost of Vienna-based officials on the delegations and Canberra-based officials who contribute to the briefing for the meetings.

(5) The payment of $5.07 million (incorrectly referred to as $5.7 million in the Hansard record) to the International Atomic Energy Agency in 1993-94 to be paid by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade represents Australia's compulsory contribution to the 1994 regular budget as approved by the Agency's Board of Governors and General Conference. As assessed member state contributions to the regular budget provide the Agency's general revenue, it is not possible to relate our contribution to specific items of expenditure. In general terms, however:
35% of the Agency's programmed regular budget will be spent on activities relating to the operation of the international safeguards regime;
6% will be spent on administration of the Agency's technical assistance and cooperation programs, funding for which is provided separately—see answer to question 6 below;
15% will be spent on the Agency's nuclear energy and safety programs;
15% will be spent on the Agency's research and isotopes programs; and

29% will be spent on management and administration programs and the cost of the policy making organs of the Agency, being the annual General Conference and the quarterly meetings of the Board of Governors.

(6) Consistent with Australia's obligations under Article IV of the NPT to assist developing country members to benefit from the peaceful applications of nuclear technology, three nuclear assistance projects will be funded under the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau's budget for 1993-94. A further project is being evaluated which may involve some expenditure during the financial year. Consideration is also being given to supporting a regional training course during May 1994. These projects are:

(i) Core support to the International Atomic Energy Agency's Technical Assistance and Cooperation Fund (TACF) which provides the bulk of funding for the Agency's technical assistance and cooperation programs (see answer to question 5 above). Member state contributions are assessed according to a target figure approved by the Agency's Board of Governors and General Conference. As the contributions are in the nature of general revenue, it is not possible to relate our contribution to specific items of expenditure. Activities funded from the TACF include: application of nuclear technology to agriculture, industry and medicine; training in nuclear safety, and safety assessments of nuclear facilities in developing countries. The budget allocation for 1993-94 is $1.3 million.

(ii) International Atomic Energy Agency—Regional Cooperative Agreement for Asia and the Pacific (IAEA-RCA). Support is provided on a regional basis to member countries of the RCA through training courses focussing on the industrial application of isotopes and radiation, occupational health and safety (radiation protection) and nuclear medicine. Small amounts of equipment are also supplied. The budget allocation for 1993-94 is $500,000.

(iii) Nuclear Technical Cooperation Project in Malaysia. This involves the provision of training and technical assistance to Malaysia's Nuclear Technology Unit and selected hospitals in nuclear medicine, industrial applications of radioisotopes, small angle neutron scattering spectrometer utilisation, product testing of radiopharmaceuticals and occupational health and safety. The budget allocation for 1993-94 is $458,500.

(iv) Nuclear Technical Assistance Project in Thailand. A feasibility study into the project proposal is to take place during October and November. Whether the proposal becomes an approved project with possible expenditure in 1993-94 depends on the study's outcome. The proposal is for technical assistance and training in the peaceful use of nuclear technology, in particular, nuclear medicine, tracer technology, the production of isotopes and associated occupational health and safety procedures.

(v) An IAEA/Australia Regional Training Course on National Safeguards Systems is to be held in Australia during May 1994. Consideration is being given for aid funds to be used to fund the attendance of developing country participants at an estimated cost of $250,000.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 7 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What sampling is conducted by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service's Imported Food Control Program, and on what food commodities, to ensure adherence by importers to Australia's ban on irradiated food.

(2) What tests are conducted by the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories (AGAL) for identification of the use of irradiation on foods and what research or experimentation by AGAL or any other government agency is being conducted to develop a reliable test or tests for detection of irradiated food.
(3) Since 1 February 1993, how many samples of imported seafood have been tested under the Imported Food Control Program for: (a) use of irradiation; and (b) bacterial contamination.
(4) How many such samples were: (a) found to have zero or unexpectedly low levels of bacterial contamination; and (b) found to be, or suspected of being irradiated.
(5) How many consignments of imported seafood were `failed' on grounds of bacterial contamination.
(6) How many `failed' consignments were: (a) destroyed; (b) processed for use other than as food for human consumption; and (c) allowed to be re-exported.

(7) On consignments of `failed' seafood allowed to be re-exported, what checks are made to identify the country they are destined for, and that the standards in these countries are such as to permit entry of such bacterially contaminated food.
(8) How many consignments of `failed' seafood were allowed to be re-exported to the Netherlands.
(9) What measures have been taken to alert receiving countries of the fact that these are `failed' foods on grounds of bacterial contamination.
(10) What steps are taken by Australia to ensure that such foods are not being irradiated in the Netherlands and subsequently being re-presented for importation into Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1&2) A three year moratorium declared by the Federal Government in December 1989 requested State and Territory Governments to enact appropriate regulations prohibiting the irradiation of food and the sale of irradiated food in Australia. It was intended to provide time for further research to be undertaken into methods of detection for irradiated food and for the recent data about the safety and nutritional value of irradiated food to be reviewed.

A codicil to the Commonwealth, State and Territory Agreement on the adoption of uniform food standards has since been agreed to enable States and Territories to make regulations in respect of food irradiation. This ensures the maintenance of the moratorium, beyond the initial three years, until the National Food Authority recommends a standard on food irradiation to the National Food Standards Council (a body comprised of the Health Ministers of all States and Territories, and of the Commonwealth). Such a recommendation will only be made once the Authority has undertaken the relevant steps as prescribed in the National Food Authority Act 1991.

The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) is not conducting any sampling under its Imported Food Inspection Program to ensure food has not been irradiated. Accordingly the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories (AGAL) do not conduct testing to identify the use of irradiation on foods. AGAL's advice is that analytical techniques suitable for routine detection of irradiation of food do not exist, although there are techniques involving thermoluminescence, electron spin resonance and gas chromatography which show promise. AGAL is not currently undertaking research aimed at developing reliable methodology for detection of irradiated food but is keeping abreast of the results of other studies on the topic. In particular AGAL is liaising with the Institute of Social Medicine and Epidemiology in Berlin and the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation.
(3) Since February 1 1993: (a) no samples of seafood have been tested for the use of irradiation; and (b) 338 samples have been tested for bacterial contamination.
(4) Of samples tested none were reported as having zero levels of bacteria or unusually low levels of bacterial contamination.
(5) Thirteen shipments were failed on grounds of bacterial contamination exceeding Australian tolerances.
(6) Of the failed consignments: (a) six were destroyed; (b) none were processed; and (c) five were re-exported.
Two shipments were still being held as of 17 September 1993.

(7) Since proclamation of the Imported Food Control Act 1992 on 15 June 1993, AQIS will only consider applications to re-export `failed' food where advice has been obtained from the food inspection authorities in the receiving country that the goods would be permitted entry under their supervision and AQIS is satisfied that proper controls will be exercised over the goods on arrival.
(8) Two.
(9) See answer to (7) above. Since June 1993 AQIS has notified authorities in the receiving country of the results of testing in Australia.

(10) AQIS monitors all seafood imports. Any shipment originating in the Netherlands would therefore be subject to scrutiny under the Imported Food Inspection Program. Since 1 February 1993 there have been no shipments of seafood from the Netherlands.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 7 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) In relation to assaying of human breast milk for organochlorine pesticides as part of the 1990 Australian market basket survey, why did the National Food Authority fail to find any residues other than DDE, a metabolite of DDT in its testing.
(2) Did an extensive Western Australian survey of breast milk organochlorine levels around the same time find dieldrin in 90 per cent of Western Australian samples.
(3) Were the levels in these breast milk samples sufficiently high to lead to daily intakes of dieldrin for breast fed infants above that set by the World Health Organisation (WHO).
(4) Were heptachlor levels in 68 per cent of the samples also sufficiently high to lead to daily intakes of heptachlor in breast fed infants above those set by the WHO.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Market Basket Survey (AMBS) arrived at different results than the Western Australian study but the two studies used different methodologies. Both the AMBS and the WA study found that the instances of detecting residues in human milk and the level of residues in human milk are decreasing.

The AMBS examines whole human breast milk, in keeping with its policy to analyse food `as consumed'. In comparison, the Western Australian study analysed the fat of human milk. Surveys of pesticide residues in the fat of human milk consistently result in higher pesticide levels than those using whole human milk. In a low fat substance such as human milk, fat soluble pesticides are highly concentrated in the small amount of fat. This results in very high levels of pesticide in the fat of what is, in total, a low residue food. As the WA study used the level of fat in human milk as the basis of its analysis, it introduces another source of error into the estimation of intake, that is the average level of fat in human milk.
The WA study acknowledges that this is a very variable level, varying with the age of the baby, the time of the feed and within the feed.

A further point of difference between the two studies was that the AMBS analysed composite human milk samples whereby the milk of a number of mothers is collected by methods that do not interfere with the running of a busy maternity ward. Only small amounts of milk were collected from each mother. In the WA study individual mothers volunteered to join the study. These mothers would be required to provide milk not only for their babies but also for the research, therefore they would be more likely than the AMBS mothers to be in negative energy balance and to be using up their fat reserves. This therefore results in a higher amount of pesticides in their milk.

The WA study includes a value equal to half the limit of detection for all `not detected' results, which will inflate the estimates of the Hexachlorobenzene, Heptachlor, and Chlordane intakes. Many of the residues detected in the WA study were close to the limit of detection. It can be difficult to measure these residues as acknowledged by the authors of the study.
Previous AMBSs have detected residues of the pesticides reported in the WA study of human milk samples, but these residues were not detected in the 1990 survey.
(2) The WA survey actually detected residues of dieldrin in 100% of the samples.
(3) The WA survey indicated that estimated daily intakes of dieldrin based on their data would be higher than the WHO Acceptable Daily Intakes (ADI).
(4) The WA study also indicated that some estimated daily intakes of heptachlor based on their data would be higher than the WHO ADI.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 8 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did Qantas Airways recently assist in the enforced repatriation to Burma of 11 Burmese seamen from a Qantas flight at Singapore's Changi airport.
(2) On what basis did Qantas cooperate in this forced repatriation.
(3) Have any provisions of Australian legislation been breached as a result of the actions taken by Qantas.
(4) Has Australia's diplomatic mission in Burma been able to determine the fate of these eleven seamen since their return to Burma.
(5) What is the nature of Australian Government protests to Burmese authorities over this incident.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) On 3 June Qantas staff at Singapore's Changi airport assisted an official of the Burmese Embassy in Singapore to obtain access to eleven Burmese seamen who were in transit at Changi airport in Singapore on Qantas flights. The seamen had previously been assisted by the International Transport Workers Federation (ITWF) in Australia to secure back pay and repatriation costs from their Greek shipping agent. Qantas was unaware of the controversy surrounding the Burmese seamen and was under the impression that the Singaporean authorities had approved access. This was the full extent of Qantas involvement: Qantas had no role in the detention of the seamen at Changi airport from 3-7 June, or in their repatriation to Burma on 7 June.

(3) No provisions of Australian legislation have been breached by Qantas. The incident at Changi airport is a matter under the jurisdiction of the Singapore authorities. Following an initial investigation by the Singapore authorities, the case has been referred to the Singapore Attorney-General for further consideration. Qantas has indicated its willingness to cooperate fully with the Singapore authorities in their investigation of the incident.

(4) On 2 September the Australian Embassy in Rangoon raised the question of the welfare and whereabouts of the seamen with the Burmese Minister of Transport and Ministry of Foreign Affairs. According to the Burmese authorities, the seamen were all at liberty in Burma. This was subsequently confirmed by our Embassy.

ANSWER.PARA: During the visit to Canberra on 6 August by an official Burmese delegation, I expressed Australia's concern at suggestions that Burmese officials had played a role in the disappearance of the seamen. The Australian Ambassador in Rangoon conveyed this concern to the Burmese Minister of Transport and officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on 2 September. The main concern of the Australian Government has, of course, been for the welfare of the semen themselves. The incident at Changi airport is essentially a matter for the Singaporean and Burmese authorities: I note that the Singapore Government has found sufficient evidence of improper conduct by the Burmese Embassy in Singapore to lodge a protest with that Embassy about its conduct with regard to the seamen.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 8 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the Australian Government's position in relation to the lack of progress in United Nations (UN) efforts to find a peace settlement in Cyprus.
(2) Will discussion of the Cyprus issue take place at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM) due to be held in Cyprus in October 1993.
(3) What action does Australia propose taking at CHOGM to promote the proposals of the UN Secretary-General in relation to Cyprus.
(4) As a member of the Commonwealth Action Group on Cyprus, what practical measures does Australia propose should be adopted in order to bring a more rapid end to the conflict.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Government supports the sovereignty and territorial integrity of the Republic of Cyprus and recognises the Republic as the only legitimate authority on the island. Australia does not recognise the so-called `Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus'. Successive Australian Governments have had a long-standing and active concern that a negotiated and peaceful settlement be reached between the parties. We firmly support the UN Secretary-General's efforts to find a solution, and endorse the UN Security Council resolutions on Cyprus.
(2) We expect discussion of the Cyprus problem will take place at CHOGM.

(3) The Australian position on the Cyprus issue has been clearly and publicly restated on many occasions. The Prime Minister will be in a position to reaffirm our policy, if this issue arises during CHOGM.

(4) The Commonwealth Action Group on Cyprus was established in 1975, shortly after the Turkish military intervention in 1974. The Group has been dormant since 1985, as it was considered that the Cyprus issue is one for the United Nations, rather than the Commonwealth to attempt to resolve. The Group agreed that the risk of direct Commonwealth involvement would be to duplicate or detract from the work done by the UN Secretary-General and his emissaries. The Commonwealth, at the 1985 CHOGM, agreed that the Commonwealth Action Group should continue to monitor developments and upon request, assist the Secretary-General's efforts. The Australian Government supports that approach.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 13 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will an assurance be given that no water resources are threatened in terms of water quality, and in particular potable water, as a result of the use of approved chemicals in water catchments.
(2) Is there any threat to the health of residents of Lorinna as a result of their potable water being polluted by the Forestry Commission's use of the herbicide Atrazine.
(3) What action has been taken in light of recent findings of Atrazine levels above World Health Organisation limits in the Lorinna resident's drinking water.
(4) Has the department developed a public safety policy in light of the fact that agrichemicals are being widely used in water catchments; if so, what are the surveillance and reporting arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) While drinking water should not be contaminated by pesticide residues, there will be some situations where contamination of water sources may occasionally occur. The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) has recognised this and has recommended health guideline values for certain pesticides to ensure the quality of drinking water and to protect public health and safety. These guideline values are listed in the draft Australian Drinking Water Guidelines which were recently adopted by the NHMRC Public Health Committee. Neither the NHMRC nor my Department, however, has responsibility for assessing the potential of chemicals to cause environmental contamination of water resources.

(2) The Health Guideline value listed in the draft Australian Drinking Water Guidelines for atrazine is 0.02 mg/L. This value was determined by taking into account a number of safety factors and indicates the level of atrazine in drinking water which may be consumed without risk to health. The levels reported by Tasmanian Government authorities as being detected from some samples of water from the Lorinna district are well below this value.

(3) No immediate action on health grounds is foreshadowed at this stage as no hazard to the public health has been identified. My Department will continue to assess technical data on atrazine as it becomes available and to monitor international regulatory developments.

(4) Surveillance and reporting activities are the responsibility of State Government agencies. I understand that Tasmanian authorities are continuing to monitor atrazine levels in water in the Lorinna district.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services, upon notice, on 13 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Did the Tasmanian Commissioner for Town and Country Planning allow only 3 weeks for public comment on a major change in zoning and development to 5 kilometres (200 hectares) of prime Tasmanian coastline; and (b) is the normal time allowed for public comment and objections 3 months.

(2) Is a single advertisement in the Launceston Examiner of 10 July 1993 sufficient notice for residents and ratepayers to object to a major proposed alteration to the Planning Scheme allowing rezoning of prime coastline.

(3) Did the Town and Country Planning Commissioner approve provisional alteration to the Planning Scheme contrary to the express advice of four previous health inspectors' full assessments stating that the location was unsuitable for septic tanks.
(4) Do the actions of the Town and Country Planning Commissioner pre-empt the recommendations of the Resource Assessment Commission's inquiry into the management and use of Australia's coastal zone.

(5) Is it procedurally correct for Break O'Day Council to give support to the Town and Country Planning Commissioner's decision to proceed with rezoning having previously advised local people that the stream flowing through Four Mile Creek settlement is polluted from septic tank run-off and algal bloom from high nutrient loads.
(6) Is it appropriate for the Town and Country Planning Commissioner to approve plans which override health reports.
(7) Has the Break O'Day Council breached its duty of care in regard to health by approving rezoning and thus further development which would exacerbate existing problems.
(8) Has the Break O'Day Council breached the Environment Protection Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1), (2), (3), (5), (6), (7) and (8) These questions do not fall within the responsibility of my portfolio and should be directed to the State Government who has responsibility for such matters.

(4) The issue of pre-emption of the recommendations of the Resource Assessment Commission's inquiry into the management and use of Australia's coastal zone would need to await the delivery of the Inquiry's final report which is not due with the Prime Minister until 25 November 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the President of the Senate, upon notice, on 21 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What has been the total cost of repairs to Parliament House during the financial years: (a) 1992-93; and (b) 1993-94 to date.
(2) What repairs have been undertaken in the same time period.
(3) Which of these repairs were subject tender.
(4) Which contractors have undertaken these repairs to Parliament House.
(5) What were the individual costs of these repairs.
(6) What improvements and upgradings have been undertaken at Parliament House over the same time period.
(7) What have been the individual costs of these improvements and upgradings.
(8) Which of these improvements and upgradings have been subject to tender.
(9) Which contractors have undertaken these improvements and upgradings.
(10) What has been the total cost of improvements and upgradings on Parliament House in the same time period.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Questions (1) to (5) relate to the costs of, and details about, repairs to Parliament House. The Joint House Department Engineering Services Policy and Procedures Manual defines repairs as "Work carried out on an item which is no longer fully functional in order to restore it to proper working order consistent with its original condition".
In this regard the number of individual repair works, as defined, undertaken during the periods 1992-93 and 1993-94 to date, total some 8,800.
Expenditure incurred (rounded) under the Engineering Services repairs expenditure account number was in 1992-93—$735,000, and 1993-94 to date—$162,000.
All repairs work, as defined, was carried out by Joint House Department Engineering Services staff.

This repairs work, as defined, does not include work carried out under the Department's general maintenance contracts put in place to cover the maintenance and operational support of a range of building services and activities. These contracts (each of which was subject to a tender process and mostly extend over a number of years) are lump sum contracts and do not separately identify or price any repairs element. In the period 1992-93 the Joint House Department had maintenance contracts in place covering 26 different building services and activities, for which total payments of $1,458,000 were made.
Full details of each individual repair, or general maintenance contract, is available on request through the Joint House Department, if required.

Questions (6) to (10) relate to improvements and upgrades to Parliament House. These are categorised by the Joint House Department as Capital Works and Engineering Services Special Projects, and relate to changes undertaken to the building's structure, fabric and plant and equipment.
During the period 1992-93, 71 individual projects were undertaken. In the period 1993-94 to date, a further 26 individual projects have been commenced.
The total expenditure on these 97 projects in the period 1992-93 and 1993-94 to date, has been $5,559,000.
Each of these individual projects was subject to a tender process and the work was carried out by contractors.
Full details of each individual project is available on request through the Joint House Department, if required.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission: Video

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 21 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the content of the video produced for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission by ABC TV Marketing, Gore Hill, for $29,760.
(2) What is the purpose of this video.
(3) How many copies of this video were produced.
(4) To what extent has this video been used.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The video entitled Industrial Democracy at Work is a narrative depicting a situation whereby staff in a hypothetical office are required to shift without appropriate consultation. A solution to the situation is arrived at through the use of Industrial Democracy processes in the form of a joint Management/Union Consultative Council.

The video has been produced as a training aid to illustrate to staff how Industrial Democracy principles can be applied in the workplace. It is intended for use in all ATSIC offices and was developed in consultation with the Public Sector Union.
One master copy of the video has been produced. A further 100 copies have been ordered for use in ATSIC's Central, State and Regional Offices at an additional cost of $493.

The video has been shown in preliminary evaluation sessions with Management. Training notes are currently being developed for use with the video and, once available, the package will be distributed across ATSIC.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Budget Video

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 21 September, 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the content of the 1993 Staff Budget Video, for which the Department paid $28,586 in August 1993.
(2) What is the purpose of the video.
(3) Is a video of this kind produced every year, if so what has the department spent on producing these videos in the past 5 years.
(4) How many copies of the videos are produced.
(5) To what extent has the video been used.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)/(2) The 1993 Staff Budget video is a 17 minute program produced to give staff an overview of the impact of the Budget on the Department and its programs. In addition to details of the 1993 Budget and its impact on the Employment, Education and Training portfolio the video contains interviews about the Budget with Minister Beazley, the Parliamentary Secretary, the Departmental Secretary, and senior Departmental staff.

(3) The Budget video has been produced for the past three years. The cost of producing the video in 1993 is $28,586 as identified in question 1. The corresponding costs for 1992 and 1991 are $28,891 and $23,000 respectively.
(4) 1031 copies of the video were produced each year.

(5) Copies were provided to departmental offices nationally. Staff were encouraged to view it immediately upon receipt. The Department does not collect statistics on how many staff view the video but a sample survey of DEET staff following the Budget showed that those who viewed the video found it useful or very useful.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Budget Video

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 21 September, 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What urgency surrounded the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) Budget video that it needed door-to-door courier service from Kwikasair, New South Wales costing $15,000.
(2) What would the cost have been had the DEET Budget video been delivered using Australia Post.
(3) How many DEET Budget videos were delivered through the door-to-door courier service from Kwikasair.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The cost of using Kwikasair to deliver to New South Wales offices was $2,819.06. The total charges for national delivery using Kwikasair was $14,763.00. Kwikasair has a period contract with Commonwealth Departments which guarantees door-to-door overnight parcel delivery. It also provides secure and verified delivery which is an important consideration given the confidential nature of the Budget related material before the Budget is brought down.
(2) The costs are not known. Australia Post is not on the government period contract which covers priority overnight parcel delivery and the Department could not, therefore, have been able to use it.
(3) 970 copies were delivered.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Desk Blotters

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 28 September, 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the purpose of the desk blotter and artwork supplies purchased by the Department for $3500 from Pirie Printers Sales, Australian Capital Territory.
(2) How many blotters were purchased.
(3) As the blotter was purchased by the Corporate Services, Information and Public Relations section of the Department, was it part of a public relations exercise, if so, which one.
(4) What urgency surrounded the blotters that the delivery of the blotters to State, area, and regional offices cost $5000 through Kwikasair, New South Wales.
(5) What would the cost have been had the blotters been sent through Australia Post.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The desk blotters were part of a package of information products prepared for CES staff outlining Budget information to help answer client questions about changes in programs announced in the 1993-94 Budget.

(4) A package of Budget information materials was produced for staff to inform them of the effect of the 1993 Budget on the Employment, Education and Training portfolio. The materials were produced to a very tight production schedule to enable them to be distributed to staff as soon as possible after the tabling of the Budget. The cost for national distribution by Kwikasair was $2491.07. The figure of $5,000 was the initial estimate of distribution costs. Kwikasair have a period contract with Commonwealth Departments which guarantees door-to-door overnight parcel delivery. It provides secure and verified delivery which is an important consideration given the confidential nature of the Budget related material. Kwikasair also provides a collation and packaging service to meet urgent distribution requirements.
(5) The costs are not known. Australia Post is not on the Government period contract which covers overnight priority parcel delivery and the Department would not, therefore, have been able to use it.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Bus Tickets

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 28 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Was $12,800 spent on green bus tickets from the Bus and Coach Association, Queensland?
(2) Was $17,500 spent on average fare bus tickets from Brisbane Transport?
(3) To what purpose will these bus tickets be put?
(4) Who will use these bus tickets?
(5) In which other States and Territories are bus tickets bought in bulk?
(6) What is the cost of the purchase of bus tickets Australia-wide?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Six thousand green bus tickets have been ordered at a cost of $12,600. It is estimated these will be used by December 1993.
(2) Yes.
(3) The bus tickets will be used to assist:
jobseekers attend interviews and for return travel;
jobseekers living in remote areas attend assessments under the special intervention program;

jobseekers with disabilities who are referred by DEET officers for professional assessment by Disability Assessment Panels or Case Managers at CES locations as part of the ongoing management of their activity plan; and
participants in the Accredited Training for Youth program (ATY) who receive Formal Training Allowance (FTA) when they incur more than $5 per week in travelling to and from courses.
(4) The bus tickets will be used by jobseekers registered with the CES in the Brisbane metropolitan and Gold Coast areas.
(5) All States and Territories.

(6) The amount spent in 1992-93 is approximately $960,000. Of this $877,000 is used to support Labour Market programs, particularly the Mobility Assistance program. The remaining $83,000 is used for staff in metropolitan areas to perform delivery functions, attend meetings etc where public transport (bus, train and tram travel) is the most economical means.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Office of the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, upon notice, on 27 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) When will Ms Ann Sherry commence her appointment as the First Assistant Secretary of the Office of the Status of Women (OSW).
(2) What is the length of Ms Sherry's appointment as the First Assistant Secretary of the OSW.

(3) What is the total annual remuneration package that Ms Sherry will receive as the First Assistant Secretary of the OSW, including all allowances, vehicle expenses, performance-based bonuses and any other entitlements.

(4) Will Ms Sherry receive any other amounts from the Commonwealth in respect of work performed other than in her capacity as First Assistant Secretary of the OSW; if so, what is the nature and amount of these payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Ms Sherry commenced her appointment as First Assistant Secretary of the Office of the Status of Women with effect from 13 September 1993.
(2) Ms Sherry has been permanently appointed to the Australian Public Service as a Senior Executive Band 2 officer, subject to a standard probationary period .
(3) Ms Sherry will be in receipt of the following annual remuneration package for officers at her level:
Salary and Leave Bonus—85 361
Superannuation—13 054
Vehicle and travel expenses—9 500
Fringe benefits tax and telephone—2 140
TOTAL—110 055

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 28 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Can the accuracy of media reports which suggest that Australia is considering withdrawing from the United Nations peacekeeping force on Cyprus (UNFICYP) be confirmed.
(2) What is the nature of any review being conducted by the department on Australia's participation with UNFICYP.
(3) What is the overall annual cost to Australia of participating with UNFICYP.
(4) Does the Government of Cyprus contribute to the financial cost of Australia's participation with UNFICYP.
(5) Does the Australian Government believe that a continuation of the UNFICYP operation is counterproductive to finding a peace settlement on Cyprus.
(6) What practical measures does the Australian Government intend pursuing in an effort to reach a settlement that will end the need for UNFICYP.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No decision has been taken by the Government and no recommendations have at this stage been put before Ministers concerning any change in Australia's contribution of 20 civilian police to the UN Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus (UNFICYP).

(2) The Government will review Australia's participation in UNFICYP before the end of the current mandate period in December 1993, in the light of a review of UNFICYP by the UN Security Council, also scheduled for December 1993. The nature of this review will be routine, although all options concerning the Australian contribution to UNFICYP will be considered.

(3) The annual cost to the Australian Federal Police for the contribution of 20 civilian police officers to UNFICYP is A$1.75 million. Until 15 June 1993, UNFICYP as a whole was funded by voluntary contributions from governments. Australia had for some time contributed a sum of US$100,000 each calendar year towards the overall costs of the force in addition to the cost of providing the civilian police contingent. For budgetary reasons, the Australian Government reduced its most recent voluntary contribution to US$100,000 for the 18 month period from 1 January 1992 to 15 June 1993. Since 16 June 1993, UNFICYP has been placed under the same funding arrangements as apply to most other UN peace keeping operations, ie mandatory assessments are levied on all UN member states for a proportion of the total, for those costs which are not otherwise met by voluntary contributions. Under these new funding arrangements, Australia's assessed contributions are likely to be, according to the latest estimate by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, about US$256,000 annually.

(4) No. The Government of Cyprus, however, advised the UN Secretary-General in a letter dated 15 April 1993 that it will make an annual voluntary contribution equal to one third of the annual cost of UNFICYP.

(5) UNFICYP has been successful in containing conflict. While the Australian Government is concerned that the continued presence of UNFICYP should not provide conditions for the parties to the dispute to avoid serious engagement in a negotiated settlement, we believe UNFICYP continues to play an important role in preventing an outbreak of violence on the buffer zone and maintaining the de facto ceasefire.

(6) The Australian Government fully supports the UN Secretary-General's efforts to reach a settlement including the proposed Set of Ideas, and the UN's role in finding a solution to the Cyprus problem.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Women's Consultative Committee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 29 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) What is the annual budget for the new Department of Employment Education and Training (DEET) Women's Consultative Committee; and (b) please give an approximate breakdown of how the annual budget will be spent.

(2) (a) How will the performance of the Consultative Committee be assessed; (b) will the Consultative Committee provide an annual report of its operations; and (c) will this be a public document; if so, please provide Senator Patterson with a copy when released.
(3) Please provide a list of members of the Consultative Committee once it has been appointed.
(4) What is the role and function of the Consultative Committee.
(5) How will the role and function of the DEET Consultative Committee differ from that of the Women's Bureau.
(6) Is it expected that the Consultative Committee will issue any publications on its operations; if so, please provide Senator Patterson with copies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Women's Consultative Committee is funded from within existing Departmental allocations. No separate budget has been determined for the Committee.

(2) (a) The Consultative Committee will report to the Secretary who will use corporate performance measurement mechanisms for this purpose; (b)-(c) As an internal Committee no publicly available annual report will be prepared.
(3) Membership details have not yet been finalised. These will be provided when available.

(4) The Committee's role is to provide the Secretary of the Department with strategic advice on women's employment, education and training and to advise on the impact on women clients and staff of new and existing programs. In addition, the Committee will monitor how women are faring in DEET policy and programs.
(5) The Committee's role and function will complement that of the Women's Bureau by broadening the scope of advice available to the Secretary.
(6) It is not expected that the Committee will issue any publications.
